title: fast food addict who spent
story: Fast food addict who spent £, a year on takeaways shows off st weight lossFormer fast food addict Carlie Lin, , from Balham in South London, confessed she used to spend thousands of pounds on takeaways each yearDuring her fast food addiction Carlie Lin, , would spend hundreds of pounds a month Image: Kennedy News and MediaByHannah PhillipsRyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov | commentsA fast food addict who spent £ a month on takeaways says sheaposs excited to flaunt her -stone weight loss on her first holiday in years.Carlie Lin, , from Balham in South London, confessed she guzzled her way through £, worth of take outs each year. The long list of fatty orders with extra sugar caused her to reach a massive st and lb. The -year-old admitted that in one sitting she would gorge on a large pizza, garlic bread side and a desert, or sometimes a curry, five nights a week.Carlie would also plunge her hand into the biscuit barrel up to  times a day, and scoff up to five on each visit. She said the bingeing on food created a vicious cycle of exhaustion and overeating. As she got tired from carrying all the weight around, she would then order take-out in the hopes of getting some energy. Among her favourite meals were fry ups, Chinese meals, fish and chips, Indian food or a pizza with a batch of cookie dough to finish.Size  Carlie became overweight during puberty and has suffered gastroesophageal reflux, the cause of extreme heartburn. Doctors recommended the gastric bypass surgery to help ease her symptoms. With the help of the weight-loss op and a new mindframe to ditch her unhealthy habits, Carlie lost an enormous amount of fat to shrink down to st lbs and a streamlined size . Carlie - who works as a picture framer - was so self-conscious about getting into a swimming costume she avoided holidays altogether for six years. But now sheaposs fitting into slinky numbers, and with an upcoming skin removal surgery, she canapost wait to showcase her new curves on the beach. Carlie says since having the weightloss surgery in November , she says sheaposs been given a new lease of le. Now instead of feeling sluggish all the time, sheaposs able to be more active with her six-year-old daughter, Betsy, and -year-old partner Leon Sinclair. Carlie is due to have excess skin removed to complete her new look in April  and the family are looking forward to their first family holiday next year where Carlie plans to wear a bikini for the first time in years. Though sheaposs no longer spending massive amounts on food, she is having to fork out on constantly updating her wardrobe. Among the new dishes she cooks are batch-cooked chillis and stews, and breakfasts that she canapost finish due to her egg-sized new stomach. Carlie said: Now, for breakfast I have one slice of French toast with blueberries and strawberries andI canapost finish the toast, I concentrate on the fruit. I have a fibre bar and grapes for elevenses and for lunch I have a sandwich thin with some ham and cucumber. I batch cook chilli con carne without the rice or stew without the potatoes for dinner. I enjoy cooking now more than I did, I like to use the slow cooker and just leave it. Carlieaposs diet beforeBREAKFASTNormally Carlie wouldnapost eat breakfast LUNCHBacon sandwich with six slices of bacon, packet of crisps and a yoghurt DINNERA large pizza, side of garlic bread and cookie dough SNACKSCarlie would snack on four or five biscuits between six and ten times a day, grapes, a fibre bar and four cans of diet cokeCarlieaposs diet afterBREAKFASTOne slice of French toast with blueberries and strawberries LUNCHOne sandwich thin, a slice of ham and cucumberDINNER Homemade chilli con carneSNACKSGrapes and a fibre barComment MORE ON Family holidaysFast foodJunk foodMental healthPanic attacksPizzaBoobsBikinisSwimming costumesChristmas dinnerChristmas shoppingChristmas party" data-immediate"data-immediate"Fancy an escape to the Chill newsletter for weekly inspiration and advice on UK holidays Sign Up!Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: great gran 90 told assemble
story: Great-gran, , told to assemble £, bed herself because of CovidThe great-grandmother ordered the bed from Barker and Stonehouse, at Teesside Park, and paid £, for the item, which included £ for it to be delivered to her home in Yarm, North YorkshireThe -year-old woman bought a new bed from Barker and Stonehouse at Teesside Retail Park Image: Barker  StonehouseByKristy DawsonChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov | comments A -year-old gran who bought a new £, bed has said she was told to assemble it herself due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.The great-grandmother, who wants to remain anonymous, ordered the bed from Barker and Stonehouse, at Teesside Park.In total, she paid £, for the item, which included £ for it to be delivered to her home in Yarm, North Yorkshire, Teesside Live reports.However, she said she was surprised to be told the retailer would not assemble the bed due to the Covid- pandemic - adding she would have to build it herself. The elderly woman said that when she explained her age and that she lived alone, they offered to put up her bed for an extra £.  The gran, who has two children, two grandchildren and two great-grandchildren, said: I bought an expensive bed, I thought I might as well - it will be the last bed I buy at my age wonapost it. They said they drop the bed in the bedroom and thataposs it. They said aposdue to the covid problem we arenapost assembling anythingapos. If theyaposre coming in and simply dumping the bed you would have as much chance of getting the virus from that as you would to make it up. They said itaposs simple to make it up, itaposs only about four screws. I said aposlook Iaposm , I live alone and thereaposs no way I couldapos. She added: Thereaposs no way I could lt the heavy head board and lt the mattress. I donapost think anyone living on their own could. They then said aposjust a minute, well for another £ we can come and do it later in the monthapos. Itaposs not that Iaposm squabbling about £ - itaposs the fact I wasnapost told when I purchased the bed. The woman said she asked for the bed to be delivered when her son and grandson were visiting the area, but claimed Barker and Stonehouse said it was not possible. She explained the firm suggested taking back her £ delivery fee and asking a relative to hire a van so they could pick the bed up and put it together, which she described as absolutely ridiculous. The woman said her newly decorated bedroom now has furniture in it but there is an empty space as the bed has not been delivered yet. Fortunately, she lives in a three-bedroom property and has beds in the other rooms which she can sleep in. She said that her family are unable to help her put it up on the next available delivery date so she has been left in limbo. The woman, who is still considering whether to pay out the extra cash, said: I think itaposs silly. Iaposm a very fit -year-old but there could be some that arenapost. They could have delivered it and they wouldnapost know what to do about the bed just dumped in the room. It could be very dficult for somebody in the same position as me. A spokesperson for Barker and Stonehouse told Teesside Live they were incredibly sorrythe additional delivery charge was not communicated at the time of purchase and that the issue was not resolved quickly and easily. They said they will waive the assembly charge and arrange a time to deliver and assemble her bed as soon as possible. The Mirror has contacted Barker and Stonehouse for comment. title: hairdresser spends 14000 house deposit
story: Hairdresser spends £, house deposit to bring two feral cats back from TurkeyKelly Walker spent the money she had saved for her house deposit to bring two cats she found during a holiday in Turkey home in the UK. It took almost a year, but she was finally reunited with themDelilah was about six weeks old when she was found by Kelly Walker Image: Kelly Walker   SWNSByMellissa DzinziDoug WhitbreadChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov | comments A hairdresser has spent almost £, to bring two feral cats she found in Turkey to her home in the UK.Kelly Walker, , visited the seaside resort of Antalya in November last year and during her trip she came across the felines, Delilah and Harriet. The woman, from Barnsley, South Yorkshire, started setting up feeding stations to try and win the catsapos trust and eventually brought them to a local vet for medical attention.She told Yorkshire Live : This vet looked at me like I was stupid. He said [of Delilah] aposshe’s only about six weeks old.She’s got parasites and sheaposs got all these dferent issues. She might not even live because she’s quite close to deathapos.  Kelly paid £, upfront to get Delilah and Harriet vaccinated, neutered and looked after at the veterinary surgery while she ed to England using cash she had saved up for a home deposit. She said: I’d saved up to buy a house. That money wasn’t just for spending on nothing but I just couldn’t leave these poor little souls like that with nobody to help them. I thought, aposwell, it’s not that badapos. People in this lockdown have been buying dogs for like thousands of pounds and Iaposm actually helping two cats. Kelly planned to fly to Romania on January , then to Istanbul, and finally to Antalya, where she would collect the cats from the vet and take them to the UK with her. However, due to strict lockdown rules in Turkey, she was now allowed to leave Istanbul Airport for days. While trying to find a solution to leave the airport, she slept on the terminalaposs seat, with no shops or restaurants open where she could buy food. Eventually, she ed to the UK and was advised to either let the kittens back onto the streets or put them to sleep. Luckily, Kelly found a pet hotel where Delilah and Harriet were looked after for a fee while she waited toonce more to Turkey. On October  this year, Kelly was finally reunited with Harriet and Delilah for the first time in nearly a year in Antalya after flying out to take them home.When she went to the airport, however, she was prohibited from flying again due to strict export protocols on live animals. Kelly said: I went to the airport with the cats, obviously, to get myself back to the UK, and I was told point-blank, ‘This is not possible. You cannot fly these into the UK from hereapos. I’d spent £, by that point so I was just totally defeated. I went from one airline to the other airline asking, and basically, getting the same reply. Kelly ed to the UK without the cats, then contacted an animal rights group that operated an international pet courier service from Turkey via Bucharest. The journey took place from October  to October , when she received confirmation the two cats were arriving at her home. Kelly said she does not regret spending her house deposit on Delilah and Harriet as she feels like she has done the right thing. She explained: I absolutely love animals. They’re my passion. I know that I spent that money, and I don’t make a lot of money. I’m only a hairdresser - but it made me feel like Iaposd done something worthwhile. title: hughie going through hard time
story: Hughie was going through a hard time - what I did was nowhere near as toughWhen Hughie Higgerson was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia, his best pal, Freddie Xavi was determined to be his biggest cheerleader. The dynamic duo have now won the GMB Young Fundraiser Pride of Britain Award Image: CollectByMatt RoperFeatures writer:,  Nov | commentsThe Pride of Britain audience was captivated by best friends Hughie Higginson and Freddie Xavi, who together have raised more than £, for the Manchester Children’s Hospital. The incredible feat began after Hughie, ten, was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia last September and began three years of treatment at the hospital. To say thank you he signed up for the hospital’s charity’s fundraising walk, but on the day was too ill to take part, so pal Freddie, , devised his own fundraising challenge, running km every day in the  days before Christmas. The two boys, both from Manchester, were joined on stage by Good Morning Britain’s Ben Shephard and Susanna Reid, who asked Freddieit was hard to keep going with his running challenge. “I knew that Hughie was going through a harder time. What I was doing was nowhere near as hard,” he replied.  “The bond between us is unbreakable, we’ll be friends forever,” said Hughie. The pair shared another unforgettable moment when Ben, knowing how Hughie loves singing and is a fan of YouTube star KSI, asked the youngster to sing one of his songs in front of Simon Cowell and Alesha Dixon. As he started singing, KSI himself sneaked up behind and surprised him. “I just want to say how proud I am of both of you. You are both strong-minded, strong willed and all you have been through, it’s so inspiring,” said SKI, who was joined by his own pal, Olympian Mo Farah, to hand over the award. Speaking after leaving the stage, the excited boys - who KSI had just invited to play a game of FIFA with him - said they would be taking their Pride of Britain award into school on Monday. Hughie said: “It amazing, it’s an honour to even be here never mind to get the award, it’s so good.” Mo said: “It’s incredible to see how much running, the courage and the commitment they have at that age. To do it for one of his best friends, theres no words to really describe it. I’m just so proud of them.” Comment MORE ON Ben ShephardSusanna ReidPride of Britain AwardsGood Morning BritainLeukaemia" data-immediate"data-immediate"Our Pride of Britain newsletter brings you awards news and inspiring stories - dont miss out!Sign me upInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: hungry punters invited take 6000
story: Hungry punters invited to take on ,-calorie steak which weighs same as newborn babyThe belly-busting challenge, at The Black Ladd Pub, in Greater Manchester, is free for anyone who can complete it - otherwise they have to fork out £. for the entire mealCould you take on this monster steak in under  minutes  Image: Kennedy News The Black Ladd  FacebookByFlorence Freeman:,  Nov A pub has put their punters to the test to complete a steak weighing a whopping oz - the same weight as a newborn baby The Black Ladd Pub, in Greater Manchester, announced the beef banquet of a ,-calorie rump steak, glazed in garlic butter with a healthy serving of onion rings and chips on the side. Manager, Keiran Leach, has challenged those to eat the mammoth steak in  minutes - or fork out £. for the entire meal. So far, the feast has only faced one challenger, who was thrashed by the spread. Keiran said: I think he did well, but the fact that he did well and only got that far shows how hard it would be to complete because you do have to finish everything.  I think it would be one in a million for someone to be able to with the size it is. This is not Kerianaposs first rodeo with a dinner competition, after he previously hosted a oz Tomahawk steak challenge. He and the pub owner finished that steak challenge victoriously. But the failure of his first ever challenger at the oz steak has certainly not lured away any interest. Calls have been made from across the country - as far as Stoke, Cumbria and Scotland - to grab a chance at defeating the mighty meat feast. Many on social media have voiced their support of the challenge, but some voiced their concerns about it being seemingly wasteful and unhealthy.  Kieran said: I understand the point of it because it is a considerable amount of meat for one person, but itaposs them that are choosing to do that. From a business point of view weaposre trying to get publicity but we do understand itaposs a lot of meat for one person. If any hungry munchers want a chance to complete the epic steak challenge, they have until the end of November to try it out. The challenge in full: oz steak , chips , onion rings , tomatoes , mushrooms , garlic butter .Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON FoodNewborn baby" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: incredible oxford covid vaccine team
story: Incredible Oxford Covid vaccine team - who gave us all our lives backThe team of scientists who worked day and night to deliver the Oxford Covid vaccine in record time were honoured with the Special Recognition Award at Pride of Britain Image: Rowan Grfiths   Daily MirrorByMatt RoperFeatures writer:,  Nov | comments “We couldn’t be here without them,” said Carol as she announced the Special Recognition award for the team of scientists who developed the Oxford coronavirus vaccine.The six men and women representing Prof Sarah Gilbert’s team received the loudest and longest standing ovation of the night, as the audience applauded them for nearly two minutes. The team worked throughout lockdown, working -hour days with some juggling home schooling with their vital research as they created the world’s most potent weapon against Covid in record time. By the end of July , a billion doses of the Oxford AstraZeneca vaccine had been delivered to more than  countries.  They received their gong from TV icon Stephen Fry, who said he “would have walked  miles over broken glass barefoot to present the award”. Afterwards, he said he was the one who was starstruck. “I couldn’t believe I was going to speak to them. I’m never going to meet Edward Jenner, who gave the first smallpox vaccinations, or Fleming who discovered penicillin, but these people are of an equal status. “It’s extraordinary what they did.” Dr Catherine Green said: “It’s lovely to have the recognition of the British public. We are just doing our job but to be recognised for doing your job under extraordinary circumstances feels really momentous.” Comment MORE ON Stephen FryPride of Britain AwardsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Our Pride of Britain newsletter brings you awards news and inspiring stories - dont miss out!Sign me upInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news inspirational-pride-britain-winners-including-"Pride of Britain: Carol Vorderman praises incredible winnersByNatasha Wynarczyk:,  Oct Updated:,  Nov | commentsThe most star-studded night is back as the Daily Mirror Pride of Britain Awards hits our screens for the first time since .More than  famous faces – including Prince Charles, Ant and Dec, Holly Willoughby, Ed Sheeran, Sharon Stone and Simon Cowell – came together to celebrate our unsung heroes.And for the first time in Pride of Britain’s -year history, host Carol Vorderman was joined onstage by a co-host, Ashley Banjo. Carol said: “The night will be a proper celebration.” Here, we reveal some of this year’s inspirational winners...Letime Achievement – Rosemary Cox, , WolverhamptonSuccessfully campaigned to set up the first Organ Donor Register in the UK, helping to save thousands of lives.  After their -year-old son Peter died in  following a brain tumour, Rosemary and John Cox saw the need for a register for people who wish to donate their organs. Peter had asked before his death for his organs to be used to help others and his sacrice saved or transformed the lives of  people.Have your say on this story in the comment section But his parents found that although patients in need of a transplant were listed on a central NHS computer, there was no equivalent register for potential donors.Over the next five years, the couple from Wolverhampton and their daughter Christine launched their campaign, travelling the country fundraising, lobbying politicians and creating awareness for their cause.Their efforts culminated at the  Conservative Party Conference when Christine made an impassioned plea from the  for a register of donorsapos wishes.Health Secretary Virginia Bottomley pledged there and then to set up an NHS Organ Donor Register, which launched on th October .  Today the number of people who have registered their organ donation decision on the NHS Organ Donor Register has reached over  million or % of the UK population. Meanwhile, since the register was established on the th October , over , people have donated their organs after their death and over , deceased donor transplants have taken place. Rosemary is now . Her husband John passed away in , but their son’s legacy lives on and she continues to campaign to promote the benefits of organ transplantation. When the NHS marked the register’s th anniversary in , it was revealed it had saved or transformed , lives. And over the last  months, NHS Blood and Transplant facilitated nearly , transplants. Special Recognition – Rob Allen, , NorthamptonFounded Sands United, an inspirational network of football teams where men who have lost babies and young children can come together to grieve Rob and his we Charlotte’s third child Niamh was stillborn, days before her due date in . They were helped through their loss by the stillbirth charity Sands, but at one meeting, Rob counted  women and three men. Realising that grieving dads were finding it dficult to reach out for help, he organised a charity football match to raise funds for Sands, but also giving men an opportunity to come together and talk about their loss. The one-off game, featuring bereaved fathers, grandfathers, uncles and brothers, raised £,, but the emotional benefit for the players was even more signicant.  And so, Sands United was born, and entered a local league in Northampton. But Rob’s impact has spread far wider. Inspired by his example, there are now more than  Sands United teams across Britain. E ach team’s kit is embroidered with the names of the babies they have lost, and hundreds of men, and their families, have been empowered to open up about their loss, and support each other through sport.This Morning Emergency Services Award – Stephen Warton, , CumbriaPart-time firefighter risked his le to e to the rescue of a teenager who had been submerged in icy waters for more than  minutes. Kacper Krauze, , had been attempting to swim across the River Eden in Appleby-in-Westmorland in February .The weather was unseasonably warm, but the icy water sent his body into shock, and he sank to the bottom of the river.Appleby fire and rescue officers, who are retained with full-time jobs including butcher and mechanic, were the first emergency responders on the scene. Crew manager Stephen, a painter and decorator, and firefighter John Bell went into the river, supported by colleagues David Anderton, Michael Dowding, Bradley Hall, James Wood and Neil Aitken from the river bank.  After a short search they located Kacper under two to three metres of water. Unable to e down and reach him due to his safety gear, Stephen went against protocol and took off his flotation equipment and helmet so he could e fully and bring the boy to the surface. Kacper had been underwater for about  minutes, and when Stephen brought him to the bank, he was in cardiac arrest and severely hypothermic. Paramedics resuscitated him and he was flown by air ambulance to hospital, where he was placed in an induced coma. He spent several weeks in intensive care but has since made a steady recovery. Mum Wioletta said: “It’s a miracle he survived. Every day is a little bit better, and he’s slowly getting back to normal.Good Morning Britain Young Fundraiser – Hughie Higginson, , and Freddie Xavi, , LancashireBest pals have raised more than £, after Hughie was diagnosed with Leukaemia and Freddie vowed to help him thank his doctors and nurses Hughie was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia last September and began three years of treatment at the Royal Manchester Childrenaposs Hospital. He wanted to say thank you to the medics looking after him so he signed up for the hospital charity’s fundraising walk.  Sadly, on the day he was too ill to take part, which is when best pal Freddie stepped up. He devised his own fundraising challenge on behalf of his pal, running km every day in the  days leading up to Christmas. He completed the final km on Christmas morning, pounding the streets before opening his presents. Hughie summoned all his strength to join his mate on the final stretch so they could cross the line together, hand-in-hand. The football-mad boys’ inspirational friendship, and incredible fundraising efforts touched hearts in their Lancashire community and beyond, and the pair have now raised more than £,. Georgia Sleigh from the hospital charity said: “Freddie and Hughie are just incredible – words just don’t do justice to how inspiring they both are.”Child of Courage – Harmonie-Rose Allen, , BathQuadruple amputee given a % chance of survival as a toddler has inspired the nation with her courage and unbreakable spirit  Harmonie-Rose was  months old, and had recently taken her first steps, when she started coughing and struggling for breath. Doctors twice allowed her home from AE, but the next day, she went floppy and a rash appeared. This time she was blue lit to Bristol Children’s Hospital, but doctors did not knowshe would survive the journey. She arrived in a critical condition and her limbs had turned black. Meningococcal septicaemia had damaged her legs, arms and the tip of her nose, leaving surgeons with no choice but to amputate. She was given a % chance of survival, and her parents were asked for permission to turn off her le supportnecessary.  Since then, and after more than  operations, she has beaten the odds. With enormous public help and unique family support she has thrived and now loves writing, drawing as well as many sports including swimming, dancing, gymnastics. In , she crossed the finish line of the Bath Half Marathon on her prosthetics, raising £, for the children’s charity, Time Is Precious. During the first lockdown in , she completed her . challenge, tackling six things doctors said she’d never do because of her disabilities,  times.These were running, singing, drawing, swimming, gymnastics and jumping, and she raised more than £, for Meningitis Now.Her latest challenge this year was to scale a climbing wall  times and run m for the first time on her blades in a bid to raise £, for an accessible playground.In March she received her first bionic arm. One of her first jobs was to paint her new nails and it also means she can hold her mumaposs hand for the first time since she was a baby. Spirit of Adventure – Max Woosey, , North Devon“Tent Boy” Max has spent more than  nights sleeping under canvas, raising £, for his local hospice Neighbour and family friend Rick Abbott was terminally ill with cancer when he gave Max a tent, and told him to “go have an adventure”. When Rick passed away, Max decided to do a sponsored camp out to raise money for the hospice which had cared for his friend in his final weeks. In March , he set himself the target of sleeping in the tent until the end of lockdown and hoped he might raise £. As lockdown restrictions dragged on, Max refused to come in from the cold and donations poured into his JustGiving page. Now, nearly  months later, he is still on his fundraising mission. At pm each night, the -year-old puts on his pyjamas, collects up his teddies, the Beano and his torch, says goodnight to his parents and makes his way to the garden.  The marathon camper has now been sleeping outdoors for more than  nights, braving sub-zero frosts, heatwaves, and even Storm Bella. He has raised more than £, for North Devon Hospice, enough to pay for  community nurses and cover more than half the hospice’s estimated losses due to the pandemic. Max has also inspired thousands of other children to take part in a Big Camp Out for Action For Children,Special Recognition – Gee Walker, , LiverpoolForgave her son’s killers and devoted her le to promoting racial harmony in his memory, building a legacy of love to overcome hate  The brutal racist murder of Anthony Walker in  shocked the nation. The -year-old aspiring lawyer was chased from a bus stop in Huyton, Merseyside and killed with an ice pick in an unprovoked attack. His mum Gee refused to let her le, and Anthony’s memory, be consumed by bitterness, declaring of his killers: I forgive them. I don’t hate them. Hate is what killed my son. I am in enough pain. Why take on and carry about hate and anger as well ” Her actions in the following  years have been just as powerful as her words. She founded the Anthony Walker Foundation in  to combat racism and offer a space for people to feel safe after suffering racial abuse. In the last five years, the Foundation has worked with nearly , young people through educational and outreach programmes in schools. Its victim support services have also helped nearly , people who have experienced hate crime while volunteers have engaged with thousands in a bid to build safer, stronger communities. Despite her achievements on a national scale, when asked what she is most proud of, she says simply: “Being a mum and a nan”Environmental Champion – Amy and Ella Meek,  and , NottinghamCampaigning sisters set up a kid’s charity to help fight the global scourge of plastic pollution Amy and Ella are the founders of youth social action group Kids Against Plastic, which is now a registered charity. It calls for action against plastic pollution and encourages iniduals, schools and businesses to be more ‘plastic clever’ and ditch single-use plastics where possible. So far more than , schools and  cafes, businesses, festivals and councils have committed to being ‘plastic clever’. The sisters, from Nottingham, have given TED talks, spoken with leaders in the aviation industry about reducing their plastic footprint, addressed politicians in the House of Commons and spoken at the United Nations’ Young Activist Summit in December . Theyaposve personally collected , pieces of rubbish, one for every sea mammal killed by plastic pollution every year, and run a scheme to champion other anti-plastic activists who do the same around the country. Their first book, Be Plastic Clever, has just been published.Prince’s Trust Young Achiever – Hassan Alkhawam, , Northern IrelandWhen Hassan Alkhawam, aged , and his family fled their home in Syria due to the war, they were given refugee status and rehomed in Northern Ireland in .  Since arriving in the country, Hassan has transformed his le. He is now studying Software Engineering at university and has been a key worker in Tesco during the Covid  pandemic. Before coming to Northern Ireland, Hassan’s father became ill and was no longer able to work, meaning Hassan had to leave full-time education and get a job to support the family. When he arrived in Northern Ireland, Hassan wanted toto education and fulfil his dream of going to university but needed to take an English language course before he could apply.  At the time, Hassan was not working and didn’t have money to pay for the course. A friend told him about The Prince’s Trust and Hassan got in touch to seethey could help. He took part in The Prince’s Trust Get into Retail programme, a training and mentoring scheme that gives young people the skills, experience, and confidence they need to find a job. After completing the four-week programme he was offered a job and started working there just before the pandemic began. As well as working part time and studying, Hassan is a voluntary Director of a local charity, NI Hyatt, that supports vulnerable members of the refugee and migrant communities. He has recently completed courses in advocacy and interpreting so that he can help this community settle into le in Northern Ireland.Special Recognition - The Oxford Vaccine Team “We couldn’t be here without them,” said Carol as she announced the Special Recognition award for the team of scientists who developed the Oxford coronavirus -gtcoronavirus vaccine. The six men and women representing Prof Sarah Gilbert’s team received the loudest and longest standing ovation of the night, as the audience applauded them for nearly two minutes. The team throughout lockdown, fitting in -hour days around home-schooling to create the world’s most potent weapon against Covid in record time. By the end of July , more than a billion doses of the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine had been delivered to more than  countries worldwide. The team received their gong from TV icon Stephen Fry, who said he “would have walked  miles over broken glass barefoot to present the award”.  Afterwards, Stephen said he was the one who was starstruck. “I couldn’t believe I was going to speak to them,” he said. “I’m never going to meet Edward Jenner, who gave the first smallpox vaccinations, or Fleming who discovered penicillin, but these people are of an equal status. “It’s extraordinary what they did.” Dr Catherine Green said: “It’s lovely to have the recognition of the British public. We are just doing our job but to be recognised for doing your job under extraordinary circumstances feels really momentous.” Comment MORE ON Gee WalkerPride of Britain AwardsEducationLoveSchoolsTeenagersOn Instagram" data-immediate"data-immediate"Our Pride of Britain newsletter brings you awards news and inspiring stories - dont miss out!Sign me upInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: i watched brit sipped champagne
story: I watched as mum sipped champagne and thanked medics for helping her to dieDawn Voice-Cooper, , received her final wish for an assisted death at an organisation in ­Switzerland, where she released a fatal dose of ­barbiturates into her bloodstreamDawn pictured in the late afternoon at a park in Basel ahead of her assisted death at the Le Circle clinic Image: Rowan Grfiths   Daily MirroropinionByAmy-Clare MartinNews reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsIn this country, we are taught to keep fighting. To plough on. But as soon as I arrived in Basel, Switzerland, it felt clear that the Swiss have a very dferent approach to death. They are practical and pragmatic, but compassionate. Assisted dying has been legal there since . And when I asked Lecircle’s president Dr Erika Preisig why Switzerland is the only country in the world which allows non-residents to travel there to die, she replied simply: “Because it is a human right.”Dr Preisig’s foundation helps around  people per year to end their le and people travel from across the globe to die on theirown terms. The fear is that the day-to-day work of helping people to die would make you detached or callous to the enormous responsibility that comes with facilitating someone’s death. However, it never felt like this was something the team at Lecircle undertook lightly. Indeed, Dr Preisig herself was acquitted of murder in  over assisting the death of a woman in her s with a psychiatric condition but was found to have violated the handling of the drug Sodium Pentobarbital. An appeal court upheld her acquittal this year, but the case could still be appealed again in the Swiss federal courts. You could see the weight of the court case on Dr Preisig. Yet despite the personal risks, her commitment to Lecircle and her belief in assisted dying remains unchanged. She even invited Dawn, her friends and I to her home for dinner on the night before she died. It is hard to know what to say to someone on their last night alive and I was feeling ill-prepared for dinner table conversation. Part of me expected to see some kind of release in Dawn – some freedom that comes from knowing you have nothing left to lose. But she had no grand plans for her last night on this earth and seemed quiet and reflective. On the short walk from the car back to her hotel, Dawn stumbled, wincing in pain, as her hip failed her. So the following morning when I watched her struggle slowly up the steps to Lecircle it was moving to think these were the last few steps she would ever make.  Lecircle is laid out much like an apartment – art on the walls, a big sofa, a table and a bed in the corner. It is not sterile like a hospital, but never-the-less as I stepped into the room it was strange to consider how many people died there. I confess at first I found Dawn’s choice harder to understand than some others. She did not look like a woman at death’s door and her complaints were ied and complex.  But I have never walked a day in her shoes and it was clear to me that she had fought to get the death she wanted. The assisted dying debate is serious and complex. It is high time it was given proper scrutiny by UK lawmakers. Leaving seriously ill Brits feeling they must travel abroad – sometimes before they wish – is not a long-term solution.Comment MORE ON HospitalsCourt caseHuman rightsAssisted suicide" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. limitcontent_window_hourssorted_bytotal_visible_contents,ozoneDisplayPrebidEnabled:true,nativeAppBanner:true,ixDisplayPrebidEnabled:true,commentCountEnabled:true,lotameMantisDisabled:,video.imaVersion:.,videoPrebidEnabled:true,video.suppressDates:true,delayVideoAdsUntilConsented:true,fbia.chartbeat.inbody:,appNexusVideoPrebidEnabled:true,parentUrl:https:www.mirror news uk-news kate-middleton-gives-rare-glimpse-"COP: Royal family arrive at Kelvingrove Gallery and MuseumByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Nov | comments The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge almost looked like ordinary commuters as they arrived in Glasgow for the COP climate change summit.The pair were snapped walking through Glasgow Central station as they arrived in the city ahead of meeting with world leaders at the conference. In the picture, posted on the Network Rail Twitter page, the couple could be seen wearing the same clothes they were later pictured in that afternoon while meeting Scouts.And Kate carried a slightly open Smythson tote bag, costing around £, which gave royal fans a rare glimpse of what she likes to bring with her on trips.  So what was inside  Well is appears some folders and possibly even a slim laptop - maybe Kate was doing some work on the train  Meanwhile, according to the book, Kate: A Biography, she also tends to carry four items with her - a compact mirror, blotting paper, a handkerchief and lip balm. Andher bag is big enough, the book says she sometimes brings her camera to snap some personal photos.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. During their visit to the Scouts, William and Kate made vegetarian burgers, repaired bicycles, and helped to re-wild a grassy bank at Alexandra Park in Dennistoun, Glasgow, while world leaders met at COP nearby.The workshop was part of the international Promise To The Planet campaign, which aims to teach million Scouts how to lead more environmentally friendly lives. Eddie OaposRourke, who supports Scout groups in Glasgow and Lanarkshire as district commissioner, described the royal couple as a real inspiration. He said: They were a real inspiration to all the Scouts who are working hard to make changes to protect the planet.Later Kate dazzled in a royal blue dress as she and Prince William met world leaders at the COP summit.She wore an Eponine coat dress and paired the £, dress with navy heels. title: mum 21 who gave birth
story: Mum, , who gave birth in coma after catching Covid meets daughter one month laterSaskia Lane, , gave birth in a medically-induced coma after being struck down by Covid. Now, still seriously ill, shes encouraging people to get vaccinated after meeting her daughterSaskia first got to hold her daughter Betsy Mae Blackman weeks after giving birth to her in a medically-induced coma Image: Caters News AgencyByCally BrooksLaurie Churchman:,  Nov | commentsA young mum who gave birth in a coma after contracting Covid has finally met her daughter – nearly a month later. Saskia Lane, , became seriously ill with Covid in August and was admitted to intensive care. She was eight months pregnant, and had to undergo an emergency caesarean while in an induced coma. Doctors at the Princess Royal Hospital in Haywards Heath decided to keep Saskia in an induced coma during the birth so sheaposd have the best chance of survival. After three weeks, Saskia was woken up. She and met her daughter Betsy Mae Blackman met for the first time on September . Saskia was also reunited with her partner Lee Blackman, .  Saskia, from Partridge Green, Sussex, is now urging other pregnant women to have the Covid vaccine after she initially decided to turn it down. Saskiaaposs mum Becky Knight, , explained: Saskia was diagnosed with gestational diabetes whilst pregnant with Betsy and decided not to have the vaccine initially after worrying about the impact it could have on Betsy. I encouraged her to get the vaccine but unfortunately, she had her first jab a few days before contracting Covid so it wasnapost effective. She initially felt worn out and tired but eventually, she began experiencing breathing dficulties and on her third trip to AE, they admitted her to the intensive care unit. The doctors decided that Betsy should be delivered immediately to help her body have the best possible chance to beating Covid and she was aware of this. But after putting her to sleep, doctors decided to keep her in an induced coma to allow her body to rest and recover. We were all absolutely devastated - we couldnapost go in and visit her because she had Covid and Lee wasnapost able to meet Betsy until she was a few days old. When she was finally woken up, she was extremely confused and didnapost understand what had happened, so I reassured her that Betsy was fine and healthy and we gave her, Lee, and Betsy the chance to meet for the first time privately.  Betsy was born healthy and weighed lb oz. Saskia is still at Guyaposs Hospital in London receiving treatment after severe damage to her lungs. She was transferred to three dferent hospitals as medical staff battled to keep her alive. Saskia was put on a le support machine at St Thomasapos hospital in London for two and a half weeks – and her mother said this ultimately saved her le. Becky said: Sheaposs been in intensive care for nine weeks now and we canapost wait for her to come home. Her lung has collapsed so itaposs only half the size of a normal one.She also has sepsis in her lung and has had a total of six drains put into her lungs, as well as a tracheotomy which left her unable to speak for three weeks when she woke up.Becky added: While she was in a coma, we were able to see her only through video calls and it was devastating seeing her in that state. Saskia is now terried of going home because she doesnapost want to catch Covid again. Itaposs traumatised her, Becky said. Saskia wants to encourage everyone to get the vaccine following her experience. The family praised the hospital staff who have cared for Saskia, saying the nurses and doctors went above and beyond to look after her and save her le. Saskia is also a mum to Eliza Blackman, whoaposs nearly two years old. The family are fundraising to support Lee and Saskia once she s home from hospital. Lee, who works as a  beater, has had to go part time following Saskiaaposs illness and is looking after both Betsy and Eliza while she is in hospital. Becky added: Thereaposs no fundingyou contract Covid and are seriously ill and have to take time off work. Sheaposs also been diagnosed with postnatal depression so weaposre hoping to get her some more funding to cover therapy costs once sheaposs home.To donate, visit: Help For Saskia’s Recovery and Her Family, organized by Charlotte Lane Comment MORE ON HospitalsPregnancyGiving birthMental health" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum 51 whose sore throat
story: Mum, , whose sore throat was sign of cancer died before marrying fiancéLesley Perowne, , from Warrington, Cheshire, had complained of a sore throat getting "worse and worse" just before Christmas last year but her throat then became swollen and blood started mixing with her salivaLesley Perowne, , from Warrington in Cheshire, was preparing to marry her fiancé Giuseppe Salamone as there were high hopes for her cancer recovery Image: UGCByAaliyah RuggRyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov | commentsA mum whose sore throat was a sign of cancer died before she could marry her long-term partner.Lesley Perowne, , from Warrington, Cheshire, started suffering with a sore throat that kept getting worse and worse before Christmas last year.She took herself to the GP after her gullet became swollen and she started spitting blood.The -year-old was given the devastating diagnosis that she had esophaegal cancer, which has a very low survival rate, Liverpool Echo reports.Despite the horric prognosis, her family had high hopes for her recovery. Lesley and fiancé Giuseppe Salamone were making plans to marry and wanted to hold the big day later this year.  Giuseppe also took time to look after his ill partner and their -year-old daughter, Mia.Giusseppeaposs brother Luca, said : Lesley started chemo but she was throwing it all up and it had to be stopped because of complications.She couldnapost eat and eventually couldnapost drink so the only option was radiotherapy. Luca said despite the struggles, they received a phone call from Lesley just weeks ago, with positive news that the cancer was shrinking and felt her throat was finally opening up. However, Lesley suddenly deteriorated and after being admitted to hospital, doctors identied a chest infection and clot on her lung. Sadly she died on October . Luca said: We had a glimmer of hope. They found a chest infection and they were going to sort it. But then suddenly, within days, she was gone. We really thought she would come threw it, at least in the short term, so in that sense it came as a big shock. Due to the struggles over the last year, Luca, who lives in Buckley, said his brotheraposs family has aposdebts racked upapos and himself and his we Sally decided to take action to help. A fundraiser was launched to help cover the funeral costs, which surpassed the £, target within days. He added: Their backs were up against a wall. You can be surprised at how nice people are when they see someone in need. I wasnapost expecting the target to be reached within days. Lesley was very strong willed, probably the worst patient the hospital had ever seen. It was like she didnapost take it seriously, she thought it would be a blip in the grand scheme of her le. She was so tough.  She just carried on. She was a hard worker, ambitious and very honest. She has always done things for people in need, was always there to help. They were going to get married this year so my brother is also mourning what could have been.The fundraising page has already raised over £, to help towards the funeral costs.Luca wrote on the page: May I ask for anyone who knew Lesley, to come forward and donate even the smallest amount to help raise money for her funeral. Giuseppe and Mia donapost want anything extravagant , but just enough to give Lesley a dignied and memorable send off. When I visited Lesley at hospital a couple of months ago with Giuseppe and Mia, we sat in the car park and planned in our heads for the future. Lesley said something like In a few months, we can all get away somewhere and have a good laugh, forget about all this silliness! I hope youaposre somewhere special Les. Pour yourself a glass of red and weaposll all be there with you soon enough, for that family getaway. We all love and miss you dearly. title: mum caravan full mould holes
story: Mum in caravan full of mould and holes fears shell be homeless for ChristmasDeborah Lendrum has been living in an "appalling" static caravan in St Austell, Cornwall which she could now be forced to leave before Christmas due to it being in a dangerous state of disrepairDeborah Lendrum has said she fears being on the street by Christmas Image: Greg Martin   Cornwall LiveByEvie TownendTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsA mum says she is living in an appalling caravan ridden with black mould and holes in the floor, leaving her scared she could be homeless before Christmas.Deborah Lendrum has been living in her static caravan in St Austell for three and a half years but she claims that despite complaints the desperate conditions have not been looked at, reported CornwallLive.She works as a cleaner for holiday rentals and pays £ rent each month. Despite this, her caravan is one of  motorhomes on the Manor Park site that have fallen into a dangerous state of disrepair. The “appalling” living conditions include condemned gas boilers, no insulation, extreme black mould, holes in single glazed windows and collapsing floors and walls. Deborah suffers from chronic obstructive pulmonary lung disease and described how her living conditions compromise her health, as well as that of her sonaposs, Alex Lendrum, who also resides on the site and suffers from mental health problems.  She said: “In winter, I wake up with a wet mattress and sheets from the damp in my room, so I have to sleep in the living room area. You can see your own breath, itaposs that cold. That can’t be good for anyoneaposs health. My son suffers from depression and he is raising his -year-old daughter here. His caravan is worse than mine. “I take a lot of pride in my home, and it’s one of the better ones, but you feel like you’re fighting a losing battle when the wallpaper keeps falling down due to mould. “Everyone is living in fear. It is a very tense and worrying time. Not only have we been living in awful conditions but we now face being made homeless before Christmas. People have families, pets and responsibilities. It’s our whole lives.” The site was recently bought by Shadwell Parks Limited, who employed PLL Management in October to manage it on their behalf. They are due to be inspecting all units this week. Any that have deteriorated beyond reasonable repair will be condemned as unfit for private residence. The residents in condemned properties will be served a  days’ notice to vacate. The company that now owns the site says it is in the process of acquiring more units.  A spokesman from PLL said: “We are seeking to resolve the issues Shadwell Park has inherited from the previous site owners. “Unfortunately, due to the current post-Brexit climate, it is proving extremely challenging to secure reliable, professional and experienced contractors for emergency call-outs. Additionally, the industry is experiencing ious shortages in unit and building materials. “Shadwell Park is in the process of acquiring new second hand units for the site which should be available in December .” When contacted, the previous site owners, Hills Brothers Residential and Leisure Parks, said: We have nothing to comment. The issues have nothing to do with us since we no longer own the site. title: mum investigating salmonella pork scratchings
story: Mum investigatingsalmonella from pork scratchings caused heart failureMum-of-two Susan Williamson, , has instructed lawyers to investigate whether the salmonella she caught from a pack of pork scratchings was the cause of her heart failure at a County Durham hospitalMum-of-two Susan Williamson, , was diagnosed with heart failure after being admitted to a County Durham hospital after catching salmonella from pork scratchings Image: Andy Commins   Daily MirrorByJeremy ArmstrongRyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov  A mum-of-two has started legal action to find outpork scratchings linked to a salmonella outbreak led to her heart failure.The aposMr Porkyapos products were recalled in August after  people were reported to have suffered diarrhoea, vomiting and fever. Susan Williamson, , ended up in hospital with salmonella infantis. After a number of follow-up tests, she was diagnosed with heart failure. She has now instructed public health experts at Irwin Mitchell to investigate whether her heart condition was linked to her illness. She said: “The last few months have been an absolute nightmare. It doesn’t seem to be coming to an end anytime soon. When I fell ill after eating the pork scratchings, I thought it might make me a bit sick and off colour for a few days.  Never did I ever imagine that it would lead to salmonella and I would still be suffering two months on. She added: I’m still very unwell now and have been told I’ll need medical care for a long time. Susan, of Blackhall Colliery, Co Durham, bought a multipack of five bags of pork scratchings on Aug. . She fell ill on Aug.  and started to suffer with sickness and diarrhoea and her symptoms also included hallucinations. On Sept. , she attended hospital where she was given a chest X-ray. An ECG established that she had suffered heart failure and she was readmitted to hospital.  She had been due to go on holiday with husband Paul but two motorhome trips were cancelled because of her illness. The Food Standards Agency recalled packs of Mr Porky, Jay’s and The Real Pork Crackling Company, all Tayto Groupaposs products, which expire before February, . The cases of salmonella were reported between Sept.  and Aug this year, the agency said. The illness usually causes fever, diarrhoea, and abdominal cramps. Symptoms typically resolve themselves. But they can be more severe and lead to hospitalisation, especially in the very young and those with weakened immune systems.  Irwin Mitchell is representing eight people who fell ill after eating the snacks. Clare Pearson, their specialist public health lawyer, said: “Susan is among those diagnosed with Salmonella Infantis and other illnesses after consuming pork scratchings. “Not only is salmonella a serious bacterial infection, it can often lead to long-lasting health problems, and even death. Salmonella has been known to have the ability to lead to cardiovascular complications. We’re now investigating whether Susan’s heart failure is linked to her salmonella infection. Snack giant Tayto said they took safety of their products aposvery seriouslyapos and swtly halted production, issuing a product recall. “Since then, with the relevant agencies, we have conducted a detailed investigation and implemented changes before restarting production, said a spokesman. “We have been in touch with a number of consumers directly and are working closely with them to resolve their concerns. We are very sorry to hear that a number of people are still feeling unwell and we wish them a speedy recovery.” Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Irwin MitchellHospitalsHeart diseaseFood poisoningSalmonella" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news pride-britain-moment-oxford-scientists-"Pride of Britain: Oxford vaccine team receive special awardByKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov This is the moment the Oxford-AstraZeneca team were presented with their Pride of Britain Award, after astounding the world by creating a Covid vaccine in just a year. Producing a vaccine normally takes  years but the dedicated staff put in -hour days – and lived off Mini Cheddars and Bounty bars – to turn it around in just  months. On Saturday, their hard work was ­rewarded with the Special Recognition prize. Six members of the -plus team of leading scientists accepted the award during the Daily Mirror Pride of Britain Awards in partnership with TSB at the Grosvenor House Hotel in London. As they took to the stage they were greeted by a rapturous applause, and the team joked they weaposre not comfortable with the attention from the crowd.  Pride of Britain co-host Carol Vorderman said presenting the Oxford team with their prize was a particularly poignant moment for her. Speaking on the Good Morning Britain, she said: I donapost knowyou felt it in the room but when the Oxford Vaccine Team came out, I think everybody was emotional and the standing ovations went on and on and on. I think everybody felt every emotion of the last  months kind of came to the forefront really and they came as such modest scientists. Carol was also overjoyed to have all of last yearaposs winners there too as they only had a virtual ceremony last year.The Oxford-AstraZeneca team were fuelled by vending machine snacks as they worked around the clock to develop their le-saving Covid jab. Among those walking the red carpet on Saturday night was Dr Catherine Green, who manufactured the first vaccine. She said: “The vaccine was always ­going to be the way out of the pandemic and here we are! “We wanted to walk the red carpet as a team because that’s what a was – a team effort. The university went into lockdown so we were living off the ­vending ­machines, eating Mini Cheddars and Bounty bars. “It feels great to be finally letting our hair down after the last  months.” And Prof Theresa Lambe, who co-designed the vaccine, added: “I know it sounds really boring but we were just doing our day jobs and we hoped it would help. We’re really glad it did so people can come together again on an amazing night like this.” Dr Sandy Douglas, the brains behind the process of mass-­developing the jab, said: “To receive this award means a lot ­because more than anything, it was the most amazing teamwork.”  So far, one billion doses of the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine have been delivered to  countries around the world. It is estimated to have saved more than , lives in the UK alone. Dr Douglas added: “We knew we had a chance that we might be able to do something extraordinary. “Me and my colleagues knew thousands of people were going to die each daywe didn’t act fast, so every day we were faster, the more lives we saved.” Watch Daily Mirror Pride of Britain Awards, Tonight, ITV, pm. title: pride britain night love tears
story: Pride of Britain - a night of love, tears and a shot in the arm for us allThe nd Daily Mirror Pride of Britain Awards recognise the heroes who live in our community - and this years ceremony was truly something special Image: Andy StenningByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist:,  Nov | commentsPride of Britain is a song for unsung heroes - and since the moment Paul McCartney attended the first awards in , its unofficial theme has always been ‘All You Need Is Love’. years on, love remained the heartbeat of this year’s glittering occasion.Whether it was the incredible Gee Walker’s children telling her ‘We love you, mum’, or Joanna Lumley telling organ donor campaigner Rosemary Cox she loved her, or Ed Sheeran ’s love song to Harmonie-Rose Allen who lost her legs and arms to meningitis, love was all around.It shone through the remarkable friendship between two young boys Hughie Higginson and Freddie Xavi.It was in the solidarity of Sands United, the football team for dads who have lost babies. And it was in the camaraderie of the Oxford team who kept each other going to discover a world-changing vaccine.  In the year that Pride of Britain lost its own founder Peter Willis, who died in June, the nation’s most emotional awards was even more poignant than usual.Coming against the backdrop of a Britain emerging from a global pandemic, it felt more important than ever to be together celebrating the best of us.At the last event in , Covid did not yet have its name. In , as Carol Vorderman thanked Oxford Vaccine team, it was the first time in  years anyone had seen the Awards co-host reduced to tears.  A room full of famous faces, from ITV ’s Simon Cowell to Hollywood’s Sharon Stone, and even Sausage from the Masked Singer, got to its feet for one of the longest standing ovations the Pride of Britain Awards, in partnership with TSB, has ever seen. After taking place last year as a virtual event, Pride of Britain was only possible in person this year because of the hard work of vaccine scientists and NHS vaccinators – many of us with the Oxford jab fighting our bodies’ daily battle against the virus.Hearing how the team had lived from the University’s vending machines, desperately missing their own families, only added to the sense that these were ordinary people achieving extraordinary things.  The team brushed off achievements which have led to . billion doses of the Oxford Astra-Zeneca vaccine being given across the world. “It’s lucky that mini-Cheddars and Bounty bars are two of your five a day,” Prof Cath Green OBE laughed. Prof Sir Andrew Pollard added: “We’re all pretty ordinary people, just doing our normal jobs in an unusual time”. As Stephen Fry, presenting them with their award said: “It’s only true heroes who think they aren’t heroes.” He added: “I would have walked across broken glass to give you this Award. Never have the three words ‘Pride of Britain’ been more deserving.”  Actress Sharon Stone spoke for many, as she overcame the tragic loss of her baby nephew to give a Prince’s Trust Award to Syrian refugee Hassan Alkhawam. “It’s really lovely to see people again,” she said. “I’ve been crying all night”. Fittingly, for a year when we remembered Peter’s passion in creating and sustaining these awards, this was an incredible group of winners.There was something unmistakably Pride of Britain about Stephen Wharton, a -year-old painter and decorator from Cumbria. In his role as part-time firefighter, he had been called to the River Eden, where teenager Kacper Krauze had sunk to the bottom, his body shocked by the icy water. Stephen is a ‘wading first responder’ but seeing Kacper’s distraught parents he took off his safety equipment so could e down to save his le.“We do get some ops discretion,” he said wryly, but “ing down  feet is pushing the bounds a bit.”  Seven-year-old Harmonie-Rose Allen, a quadruple amputee, was completely unfazed by the bright lights.Listening to her karaoke duet with Ed Sheeran, Simon Cowell told Harmonie-Rose her singing was better than Ed’s, but “don’t tell him”. Harmonie looked puzzled. “He’ll probably see it,” she said, politely. One of the most moving moments of the night came as Rebecca Carless and Jamie McCallum were surprised by the cameras, thinking they were Pride of Britain guests rather than winners. The parents were behind a Carpool Karaoke-style video, #WouldntChangeAThing, celebrating  children with Down’s Syndrome – that went viral. The extraordinary people kept on coming. -year-old Max Woosey, who has spent more than  nights sleeping in a tent gted him by a dying neighbour – through bitter storms and even with Covid – raising £, for his local hospice. Campaigning sisters Amy and Ella Meek, aged  and , who set up a kids charity to help fight plastic pollution. Hughie and Freddie, best friends who have raised more than £, since Hughie was diagnosed with Leukaemia. Some of the money has gone on slushies for young patients enduring chemo. Rob Allen who founded Sands United after he noticed no men were in the support groups for families struggling with baby loss. Rosemary Cox, , who successfully campaigned to set up the first Organ Donor Register in the UK in memory of her son Pete.Former Royal Marine and triple amputee Mark Ormrod who has gone beyond what should be possible to raise over £, for veterans’ charity REORG.  And perhaps most extraordinary of all, Gee Walker, whose son Anthony was murdered in the most of horric of ways, in a racist attack in .For the last  years she has worked tirelessly to promote racial harmony in his name, and her capacity for forgiveness is almost unfathomable. “I will use my pain to make a dference,” she said, of the legacy she has built. “You can’t kill goodness.” On stage, Danny Dyer, in his imitable style, called soap-fan Gee, “Queen of all the Treacles”.  Pride of Britain is also a legacy – for Peter, our friend and colleague, whose inimitable presence shone through the awards. As Lloyd Embley, Group-Editor-in-Chief of the Mirror, told the audience: “This was his baby - and we are going to do everything we can to look after it for him.” When Peter first came up with the idea for Pride of Britain, people thought he was mad.Which celebrities would turn up to see a bloke who’d rescued someone or to recognise the achievements of some scientists   Then Paul McCartney turned up at the first ceremony, just months after losing his we Linda, and the rest is history. The sky was the limit for Peter, who would have certainly wanted Lennon too. years on, Pride of Britain continues to attract Britain’s A-list with its song for unsung heroes. And in , it is a song our country has never needed more. title: primary school asks both boys
story: School asks boys and girls to wear skirts to show clothes have no genderKids at Castleview Primary School, Edinburgh, took part in the the Wear a skirt to school day to show their solidarity after a boy in Spain was expelled from his classes for wearing a skirtPupils at a school in Edinburgh were asked to wear skirts today Image: Getty Images Glowimages RFByJames DelaneyEllie ForbesChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA primary school has asked both boys and girls to wear a skirt to classes in a bid to promote equality and show solidarity with a boy expelled from lessons in Spain. Today, children in the P year group at Castleview Primary School, Edinburgh, took part in the aposWear a skirt to schoolapos day. The initiative follows the campaign aposLa ropa no tiene géneroapos - aposClothes have no gender’ - which was launched in the Spanish city of Bilbao after Mikel Gomez, , was referred to a psychologist for wearing a skirt to class.Castleview students came up with the idea which saw pupils and teachers wear skirts today in support of equality and to help teach tolerance and respect, Edinburgh Live reports.Miss White, a teacher at the primary school, wrote on Twitter : P have been learning about the importance of breaking down gender stereotypes.We have organised a ‘Wear a Skirt to School Day’ to raise awareness of #LaRopaNoTieneGénero campaign. This will be on Thursday th November and we’d love everyone to get involved! She added: We absolutely do not want to force anyone to wear something they’re not happy with but we’re hoping lots of you will be keen to help spread our important message. Trousers under skirts are allowed! The move was praised by some parents but also sparked controversy as some people claimed it has nothing to do with education.  One social media user said: Ah good the school has finally be outed. Castleview shame on you. Itaposs bad enough that this rubbish is being pushed at higher level, but primary  The children in your care need academic education. But one parent hit back saying: My children attend this wonderful school. They are not screwed up. They are confident young learners who are encouraged to be unapologetically themselves and to accept and love others for who they are. Well done Castleview.  Another said: Disgraceful. Just teach the kids their basics and stop all this b****y nonsense. Youaposre screwing up the kids. A spokesperson for the Edinburgh Council said: As Scotlandaposs capital city we are fully committed to promoting equality and ersity, and are keen to increase respect, tolerance and understanding especially in our schools. We want to ensure all our schools are inclusive and Castleview are carrying out a lot of positive work to promote equality across all their year groups. As part of this work their Ps came across the aposClothes Have No Genderapos campaign which started in Spain last year after a pupil was expelled from school for wearing a skirt. They askedthe school could do something similar to the show of support in Spain and raise awareness of what they have been learning in class. The school has had positive feedback from parents however pupils donapost have to take partthey donapost want to. Castleview Primary School has been promoting equality for years, with children learning about Black History Month as well as LGBT+ rights. news uk-news queens-recent-health-issues-not-"Queen wants to ‘get on with things’ despite health says expertByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Nov | commentsThe Queenaposs recent health issues donapost seem too concerning and itaposs a miracle sheaposs only just started using a walking stick, a royal expert has said.The monarch is currently resting after cancelling all working visits until mid-November and has been advised to stick to “light, desk-based duties”.Several of her royal engagements have been cancelled and it was revealed that she wonapost be attending the annual Festival of Remembrance at the Royal Albert Hall on November .The Queen, who has recently used a walking stick for the first time on royal visits, is recovering after she had tests and spent a night in hospital last month. But royal expert Camilla Tominey told True Royalty TVaposs The Royal Beat: She’s ninety-five. I think she’s just perhaps got some mobility issues.We saw this with the introduction of the walking stick. Frankly, it’s a miracle that’s only just been introduced.”Despite being advised to rest, earlier this week the Queen was spotted at the wheel of her car driving around her Windsor estate. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.And today, it was revealed she had left Windsor Castle by helicopter to s pend the weekend at Sandringham, her country home in Norfolk.Doctors cleared her to make the trip and she was understood to be “delighted” to be able to make the journey for her mini-break which had been planned for some time. Her Majesty is understood to be making the trip to make plans ahead of welcoming her family to the country estate for Christmas.The Mirror exclusively revealed on Sunday how the Queen was “totally committed” to hosting the festive holiday s for all her extended family, after being forced to step back from public duties to rest under doctors orders.A royal source said: “The Queen had been hoping she would still be able to spend the weekend at Sandringham and was delighted her doctors gave her the all-clear to travel. “Her Majesty is very much looking forward to hosting her family at her Norfolk home for the Christmas holiday and there is much preparation to be done in time to accommodate everyone who has been invited. “The Queen has many happy memories of being at Sandringham with the family over Christmas and was in the firm belief that she was far better off being there in person to oversee everything as much as possible. “But she travelled on the understanding with her doctors that she continues to rest as advised.”The Royal Beat - available on True Royalty TV.Comment MORE ON The QueenRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: queens special love sandringham family
story: Queens special love for Sandringham - family Christmas and sacred dayThe Queen has left Windsor Castle and travelled by helicopter to Sandringham to spend the weekend - and her Norfolk country retreat is a place of special and sacred memories for Her MajestyA beaming Queen leaves church at Sandringham on Christmas Day Image: Getty ImagesByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThe Queen is spending the weekend at Sandringham after flying up by helicopter, and her Norfolk home has a very special place in her heart.It holds countless happy memories for the Monarch and the entire royal family, but there have also been some sad times there. It is understood doctors cleared the -year-old monarch to make the trip to her beloved estate after she had spent several days resting at Windsor Castle due to tiredness.And the Queen was understood to be “delighted” to be able to make the journey for her mini-break which had been planned for some time. So why is Sandringham such a special place for the Queen to spend time  Here we take a look... Early memories The much-loved Sandringham Estate has been owned by the royal family since  and covers over , acres of land in the Norfolk countryside - meaning there is plenty of glorious open space for the Queen to walk her dogs. She has been visiting and staying at the estate since she was a child - spending many Christmas holidays there.Sadly her father George VI passed away while at Sandringham in February , while the Queen and Prince Philip were away on a royal tour.Even now almost  years on, the Queen extends her Christmas holiday to that date in February order to mark the day there.And the Christmas decorations stay up in the main house until she leaves toto London after Ascension Day.Christmas time Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.Each year, the royal family gather at Sandringham, where they all spend Christmas together, which said to be a highlight in all of their calendars.There they get to spend time decorating the Christmas tree, exchanging gts, attending church and enjoying a traditional Christmas lunch. In , she even gave her Christmas message live from the estate.Unfortunately, Covid restrictions meant the whole family were unable to have their traditional Christmas at Sandringham last year.But the Mirror exclusively revealed on Sunday how the Queen was “totally committed” to hosting the festive holidays for all her extended family again this year.A source said: “Her Majesty is very much looking forward to hosting her family at her Norfolk home for the Christmas holiday and there is much preparation to be done in time to accommodate everyone who has been invited. “The Queen has many happy memories of being at Sandringham with the family over Christmas. Prince Philipaposs legacy Not only is Sandringham a place held in special affection by the Queen - it was also loved by her dear late husband Prince Philip.He took over the management of the estate after she inherited it and it is where his legacy lives on.In a recent documentary about Philipaposs le, Prince William explained : Sandringham has always been a really, really important part of his le.He was tasked with being the warden, managing the estate from . I think for him, being up here, was an escape. He likes the fact that heaposs been able to have an impact here… Heaposs planted over  kilometres of hedge land,  woods, over two million trees. These things really matter to the makeup of the surrounding area. title: royal marine lost both legs
story: Royal Marine lost both legs and an arm - and has not stopped helping other veterans sinceMark Ormrod has always refused to let his le-changing injuries hold him back - and now he has been presented with the ITV Fundraiser of the Year Pride of Britain Award Image: PAByMatt RoperFeatures writer:,  Nov | commentsFormer Royal Marine Mark was just under four months into a tour of duty in Afghanistan when he stepped on a landmine, losing both legs above the knee and his right arm in the explosion. But refusing to let his le-changing injuries defeat him, he threw himself into fundraising to help other injured veterans. Since starting with shaving his beard, Mark, from Plymouth, has taken on progressively harder challenges, including a km swim across Plymouth Sound and a .-mile bike ride, and raised more than £, for charity. Unaware that he was up for an award, Mark, , was joined on stage by two dames – Paralympic athlete Dame Sarah Storey and actress Dame Joan Collins. Speaking afterwards, he said: “I didn’t have a clue. It was a shock and overwhelming but, ultimately, I’m just proud.  “It has been a crazy year and I have an amazing team behind me. This is the cherry on the cake.” And Mark, who was standing in between Dames Sarah and Joan, joked: “And to be presented by two dames, two legends, I feel like the filling in a very beautul sandwich.” An emotional Dame Joan added: “A dame sandwich! You are fantastic, inspiring and spectacular, and I am so impressed. When I saw your video it made me cry. You are so brave, it’s making me cry now.” Dame Sarah said: “It’s just truly inspiring. What Mark has achieved is just remarkable. “Most of us can’t imagine what that will be like and we feel very fortunate for people like Mark who are there for us and are looking after us – he really is the pride of Britain.” Comment MORE ON Royal MarineMark OrmrodSarah StoreyJoan CollinsPride of Britain Awards" data-immediate"data-immediate"Our Pride of Britain newsletter brings you awards news and inspiring stories - dont miss out!Sign me upInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
