title: unaccompanied-asylum-seeking-children-supported-borders
story: THE Borders will play its part in supporting unaccompanied asylum-seeking children after elected officials backed the councilrsquos involvement in a UK-wide scheme.The national transfer scheme for unaccompanied asylum-seeking childrenwas discussed at a recent full Scottish Borders Councilmeeting.In June, the Home Office announced changes to the scheme, encouraging more local authorities to get involved so that responsibility for the children ldquowill be more fairly distributed.And SBC will now comply with the request for ldquourgent national support for this vulnerable group following unanimous approval.:NHS Borders lsquowelcomesrsquo support as extra military personnel set to be drafted inA report put to councillors states: ldquoGiven the current uneven distribution of UASC across the United Kingdom, the Home Office expect to re-balance the distribution over a two-year period.ldquoThe Scottish Borders are expected to take two UASC within each cycle. It is anticipated that there will be two or three cycles within the first year, and thereafter one cycle per year.The majority of young people within the scheme are aged over , are male and originate from a number of countries, including Iraq, Iran, Afghanistan, Sudan, Eritrea and Vietnam, according to the report.A daily amount of pound is payable to councils for each lsquolooked afterrsquo UASC they host, the report adds, equating to pound, per week.UASC are designated as lsquolooked after childrenrsquo up until  years of age and thereafter as lsquocare leaversrsquo, and are eligible for support until they are  years of age.A weekly amount of pound is payable to councils for each UASC care leaver, according to the report.:Galashiels man who pleaded guilty to possession of class A drug is jailedDuring the meeting, Kelso councillor Tom Weatherston, SBCrsquos vice convener, said the number of children the council is taking on is ldquonot large and that ldquosuitable placements for the first cycle are in place..removeThe Conservative member added: ldquoThis is the right thing to do. We can provide a home for these young people who have been forced to leave their countries.East Berwickshire councillor Helen Laing, of the SNP, said she hoped the children would see the Borders as their new home.Back in June, Vicky Ford, who was then a UK Government minister for children and families, said: ldquoUnaccompanied asylum-seeking children can be some of the most vulnerable in our care, having often faced dreadful exploitation from traffickers.ldquoWe know that many areas have played their part to date but itrsquos absolutely right that local authorities around the country step up and share the role of supporting these young people to settle where appropriate and make valuable contributions to their communities.

title: remember-remember-fifth-sixth-november
story: A number or organised fireworks displays are taking place in the Borders over the weekend   November .The Border Union Bonfire Night takes place at the Border Events Centre in Springwood Park Kelso on Friday  November. Gates open from :pm with Food Refreshments and Kids Entertainment.No sparklers will be allowed and all children under  must be accompanied by an adult. The cost to enter is pound. per car and donations to the BUAS are welcomed.Please note organisers say that the display is subject to cancellation.In addition organised displays are also being held at other venues throughout the region.The Peebles display organised by Peebles Round Table and Stobo Castle Health Spa will take place at Victoria Park on Saturday  November. The bonfire will be lit at .pm and the fireworks are scheduled to start at .pm.Suggested donations are pound. per adult and can be made at localgiving.org peeblesfireworksThe Denholm display takes place on the village green. The bonfire will be lit at .pm and the fireworks are scheduled to start at .pm.The Gattonside display will be held on the village green. The bonfire will be lit at .pm.If you know of any other organised event, please add details to the comments section of this article.A spokesperson for the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service said: ldquoIf you are unable to attend an organised display, we would ask you to consider the impact of fireworks on people and animals. It is often children rather than adults who are injured by fireworks.ldquoThe noise and lights that fireworks emit can also be overwhelming for people with a sensory impairment and those with neurological dferences such as autism. Animals can also find fireworks particularly distressing.

title: great-borders-river-clean-help-make-difference
story: THE Great Borders River Clean s to the region this weekend, helping to clear up local rivers and natural spaces.Covering  areas of the Borders, the event invites locals to join together to help remove rubbish from riverbanks and surrounding areas.Organised by Tom Rawson, the founder of GreenTweed Eco, it will begin on Friday and will run until Sunday.:Coronavirus: Outbreak at Borders school sees parents contacted, says councilldquoThis weekend marks a great weekend of environmental action as communities and groups come together in support of the natural world and the global leaders working so hard to reach agreements at COP down the road, said Mr Rawson.ldquoThe Great Borders River Clean is a regional-scale event where iniduals really can make a measurable, positive dference.On Fridayvolunteers in Ancrum will meet at Ancrum Football Club at pm. Then on Saturday, river cleans will be taking place in: Peebles , Melrose , Darnick , Chirnside , Tweedbank , Galashiels , and Coldstream .On Sunday, November , towns taking part in the river clean include: Innerleithen , Traquair , Walkerburn , Earlston , Hawick , Selkirk , and Kelso .Dates and times are yet to be confirmed for Leaderfoot, Stow and West Linton.:Several organised fireworks displays in Borders this weekendMr Rawson added: ldquoWith the support of Tweed Forum and the Fallago Environment Foundation, the Great Borders River Clean has grown into one of the countryrsquos largest river cleans.ldquoThe Spring  Great Borders River Clean saw nearly  volunteers clear over ,kg of rubbish from Borders river systems..removeldquoAll you need to do to join in is to look at the facebook greentweed.eco page to find an event near you, wrap up warm, bring bags and gloves and get stuck in.ldquoYou really will be making a massive and highly visible positive dference.

title: coronavirus-borders-recorded-100-cases-24-hours
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirusin the last day, latest figures show.According to Scottish Government data published at pm today , the Borders has now seen , cases of the virus since the start of the pandemic.There had been a backlog of results being reported from NHS Scotland Pillar  lab tests from the afternoon of November  which also impacted reported cases on November . These missed results were included in todays release.There are  people in the hospital in the Borders with confirmed cases of the virus ndash two fewer than yesterday.Scotland has now recorded , cases of the virus since March last year, according to the latest data.

title: borders-buses-cancels-number-services-due-coronavirus
story: A NUMBER of Borders bus services have been suspended due to coronavirus.Borders Buses says it has been left with ldquono alternative but to cancel some journeys tomorrow .A spokesperson said: ldquoDue to the localised breakout of COVID- in the Scottish Borders and the impact it is having on our team, we are left with no alternative than to suspend several journeys tomorrow.ldquoWe shall do our utmost to keep you [passengers] updated on any further changes. We thank you in advance for your understanding.The following services have been cancelled:X:Galashiels to PeeblesGalashiels to Peebles EdinburghEdinburgh to Peebles GalashielsGalashiels to Peebles EdinburghEdinburgh to Peebles GalashielsX:Hawick to GalashielsHawick to GalashielsHawick to GalashielsHawick to GalashielsGalashiels to HawickGalashiels to HawickGalashiels to HawickGalashiels to HawickGalashiels to HawickH:Hawick townrsquos H has been cancelled from  to . The H will cover parts of the route.See the Borders Buses Facebook page for more information.

title: coronavirus-borders-recycling-centres-close-due-virus
story: TWO recycling centres in the Borders have closed due to a member of staff testing positive for coronavirus.The community recycling centres at Eshiels and Hawick will close for the remainder of today .A Tweet shared by Scottish Borders Council today at .pm reads: "Our community recycling centres at Hawick and Eshiels will be closed for the remainder of today after a member of staff tested positive for COVID-."

title: former-special-adviser-pm-launches-firm-speed-clinical-research
story: A former special adviser to the Prime Minister has publicly launched a firm to speed up clinical research into new health treatments.Michael Young, together with Meri Beckwith, launched Lindus Health with around pound. million in seed funding from technology and healthcare investors such as Firstminute Capital, Presight Capital, Seedcamp and Hambro Perks.The pair aim to cut the costs of bringing new drugs to market through less expensive clinical trials and better technology, and have created a new clinical trial .They say this will result in faster, safer clinical trials that lead to better health outcomes for the public.Current trials run by Lindus include several from the universities of Oxford, Leeds, Brunel and Nottingham.Mr Young said: ldquoDuring my time in government, I heard time and time again that the way clinical trials are conducted is broken.ldquoThis means that patients are missing out on lesaving treatments.ldquoTo fix this requires a totally new business model for clinical trials. So we founded Lindus Health to do just that and to enable the next generation of healthcare companies.Mr Beckwith said: ldquoTraditional clinical research companies are dinosaurs.ldquoTaking part in a Covid vaccine trial was like stepping into a time machine.ldquoThis was one of the best-funded trials in history but research was done on pen and paper and participants had to go into hospital at the height of the pandemic to fill out forms.ldquoWe founded Lindus Health to make it easier for patients to participate in research, and accelerate the development of new treatments..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Former special adviser to PM launches firm to speed up clinical research

title: scotland-v-australia-channel-scotland-rugby-game
story: Scotlandwill play Australia in their second match of the rugbyautumn series this weekend at Murrayfield.Last week the team played against Tonga in front of a home crowd, winning - in an impressive match.Now turning their attention to Australia, the odds look slightly tipped in Scotlands favour, having won the last two matches against the team.With the fansbehind them once again, they will look to repeat last Saturdays triumphant performance as they go against the Aussies for the first time since .As rugby enthusiasts once again fill up the Edinburgh stadium, heres how you can watch at home...Kick-off time for Scotlandv Australia match this weekend The Scotland v Australia match will take place at Murrayfield on Sunday November  at :pm.It is the teams second match in the autumn series, which will take place throughout November.What channel isScotland v Australiaand how to watch live Amazon Prime hasthe broadcast rights for the autumn internationalseries in the UK.You will need a membership to tune in, butyou dont already have one you can sign up to a -day free trial.If you dont want to continue your trial after the -days however, you will need to remember to cancel your subscription.When is Scotlands next match in autumn series Here is Scotlands schedule for the autumn series:Scotland v Australia: Sunday November  at :pmScotland v South Africa: Saturday November  at pmScotland v Japan: Saturday November  at pm

title: limmys-show-watch-three-series-limmys-show
story: Limmys Show, the sketch series by Scottish comedian Limmy is available to watch on iPlayer from today.Throughout the show, which has a cult following, Limmy plays himself and a iety of other characters in observational comedy sketches.The first series was broadcast in , with the second and third coming in  and  respectively, airing on BBC Scotland.A Christmas special in  marked the final episode, with Limmy saying he didnt want to do any more episodes in the aftermath.Now all three series are available to watch - heres how you can tune in....Where to watch all three series ofLimmys ShowYou can watch all three series of Limmys Show on BBC iPlayer.The original musicaccompanies the show, rather that the musicwhich was substituted when the show appeared on Netflix.There are  episodes across the three series, plus the Christmas special which is also available on iPlayer.Revealing the news, Limmy tweeted: "I am happy to announce that all three series of Limmys Show are now on iPlayer! Including the pilot! And with the original music, not that stuff I had to swap to for Netflix!"I am happy to announce that all three series of Limmys Show are now on iPlayer!Including the pilot!And with the original music, not that stuff I had to swap to for Netflix!https:t.co RKfyFSyomdash twitch.tv LimmyNovember , The Scottish comedian has a huge following on Twitter where he often posts videos of sketches using the handle @DaftLimmy.His extensive fan base will likely be pleased at the news of the release, with series one and two previously only available on DVD, while series three did not come out on disc.It was available for a short period on Netflix, before being removed in .

title: northern-lights-aurora-borealis-can-see-northern-lights-tonight
story: The northern lights were spotted across the UK last night, from Scotlandall the way down to Devon.It is known officially as an aurora borealis, whichis the latin translation of northern lights.These lights occur when there is activity on the earths sun.Atoms and mollecules from the earths atmosphere collide with particles from the sun and create colours in the sky.The earths magnetic field is what causes the wavy lines and patterns of the northern lights.They are a fairly rare occurence, but we in Scotland might get another chance to see them tonight.Heres what we know...Can I see the northern lights in Scotland tonight According to AuroraWatch UK, parts of Scotland could see the northern lights again tonight.Yesterday, areas across the UK reported sightings of the aurora borealis.As of pm on Thursday, AuroraWatch UK reported "minor geomagnetic activity" on its Facebook page, meaning there is a possibility of an aurora laterthis activity continues.It advised checking the site again when it was dark for confirmation of whether or not the northern lights could be seen in Scotland tonight.The site is available here.The chance of seeing an aurora is on the left side of the graph, while the time is along the bottom of the graph.A red alert means it is likely an aurora will occur, while an amber alert means a possible aurora.Earlier in the day, the site had reported a red alert meaning that an aurora was likely, however this has decreased as the day has gone on.Meanwhile, Met Office space weather expert Krista Hammond also confirmed there was a chance of spotting the lights again tonight."As was predicted by the Met Office Space Weather Operations Centre, a coronal mass ejection impacted with the Earth yesterday."The resulting strong geomagnetic storm meant the Northern Lights were visible across large areas of the UK overnight last night."Wersquove had reports that the aurora could even be seen in some central areas of the UK, which is possible when a storm of this magnitude impacts the Earth..remove"This means there is the potential for further sightings of the Northern Lights overnight, although there will be spells of patchy cloud over Scotland which could limit visibility in places."What time am I most likely to see an aurora The northern lights are usually most visible between pm and am, however they could be spotted any time during the hours of darkness.

title: leader october 8 2021
story: Well done to Emily Bennie and Ross Conner for their recent musical achievements.Emily has achieved the ARSM diploma, designed to give promising musicians an opportunity to demonstrate performance skills after grade eight, which is considered by many musicians to be the pinnacle of achievement.What makes it even more impressive is the fact she achieved it while also working towards her National , Higher and Advanced Higher exams.And Ross won his silver award after competing again some of the best young pipers in Scotland, with just  competing places up for grabs.Ross well and truly earned his spot, having won numerous competitions and awards over recent years.As well as his musical pursuits, Ross participates in many events in and around Campbeltown to raise funds for charity and has recently become a volunteer crewman on the Campbeltown leboat.Ross and Emily#s successes don#t come easily both have dedicated years of commitment to their talents and are thoroughly deserving of these fantastic accolades. They have bright futures ahead of them.Kintyre has a long and ied musical heritage and it#s people like Ross and Emily who are keeping it alive and no doubt inspiring others to do the same.

title: leader october 15
story: It was encouraging to see a positive and constructive debate, with cross-party MSPs from across the region delivering a similar message.What matters now is what happens next.John Gurr, chairman of the Rest and Be Thankful Campaign group, has invited Transport Minister Graeme Dey and the area#s MSPs to join him in a journey along the route, #on the bus too,#desired.Whatever mode of transport Mr Dey choses to take one thing remains certain. Short and long term solutions need to be found and found quickArgyll and Bute is to continue to grow and thrive.•A massive shout out from the Campeltown Courier to all of the award winners at the inaugural Spirit of Campbeltown Awardsheld in the Town Hall last Saturday night and an equally huge well done to Cheryl Lang who created and organised the event.Finally thank you to all the members of the public who voted for the winners in each category and all those who supported the event. Truly heart warming indeed.

title: letters october 15 2021
story: I am writing this letter due to concern and disgust at the state of Kilkerran Cemetery, Campbeltown, lately.When entering the cemetery, there the workmen#s tractor, vans and trailers are parked, even at the end of the work day, and a mound of earth which has been there for some time and in fact has weeds growing at the back of it.Leaves off the palm trees are strewn all over the road and grass.Regarding the vans, trailers and tractor, they make it dficult to drive your car in the cemetery and do not help with the appearance. Surely they could be stored at the council depot, especially when not getting used.The grass throughout was cut and the loose grass was left lying in thick clumps, asit was a playing field, instead of a cemetery.This cemetery, in years past, won an award but I fail to see the same happening again with things as they are of late.The grass around the stones, at the sides and back, is not being cut, resulting in long grass and often ferns growing there are bollards lying loose which will undoubtedly result in damage to a car there are cones at the main car park, restricting the amount of cars that can park there, and there are also cones at the portable cabins the road in the cemetery is a total disgrace!I in no way blame the men who work in the cemetery as they are doing as they have been told to do, and I know they are taken from the cemetery to work where, resulting in those men not having the time to complete the work which is necessary to keep the cemetery in the condition it should be.I understand about cutbacks and lack of funds but I am wondering where the money goes that people have paid for plots and or council tax, which increase and yet there are even more cutbacks.My biggest concern is where has the respect gone The following is in response to the debate about the state of the A over Rest And Be Thankful in the Scottish Parliament last Wednesday, October .I fear that the current Rest and Be Thankful is a catastrophe waiting to happen and I think that there needs to be an urgency from the Scottish Government to deliver a medium-term and long-term solution for the people and businesses of Argyll.The Cabinet Secretary discussed the necessity to collect data for the end long-term solution and, as much as I appreciate that, it should have been done years ago and I completely understand the frustrations felt by businesses and travellers alike.The Cabinet Secretary also invited all contributing MSPs to walk the forestry road with engineers and I am going to write to him to accept that invitation.

title: thought for the week october 15 2021
story: One morning recently, I heard the following two news items on the radio:First was a report about the petrochemical plant at Grangemouth which emits tons of CO into the atmosphere. There are plans to convert it to a hydrogen plant which would capture the CO, send it along a pipeline to Aberdeenshire ready for it to be stored deep under the sea.That was immediately followed by a report on the shortage of CO caused by the increase in energy costs and the closing down of two fertilizer factories which send CO on to other industries, in particular food.How ironic – one industry wants to bury the stuff that others desperately need!I decided to find out more and discovered that CO in ying grades of purity is used in a wide iety of industries.On further research, I also discovered that CO is already being turned from a pollutant into a resource.Companies around the world, including the UK, are reusing CO to make building blocks, cement, foam housing insulation and fuel.I found two examples of companies feeding CO to algae, one to make carbon fibre and the other to revive oyster reefs.#Now it is required that those who have been given a trust must prove faithful.# We are all responsible for the care of our planet, whether as members of faith groups or members of a global society.Refining CO might cost a fortune but not doing so could cost the earth.

title: from our files october 22 2021
story: Campbeltown fish quay was buzzing last week, with more than  fishing boats in overnight last Monday.There were  Irish fishing boats from Portavogie, Kilkeel and Ardglass, as well as  of the local fleet.They were landing in Campbeltown and it was a busy night for the boys working at the fish market.Harbour master Stephen Scally said it was great seeing Campbeltown busy with fishing vessels and landing good catches again the pier was buzzing with crews and workers.The first heavy rain storm of winter hit Kintyre this week, topping up the rain gauges and flooding fields and roads.Parts of Kilkenzie and Bellochantuy were covered in deep surface water and all fields and burns were swollen with water to bursting point in places.By Tuesday,  days into October, the monthly rainfall had beaten that of September.Harbour master Stephen Scally reports that in the  hours between midday on Monday and Tuesday . inches of rain fell, taking the October total so far to five inches in September there was only . inches for the whole month.At Campbeltown Airport, the anemometer was hitting  knots,  mph, during gusts of wind.And the bad news is this weekend could see more bad weather, with meteorologists watching two low-pressure systems which could be the starting point for another severe storm.TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOSpeculation continues over the future of the Keil Hotel following the announcement last week that an interim liquidator had been appointed for Premier Cuisine.It had initially arisen because it was believed Premier Cuisine was the parent company of Keil Leisure, the firm which is undertaking the refit of the Keil Hotel.Keil Leisure announced in February this year it would be carrying out the £ million refit of the Keil Hotel in Southend with plans to turn it into a four-star hotel and country club.However, when the Courier spoke to Mr Brian Morton, the managing director of Premier Cuisine, this week, he denied any link between the two companies.And he stressed the refurbishment of the Keil Hotel was still going ahead by Keil Leisure and that nothing had changed.The official public notice which had sparked off the worries was published in the Glasgow Herald last week on behalf of HM Commissioners of Customs and Excise.The notice gives details of the proposed winding up of Premier Cuisine and the appointment of an interim liquidator following the presentation of a petition to the sherf at Glasgow and Strathkelvin on September .A Customs and Excise spokesman said the case was most definitely live and that they would be proceeding with it to recoup their money which he described as #a substantial amount#.FIFTY YEARS AGOCampbeltown#s first traffic warden began patrolling the burgh streets on Monday.He is Mr Albert Brown, of Kildonald Cottage, by Peninver. Mr Brown and his we came to live at the cottage about a year ago from Erskine, Renfrewshire.Mr Brown spent last week at Argyll County Police Headquarters in Lochgilphead before commencing his duties in the town.In an interview, Mr Brown said he found Campbeltown drivers very co-operative and he has had no trouble with motorists.He does not think there is a serious traffic problem in Campbeltown and says there is ample parking space in side streets.Because of this, there is no reason why motorists should contravene the no-waiting orders, he said.Mr Brown is also responsible for directing a steady flow of traffic through the burgh at peak times and has been on points duty several times.Should Mr Brown find himself left with no alternative but to #book# a motorist, his report goes to the local police station and is dealt with there. He has the full backing of the police. It is hoped he will have a personal two-way radio soon.Mr Brown feels traffic lights would serve a useful purpose at the Longrow South and Main Street junction.Mr Brown served throughout the last war in the th Marine Commandos, when he was awarded the Military Medal.ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOA further reduction in the price of Drumlemble coal has been made this week. The local fuel is now to be had at s d a ton, or s d a cwt, delivered.The villa Craigowan, which belonged to the late Mr Robert Hogarth, has, we understand, been purchased by the proprietors of Hazelburn Distillery.Herring fishing is almost at a standstill in the local waters. Last week, only  baskets were landed at s a basket. This week so far has been absolutely blank.Another fine addition has been made to the Campbeltown fishing fleet. Mr John Cameron, Bolgam Street, has bought the Girvan boat Alipede I from Mr A M McCrindle. She is a nice boat, fitted with a - Kelvin engine.Mr Peter Dewar, who was president of the Campbeltown and District Football Association for the past two years, has been presented by the association with a smoker#s outfit on the occasion of his leaving for a new appointment in Islay. From his friends in the Liberal Club, Mr Dewar has received a travelling bag as a parting gt.[Editor#s note: Today, smoking is actively discouraged as a health risk but a century ago it was considered acceptable a smoker#s companion or outfit was a matching decorative set of ashtrays, match holders, tobacco, cigar or cigarette boxes and a pipe rack.]The luck of the draw in the Scottish Junior Cup competition has been going strongly in favour of Grammar School Former Pupils. For the third time they have been drawn at home. Their opponents in the third round are Ardeer. The fixture has to be played before November .Argyll Mountain Battery has won the Brigade trophy competed for by the three batteries of the st Highland Mountain Brigade RGAwhile in camp at Buddon. The Ross Battery carried out its practice early in August, while the Argyll and Bute batteries competed during the last fortnight in September. The winning of this trophy reflects the greatest credit on the young gunners who so efficiently manned the battery#s guns during the practice and it will also give pleasure to the old gunners of pre-war days to know the young generation is proving worthy successors.

title: letters october 22 2021
story: It was great to speak to my constituents in Carradale on my latest visit to the village last Saturday.Many residents mentioned the need to cut the grass verges, especially at junctions, for safety reasons. I have contacted Argyll and Bute Council#s roads management about this on numerous occasions and will continue to do so.I have also been in contact with East Kintyre Community Council about the state of signs at passing places in the area. There are roughly  passing places, some with no signs, some with old and badly deteriorated posts and some with new signs.With the increase in use of many East Kintyre roads, it makes sense to have clearly marked passing places.With more and more people working from home, fit-for-purpose broadband speeds and mobile phone coverage is not just a luxury, but an essential tool for day-to-day le. I have been lobbying BT Openreach and local and national governments for more digital investment in our rural ward.I will continue to work day-in and day-out for our area, making sure voices in Kintyre and the islands are heard.As a clinical nurse specialist on Breast Cancer Now#s helpline, I#m acutely aware of the shattering impact of the Covid- pandemic on the emotional wellbeing of people with breast cancer.News of a diagnosis can be a lonely experience and the pandemic has, at times, exacerbated this, denying people the chance to be with loved ones.We#ve seen a sharp rise in calls to our helpline and emails to our Ask Our Nurses service from people struggling emotionally. Many say the loneliness they#ve felt living with breast cancer during the pandemic has been the hardest emotional impact to cope with and that it has negatively impacted their mental health.As many of us look ahead to a #new normal# beyond the pandemic, we must acknowledge the loneliness legacy facing people who#ve lived with breast cancer through the pandemic and commit to addressing it.This Breast Cancer Awareness Month, we want to remind everyone affected by breast cancer that we#re always with you, in every way we can.Thanks to support from players of People#s Postcode Lottery, our online support services are one click away for anyone after a breast cancer diagnosis.Whether you#re a younger woman, adjusting to le after treatment, or living with incurable secondary breast cancer, our tailored support provides a confidential, safe space to connect with others and access specialist information.Find out more about Younger Women Together, Moving Forward, Someone Like Me, and Living With Secondary Breast Cancer at breastcancernow.org online-services

title: west coast motors 100 years of bringing people together part ii
story: A century after Campbeltown-based coach operator West Coast Motors was founded, bus enthusiast Lawrence Macduff, who splits his time between Kilmarnock and Dunoon, has penned a commemorate article delving into the company#s history from  to the present day.The piece, and several photographs also supplied by Lawrence, is being published in the Courier. Look out for the third and final piece in next week#s paper.Wartime needs created additional traffic and pressures for the two main operators, thereafter, once into peacetime, West Coast Motors and its rival were able to modernise their fleets.McConnachie#s stole a march by bringing Kintyre#s first double decker to the town in , buying two more in the late s which older residents may still remember. However, failing general economics resulted in West Coast acquiring this business in . These #deckers never ran for West Coast and it would be more than  years later before such buses entered their fleet.Liveries iniably provide a recognisable identity for any bus operator and West Coast is no exception. The flowering of the company#s one surely came to its climax in the s with the flowing combination of ivory, red and maroon, set off by polished body trim lines and wheel embellishers. Styles continue to evolve but, in the opinion of this writer, no other Scottish operator has chosen a more distinctive colour scheme than West Coast which still uses two of those principal colours, ivory and red, which it bestowed on its buses  years earlier.During the s and s, West Coast#s modern vehicles were typical examples of their time. In the latter period, new bus grants were obtainable under certain conditions resulting in some splendid coaches being purchased.In post war years, the company gradually built on its service network in Kintyre and Mid Argyll. In , it picked up the East Loch – West Loch Tarbert mail ship link from Tarbert-based Dickies then the Tarbert – Kilberry service from McEacherns in , the Lochgilphead Tayvallich service from McLachans in  and, perhaps somewhat prophetically, the Benderloch-based operations of McColls in .Without doubt, the most signicant developments in West Coast#s history occurred in the - period. During the s, William Craig had attempted to introduce a direct Campbeltown to Glasgow service but failed in this ambition then and at later attempts. Finally, in , these hopes were realised when the company became a joint operator, with Scottish Citylink, of the through service between the two locations.The s continued to see signicant developments. Firstly the acquisition, also in , of the buses and Mid Argyll routes operated by Lochgilphead-based Stag Garage. This was followed, a year later, by the purchase of the old MacBrayne garage in Ardrishaig, giving West Coast an excellent base in the area.The early s saw a further involvement in Oban when West Coast secured responsibility for the Oban to Glasgow service and by  it had acquired the former Alexanders depot in Oban enabling it to build further on its already signicant presence in Argyll.Since , the rate of change has quickened further. West Coast secured the Cowal and Bute area contracts and depots in  and when Bowmans, the long-established Mull services operator retired in , West Coast added this to its portfolio. Their Oban base allows vehicle and manpower deployments on Mullneeded. Of the major Argyll islands, only Islay remains independently served by the Mundell concern of Tarbert, whose lorries are also a familiar sight in the county.

title: leader october 22 2021
story: It is dficult to understand the Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party#s decision not to allow Donald Kelly to represent the party at the  local election – especially when it will not provide a reason.Councillor Kelly said he met #a wall of silence# when asking for a proper explanation or justication, and the Courier has had a similar experience, with numerous attempts to gain answers proving unsuccessful.We asked why the decision was made and why Councillor Kelly was not made aware or given notice of itit was in relation to his Argyll First membership and why support from former Scottish Conservative leaders Annabel Goldie and Ruth Davidson appeared not to be taken into consideration.If we do receive answers to our questions, we will share them with our readers but until then we can only speculate.Surely Councillor Kelly and the people of South Kintyre deserve to know.Congratulations to Fraser Cursiter and Katie Webster who got engaged this week after Fraser proposed on the beach in Carradale.We wish the couple, who are soon moving to Australia, the best of luck for the future we hope theyto visit the place that has earned a special place in their hearts.

title: photograph of the week october 22 2021
story: It shows one of a family of otters that lives on Gigha going for a dip in a freshwater pool.Keith looked for a likely spot for otters to visit and set up his Campark T camera in expectation and his efforts were well rewarded.As well as otters, this spot also attracted geese, a heron, a mink, a young buzzard and a iety of small birds.If you have a photograph you would like to share, please email it to editor@campbeltowncourier or send it via the Courier#s Facebook page.

title: thought for the week october 22 2021
story: As we crossed the bridge, we were excited to see the island’s beauty.At first though, we had to take our friend’s word for it, as rain, low cloud and failing light obscured most of it from view. The next day the rain stopped, the clouds lted and the sun broke through.We saw for ourselves that what our friend had said was true. Skye’s scenery is stunning.In John, chapter , verses -, the apostles told Thomas that while he had been away, Jesus had physically appeared to them. Thomas refused to accept as true what they told him, insisting that unless he saw him with his own eyes and touched him with his own hands, he would not believe Jesus was alive.For him, seeing was believing.Later, Jesus once again appeared to the apostles and, this time, Thomas was present. Now Thomas believed. Jesus rebuked him for his unbelief and said: ‘Blessed are those who have not seen yet believe.’We believe lots of things, not because we can see them for ourselves but by accepting the word of those who have.Christians believe in Jesus, not because we have seen him with our own eyes, but because of the reliable word of the apostles who physically saw the risen Jesus with their own eyes.I encourage you to read the Gospels, the accurately written-down eyewitness testimony of the apostles to Jesus so that you might see who he is and as you trust in him alone,

title: cinema prepares of weekend of halloween horrors
story: As part of the national BFI Japan  season, the cinema organised a spooky line-up featuring frightening monster turtles, giant pigs, family anime, whisky tasting, claymation, filmmaking and what is probably the scariest movie of all time.The BFI Japan  entertainment kicked off last Friday, with a screening of Lost in Translation, which was followed by a Japanese whisky-tasting session led by Mark and Kate Watt of Watt Whisky.Tomorrowmorning, children aged between eight and  can get a taste of monster model-making courtesy of Jim Parkyn, lead modelmaker at Aardman Animations, the studio behind Wallace and Gromit and Shaun the Sheep.Jim will help the youngsters create their own monsters, inspired by the likes of Godzilla, the original kaiju – Japanese monster – on film.The children could see their own creations tearing up the Wee Toon as the models will then be used to create a special monster movie which will be screened the following day, on Hallowe#en itself, alongside Gamera: The Giant Monster.Parents are welcome to sit in on the workshop which will last  minutes and will include a chance to ask questions and hear about the master model-maker#s work.The £ workshop ticket includes entry to Gamera: The Giant Monster but spaces are limited and those interested are advised to book as soon as possible.On Saturday afternoon, there will be family anime with Studio Ghibli#s multi-award-winning Spirited Away, considered to be one of the greatest animated films.In the evening, for horror lovers who are brave enough to be scared out of their skins, there#s a rare opportunity to catch the original Ring – Ringu – on the big screen.Ellen Mainwood, Campbeltown Picture House Manager, said: #What more could anyone want of Hallowe#en – giant fire-breathing prehistoric turtle monsters, parents turned into pigs, claymation fun and terrying horror #We#re delighted to be part of the BFI Japan  season, a nationwide celebration of the best of Japanese film.#Tickets for all events, listed below, are on sale now at www.campbeltownpicturehouse

title: from our files october 29 2021
story: Campbeltown#s vital Ring and Ride bus service is safe – for now.It was granted a last-minute reprieve from council budget cuts on Wednesday, two days before it was due to be scrapped.Argyll and Bute Council agreed to continue the Ring and Ride service whilst it takes time to look for an alternative.Councillor Rory Colville, community spokesman for Argyll and Bute Council, said: #We are responding to the concerns of the people who need this service most.#It will continue in its current form for as long as it takes to make an informed decision about changes and we will make people aware of what will be provided in the future.#No timescale was given as to whether this would be before next May#s elections.In last year#s budget, the service was earmarked for the axe at the time, but the council gave assurances alternative arrangements would be put in place.Councillor John Semple said: #I am glad to see that finally some common sense seems to be filtering through – only three weeks ago the administration voted to continue with this cut.#I will continue to look after the interests of the most vulnerable people in this community as the administration#s plans materialise.#Argyll First councillor Donald Kelly was a prime mover in establishing and expanding the service and is totally against the withdrawal.He told the Courier that this is only a stay of execution for this service and assurances are needed that the service will be retained in the long-term.TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOThe MP for Argyll and Bute has pressed for additional facts about the ferry service between Campbeltown and Ballycastle.During last Friday#s Scottish Questions in the House of Commons, Mrs Ray Michie pressed the Secretary of State for Scotland, Mr Michael Forsyth, for more information.She said: #I welcome the announcement, at long last, of the ferry service, although I am disappointed Caledonian MacBrayne was not allowed to run it.#She went on to ask: #For how long does Sea Containers have the contract  Is the Secretary of State expecting the service eventually to run all year, so that we can build up not only a good tourist service, but a good import and export trade #Mr Forsyth responded: #It was important for the new route to be established. It was possible to achieve that with a private sector operator taking the risk, which means that CalMac#s available public capital and running costs can be deployed on maintaining other services and introducing new ones.#It must be the right approach to use the state#s nationalised service and the scarce resources available to it as wisely as possible.#That was what lay behind our thinking.#He went on to say that he would write to Mrs Michie regarding the contract.Mrs Michie commented: #It is important we get the full facts about this service so that we can judge whether this really is value for money as the government claims.#FIFTY YEARS AGOEmergency sea rescue services in the Firth of Clyde could have been victims of another hoax on Friday.For the Campbeltown leboat, three naval vessels and a Dakota aircraft spent nearly six hours searching Kilbrannan Sound and its approaches for a boat reported to have been sinking off Campbeltown.The drama began at lunchtime when the Campbeltown leboat mechanic, Mr Alistair Gilchrist, intercepted a wireless message which read: #Mayday Boy Danny sinking  degrees off Campbeltown.#Kildonan Coastguard Station, Troon Leboat Station and Portpatrick Radio also picked up the call the boat#s name, however, was not mentioned in the message received by the other three stations.Then a full-scale search operation swung into operation. Along with the leboat, the warship HMS Eastbourne, Fishery Protection vessel Vigilant and the US Navy ship Victoria began combing the area between the south of Arran and Kintyre.They were joined later in the search by a Dakota aircraft from Prestwick.An RAF patrol vessel stood by at Campbeltown.Campbeltown leboat reported the discovery of a large piece of timber. It was, however, too heavy to lt aboard and it was not thought to be part of possible wreckage.Then, after six hours, the search was called off. The plane and boats had covered an extensive area of sea.Coastguards using mobile equipment searched along the shores of Arran and Kintyre.Nothing was seen.Police in Campbeltown began investigations into the matter shortly after the leboat put to sea their enquiries are continuing.ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOAuchencorvie United, one of the teams that came into being in the rural area as a result of the formation of sports clubs among agricultural workers, made their first appearance in local competitive football last Saturday afternoon.Drumlemble supplied the opposition and had a comparatively easy victory by four goals to nil.Auchencorvie had several players of some promise but, as a whole, the team was sadly wanting in science and judgement and the lesson of their first experience should impress on them the fact that mere lusty vigour is not sufficient to win on the football field.In the first half, Drumlemble did not press their undoubted superiority unduly, being content with a one-goal lead at the interval. James Munro was the scorer.In the second half they added three more to the total, D Thomson having two and A Kerr one.At the opening concert of the winter session of the Scottish Clans# Association of London Mr Charles Kelly, a well-known Campbeltown vocalist, sang with much success.His pieces were The March of the Cameron Men, The Lea Rigg, I Passed By Your Window and Until.In all these numbers he had a fine reception, especially from Campbeltonians in the audience of whom there seemed to be a goodly number.A correspondent writing with regard to the work of the association says that there are probably a good many Kintyre folk in London who would find it a great pleasure to join the Scottish Clans and take part in society#s many s.The atmosphere is truly Scottish and the gatherings have a homeliness about them which appeals greatly to the newcomer.

title: late late show as pupils cruelly lose out
story: Campbeltown Pupils were left to rue the loss of another late goal last Saturday after an th-minute strike resigned the Kintyre Park side to a narrow defeat away to St Peter#s.Playing at Renfrew FC#s impressive New Western Park, the McFadyens-sponsored Pupils started the match brightly, despite another y injury list which saw several established first-team players ruled out and others unavailable due to work commitments.The Pupils took the lead before the -minute mark when John McCallum, playing at right wing in a --- formation, reacted quickest to Craig Lamont#s long throw-in, which bounced up on the dry synthetic surface, to guide a deft looping header beyond the reach of the St Peter#s keeper.The Kintyre side had efforts from left winger Scott Souden and lone striker Sean Grady go wide of the target – the latter#s promising effort deflected wide of goal – while McCallum was released by Grady and rounded the hosts# keeper only for his cutback to be cleared for a corner, away from the feet of the waiting Souden.At the other end, the Pupils had a new-look combination in defence, with full backs Craig Lamont and Michael McKinlay, and Ross Souden in central defence partnered by -year-old debutant Antonio Akoulli, studying in Scotland and hailing from Thessaloniki, Greece.The four had to be alert to the efforts of St Peter#s wingers Menzies and Lewis on either flank, and did so very well for the opening  minutes until a lapse in concentration saw Scott Lewis – signed from fellow WoSFL side Benburb FC for a transfer fee – ghost along the edge of the box and slot home a fine finish across keeper Alasdair Ferguson with his weaker left foot, into the young keeper’s bottom left-hand corner to make it -.Impressively, the Pupils rebounded from this setback and scored with  minutes played when Liam Renton, playing as an attacking midfielder, latched onto a ball from Scott Souden just inside the hosts# box, and turned his marker sharply before guiding a left-footed shot beyond the keeper#s grasp.All the while, the Pupils# deep-lying midfield pairing – a real contrast of experience levels between skipper Keith Mitchell, and Conner Brown beside him making his club debut – continued to break up play and keep the Feathers Inn-sponsored side moving forward.Despite this, there was a further scare in the visitors# penalty area when St Peter#s hit the bar from a powerful volleyed shot on the stroke of half time, but the Pupils# lead remained intact.Into the second half, though, the Pupils were pegged back in the opening few minutes of proceedings, a clever turn and precise shot beyond the grasp of Ferguson providing a fine equaliser.Admirably from a Pupils point of view, there was no onslaught from the ision#s third-placed team, also boasting a loan signing from Greenock FC, another semi-professional side, in their midfield ranks, and smatterings of semi-pro experience across their starting .However, what followed instead was a gradual build-up of pressure which the Pupils had to work increasingly hard to contain, the home side#s willing forwards continuing to probe for openings in the visitors# defence.The hard-working pair of Matthew Lang and Calum Houston were introduced in attack for the Pupils with  minutes remaining, with fresh legs required as the embattled visitors# energy levels began to wane.But even the dismissal of Lewis for the hosts, hitting out at Renton in reaction to a robust tackle from the latter, which earned the Pupils man a booking, couldn#t deny the Paisley side a late, late winner, a long ball going undefended in the Pupils ranks, and slotted home in the box by a St Peter#s midfielder to give them all three points, and in turn deny the Pupils a probably deserved draw.The Pupils# management team conveyed thanks to the travelling players for their efforts, even in defeat, and will surely take consolation from giving experience to young talent in the side, with four club debuts made in the space of week – after -year-old Andrew Renton#s appearance against Rossvale on cup duty – and within that clutch, a potentially very useful defensive addition.Tomorrow , the Pupils are at home to Glenvale FC, from Paisley, again on league duty, with kick off at pm.For more information, visit @PupilsAFC on Twitter or Campbeltown Football on Facebook.

title: leader october 29 2021
story: More must be done to prevent the continued spate of thefts which have  blighted Kintyre farms in recent years.To be targeted once must be incredibly frightening but some farmers have been targeted again and again, despite following advice to increase security and lock vehicles away.Maybe now that non-farming vehicles have also been stolen – a van in , a car in March  and another car last week – the wider community may realise the seriousness of the situation.The impact of rural crime takes a huge toll on the mental health of those who live in rural areas like Kintyre, many of whom choose to live here because of the low crime rates.It is therefore heartening that everyone the Courier spoke to in relation to the thefts seems genuinely keen to work collaboratively towards a solution.Parents must make sure their opinions are known about Argyll and Bute Council#s proposal to cluster some Argyll and Bute schools.No matter your opinion –you think an amalgamated Kintyre super-school would create a united front oryou think a dedicated headteacher for each school is better – you must make your voice heard.

title: letters october 29 2021
story: We know this winter is likely to be a dficult one for parents due to the risks caused by Respiratory Syncytial Virusinfections.RSV is a common virus that causes cold-like symptoms but can cause critical illnesses such as bronchiolitis in babies born premature or sick.RSV is usually most prevalent in Scotland between October and March each year.Throughout the Covid- pandemic, restrictions in social contact meant that cases of RSV were reduced. Since people began mixing again, there has steadily been an increase in cases ahead of the usual winter seasonal trend, mainly in children aged under five.Bliss will be working to provide information and support about RSV and respiratory infections directly to families of premature and sick babies at neonatal units across Scotland.We are urging all parents to know the warning signs of respiratory conditions and to contact their health care professional when they need to.In the early stages, RSV symptoms are similar to a common cold .Symptoms usually last between one and three weeks. If the lungs are affected, one or more of the following symptoms will develop or get worse:To find out more, please visit bliss.org.uk RSVA new campaign has been launched urging defibrillator owners to register their devices on a national database to help save more lives from cardiac arrests.Leading charities and health organisations are calling for defibrillators to be registered on The Circuit – the national defibrillator network, which connects defibrillators to NHS ambulance services across the UK.When someone calls  to report a cardiac arrest, call handlers are trained to provide the location of the nearest registered defibrillator within m of the call. Studies show that using a defibrillator within three minutes of collapse, along with starting CPR, can greatly increase chances of survival.This swt action can make a real dference, and The Circuit is a vital tool in helping increase bystander action to help someone in cardiac arrest.We would urge everyone to register the defibrillators that they are responsible for, so that they can be easily located and accessed when needed.It#s free to register your defibrillator onto The Circuit, and you only have to do it once. You can also register multiple defibrillatorsyou areto more than one.Visit www.thecircuit.uk for more information.

title: team nets new bags
story: The purchase of the holdalls was possible thanks to a donation to the under s team from Wylie Hume.#Everyone involved at the s would like to say a massive thanks to Wylie for his kind donation,# said David Paterson, team manager.#As many will know, Wylie himself was heavily involved in the local children#s football association in the s and s and wished to show support to our efforts.#Along with a small payment from parents, rucksacks were also purchased with Campbeltown and District Juvenile Football Association#s help – as is the case for all age groups in the association.#Thanks from all involved at the s.#

title: thought for the week october 29 2021
story: Although the autumn marks the end of summer, for many looking ahead, it#s filled with excitement and anticipation as Christmas approaches. The countdown begins!There are many good things in le we look forward to: a sunny day, a bike ride, the weekend, holidays, retirement or a new job.At dferent times we look forward to dferent things, but behind them all is a common search.The French scientist and mathematician Blaise Pascal said: #All people seek happiness. This is without exception##He said that whatever our idea of how to reach it, our desire never takes the smallest step except towards the goal of happiness it is the desire behind every ambition.But from time to time we recognise our search is misleading, happiness doesn#t last, the clouds come, the ride ends, Monday morning always follows#Three time Wimbledon champion Boris Becker said: #I had won Wimbledon twice before, once as the youngest player. I was rich I had all the material possessions I needed.#It#s the old song of movie stars# they have everything, and yet they are so unhappy. I had no inner peace, I was a puppet on a string.#Where, then, is lasting happiness to be found The bible teaches us that every wonderful thing we enjoy is both a gt and sign pointing us to the giver, our creator God who loves us.If we hope to find ultimate happiness in His gts, we expect too much#We were designed through those gts to enjoy the God who gave them and to find true joy in Him.#I have come [said Jesus] that you may have le and have it to the full.#

title: west coast motors 100 years of bringing people together part iii
story: A century after Campbeltown-based coach operator West Coast Motors was founded, bus enthusiast Lawrence Macduff, who splits his time between Kilmarnock and Dunoon, has penned a commemorate article delving into the company#s history from  to the present day.The piece, and several photographs also supplied by Lawrence, is being published in the Courier. Photographs from the early days up to  are from the collections of the late Robert Grieves and from John Sinclair, two indefatigable photographers whose material is of national Scottish importance. This week#s article is the conclusion.West Coast#s business portfolio now extends well beyond Kintyre.In , it bought the Glasgow Citybus concern which operates on the north side of the Clyde.Two years on, it also picked up a city tour business which is now operated under the City Sightseeing franchise in Glasgow.It also operates the inter-rail station shuttle in the city.An interesting ersication in  was what became a fast passenger ferry link from Campbeltown to Ballycastle while a few years further on, Fairline Coaches, based near the company#s Glasgow Citybus depot in Whiteinch, Glasgow, was absorbed into West Coast.The company also won the contract to operate Citylink#s new Glasgow-Edinburgh Airport service and additionally, partnered Fort William-based Shiel Buses on Citylink#s Glasgow-Fort William and Skye services.Perhaps the biggest and most signicant recent extension of West Coast#s business came with the creation of Borders Buses. The company acquired services radiating into the region from Edinburgh as well local route networks taking it as far south as Berwick on Tweed.As a result, the West Coast identity is to be found all over the Borders.Combined vehicle strength is now around , a far cry from fewer than  in the s.I#d like to conclude this abbreviated survey with two final observations. Firstly, I wish to acknowledge and applaud the drive and foresight of the Craig family in building the business from its original heartland in the southernmost area of Argyll.Public transport is full of challenges whether air, sea, rail or road and, as in every field of business le, there are never any guarantees of success.Once any business reaches a successful position, it often requires even more effort to maintain it there, let alone continue to grow it in size and influence.The presence of Covid since  has, of course, created major dficulties for every business virtually across the board.Finally, a word of praise for the staff and especially for those who are engaged on the vital long-distance links, particularly the Campbeltown, Oban and Skye services.These routes are not only amongst the most weather prone in Scotland, they operate almost exclusively over ordinary trunk roads, iniably convoluted in nature and of borderline width for the safe transit of long vehicles.A driver myself, though never on any of these routes, I#m familiar with all these roads and have some perception of the extreme challenges drivers frequently face.To them, and to all the company#s staff and management, I, and I#m sure many readers who are users of the services West Coast Motors provide across Argyll and in other parts of Scotland, offer grateful thanks.

title: campbeltown people urged to apply for voucher
story: When Major George Melville Duncan died in , he bequeathed money to the then Campbeltown Town Council for the #benefit of the poor of the burgh in the form of gts, of fuel, clothing and foodstuffs during the winter months#.When Andrew Greenlees died, he also set up a trust to help.The application process comprises a number of filters to ensure the use of the funds meet the terms of the bequest trust.The first of these filters is that only one application per household can be considered and applications will generally not be considered where the income of the household is above £ per adult resident in the household, per week.Only residents of the Royal Burgh of Campbeltown are eligible to apply. Successful applicants will be issued with a voucher that can be used at selected retailers in Campbeltown.The trustees will evaluate each application and determine awards in relation to each approved form.Application forms are available on Argyll and Bute Council#s website at https:www.argyll-bute.gov.uk gm-duncans-bequest or they can be obtained by contacting Iona Campbell, senior committee assistant, by calling   or emailing iona.campbell@argyll-bute.gov.uk or Shona Barton, committee manager, by calling    or emailing shona.barton@argyll-bute.gov.ukApplication forms can also be collected from the Burnet Building, Keeping it Local CIC, and Kintyre Food Bank.All application forms should be ed by email to iona.campbell@argyll-bute.gov.uk or ed by post to Iona Campbell, Legal and Regulatory Support, Argyll and Bute Council, Kilmory, Lochgilphead, PA RT no later than Monday November .

title: muddy good rugby festival at taynuilt
story: More than  players from Campbeltown, Lochgilphead, Oban, Fort William, Mull and Taynuilt took part with some fantastic rugby on display across all the age groups from the Micro P-Ps to the P s.Conditions were damp under foot given the amount of rain that has been falling lately. The rain on the day did not dampen the enthusiasm of everyone taking revelling in rolling about in the mud.Congratulations to Kintyre who won both the P  and the P  competitions. They had a real desire to compete and were deserved winners.It was also great to see Mull being represented again after missing the last few festivals and they acquitted themselves well in their first games under their new coaches.A big game of girls touch rugby topped off a great day with all the girls taking part to celebrate Women and Girls in Sport week. This was one of the highlights of the day with the youngest player in P all the way through to the P’sA big thank you to everyone at Etive Vikings for their hospitality. The last festival of the season will take place at Lochaber Rugby Club, Fort William on Sunday November .All pics in D photosMain photograph : Isle of Mull players take a well earned rest.

title: caring co op supermarket staff spruce up school garden
story: Over the course of a few days, they weeded the whole garden, painted the tubs and shed and planted lovely plants.They have also provided lots of bird feeders to encourage birds into the garden, bark for the paths through the tree area and gave the school solar lights to brighten up the space.#The children were excited to see their school garden looking so much better when they came back after the holidays,# said a school spokesperson.#We would like to thank them very much for all their help and funding with this. Super effort by the Co-op! Thank you.#

title: clachans halloween trail shows community spirit
story: This year and last, while it hasn#t been possible to hold the usual Hallowe#en party because of Covid- concerns, villagers have lined a route through the village with spooky decorations and carved pumpkins.On Sunday October , villagers and visitors were invited to walk the route from Long Rigg, past Clachan Filling Station to the bus shelter.In addition to a dozen pumpkins donated by Campbeltown#s Tesco supermarket, Lori Silvan, one of the event#s organisers, bought extra which were delivered to families around the village before the event so they could be decorated and placed on the trail.As well as decorating their gardens and homes, villagers created some spooktacular displays including witches around a smoking cauldron and ghosts gathering around a glowing #fire pit#.Among the many other displays was a a fearsome werewolf head, created by a local artist, which sat atop a wall waiting to scare passers-by.Some homes also treated the children who followed the trail to some goodies they handed out or left at their doors.#We did this last year and it was an amazing event,# said Lori. #An amazing time was had by everyone again this year.#Thank you to everyone who helped by decorating their gardens and houses and the adults who joined in by dressing up and creating a great atmosphere. It was great to see some of the new folks joining in. It was a brilliant night.#Lastly, a huge thank you to Tesco in Campbeltown for donating a dozen pumpkins which helped to make the trail even more special.#

title: muddy good rugby festival at taynuilt 2
story: Youngsters from the Kintyre-Campbeltown team joined players from Lochgilphead, Oban, Fort William, Mull and Taynuilt, with some fantastic rugby on display across all the age groups from the micro P-Ps to the P-s.Conditions were damp underfoot, given the amount of rain that has been falling lately.But the rain on the day did not dampen the enthusiasm of everyone revelling in rolling about in the mud.#Congratulations to Kintyre who won both the P  and the P  competitions,# said a spokesperson. #They had a real desire to compete and were deserved winners.#It was also great to see Mull being represented again after missing the last few festivals and they acquitted themselves well in their first games under their new coaches.#A big game of girls# touch rugby topped off a great day with all the girls taking part to celebrate Women and Girls in Sport week.This was one of the highlights of the day with the youngest player in P, all the way through to the Ps.The last festival of the season will take place at Lochaber Rugby Club, Fort William on Sunday November .

title: pupils u15s defeated by top of the league team
story: Campbeltown Pupils shosted top-of-the-league Clyde Community s last Sunday, in their first home game in ision one.The Kintyre side has been working hard on the fundamentals of football and managing to hit the mark.Both teams started the game very strong and it was a great first-half from the local side, with the scoreline level at - when the half-time whistle blew.The travelling Clyde side found their feet very quickly in the second half and held a strong back four which the Campbeltown side could not penetrate.With the visitors# scoring three further goals, the final score was Campbeltown Pupils , Clyde Community .

title: spooky sporting activities
story: Participants of both sports dressed up as they took part in activities last Sunday, on October , All Hallows# Eve itself.Paddleboarders dressed up as witches, a cowgirl, Ghostface and sported spooky head boppers as they enjoyed a ride on Campbeltown Loch.And young golfers donned their glow-in-the-dark gear as they took part in an evening competition at Machrihanish Golf Club before changing into their own frightening costumes for a party in the clubhouse afterwards.

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ldquoThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.ldquoIrsquom walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: humbie-house-owners-lodge-plans-outdoor-swimming-pool
story: Owners of Humbie House Mr and Mrs Baillie want to build the -metre-long pool in the gardens of their Category C-listed home.Plans submitted to East Lothian Council show a pool five metres wide and up to . metres deep, a pool house with changing facilities and a living room.A stone-paved walkway around the pool is also included in the designs.

title: former-day-centre-revert-two-homes
story: The Primrose Day Centre ndash located on Ormistonrsquos Main Street until closing its doors in  and moving to nearby George Street ndash had previously been two separate houses.Now, it looks likely to revert back to residential use after East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department approved SRS Scotland Limitedrsquos plans.A one-bedroom flat and neighbouring two-bedroom flat will be created within the ground-floor building.East Lothian Council had advertised the building for sale, asking for offers over pound,.The planning officerrsquos report noted that there had been five bids for the property, which was eventually sold earlier this summer.The report reads: ldquoThe councilrsquos estates team have confirmed that at the end of the marketing period in , no offers had been received for the premises.ldquoThe property was remarketed in early  with an asking price of offers over pound,.ldquoAt the closing date in June , five offers for the premises were received.ldquoTwo were unreasonable in the offer made was below pound, and of the other offers received all were proposing the conversion of the building into residential use.As the building is being split into two properties, a second entrance will be created at the front of the two-bedroom home.East Lothian Council attached one condition to its approval: the bus stop markings outside the building are to be removed to allow parking.

title: golfers-donate-2-300-dunbar-rnli
story: A total of pound, has been handed over to the RNLI following a charity competition at Winterfield Golf Club.The competition, which was organised by local golfers Walter Moodie and Alan and Carolyn Bennie, has run for a number of years.Moira Porter, secretary of Dunbar RNLI fundraising committee, is a keen golfer at the club and said: ldquoThis fantastic donation comes during a time of limited fundraising opportunities due to the Covid- pandemic.ldquoMyself and all of the volunteers are especially grateful that the golfers were able to offer their support whilst enjoying the fresh air and exercise that the sport offers.ldquoOur thanks also go to all the local sponsors of this event.Gipper Ainslie, full-time mechanic at Dunbar RNLI, took part in the competition, which was won by Walter Moodie.He said: ldquoWinterfield Golf Club has a close connection to the sea, not only being a links course but also with many members past and present also being involved in the fishing community and leboat.ldquoWith the clubhouse standing elevated above the coastline and its stunning views of the Firth of Forth, the Bass Rock and the Isle of May, Winterfield proved an excellent location for the charitable event.

title: university-lecturer-walks-hot-coals-charity
story: Keen rower Mhairi Sumner, , from Portobello, was one of a group of brave supporters and staff from Scottish charity Thistle who took on the firewalk challenge on October .Founded in  to provide support for disabled ex-servicemen ing from World War II, Edinburgh-based Thistle continues to offer a dedicated veteransrsquo support service.Also taking part in the venture were a forces veteran carrying a stretcher with his son, a burlesque dancer, and three personal assistants who support people living with disabilities.They were all given training for the firewalk, which took place at the Thistle Centre for Wellbeing in Craigmillar, Edinburgh.Ever since she was young, Mhairi preferred to be barefoot at any opportunity. Whilst other rowers don neoprene boots and dry socks to keep their toes warm and dry, she prefers to row barefoot. She is programme leader in events management at QMU and a member of Row Porty.Mhairi, who has raised pound so far, said beforehand: ldquoI love a challenge and I will be putting my tootsies to the test by walking on fire for an amazing charity. Thistle is local to me and I want to support the fantastic work they do by raising as much as I can.Gail Begg, Thistle corporate and community partnerships lead, commented: ldquoWersquore thrilled to have the support of our wonderful fundraisers taking part in the firewalk for Thistle.ldquoItrsquos a fantastic challenge and a great event to create some drama and excitement as the nights begin to draw in.ldquoTheir efforts will raise much needed funds for Thistle, ensuring support is available for people living with long-term health conditions so that a health crisis doesnrsquot become a le crisis.To sponsor Mhairi, go to justgiving fundrais ing mhairi-sumnerFind out more about support available at www.this tle.org.uk or by emailing re ferrals@thistle.org.uk

title: harvest-donations-go-foodbank
story: Deacon Gordon Steven led the service, which was opened by Violet King playing music on the church organ.A reading from the Bible ndash the Parable of the Sower ndash was given by Jean Steven.Donations of foodstuffs will be given to the foodbank located at Musselburgh Baptist Church on New Street.

title: bus-offering-covid-flu-vaccinations-touring-county
story: East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnershipis launching its own dedicated vaccination bus from today .Initially, the bus will offer Covid- booster and flu jabs to people over the age of  and also those who clinically extremely vulnerable.The bus will visit dferent communities across the county providing options for people who may struggle to get to larger sites in Haddington or Musselburgh.It is also an opportunity for people to receive a flu jab or Covid- boosterthey did not have the opportunity to attend the appointment they were offered, or for those invited for flu vaccination but it was too early for them to have a Covid- booster.Krista Clubb, ELHSCP primary care vaccination service manager, said: ldquoThe vaccination bus and drop in clinics have proved to be a huge success across the NHS Lothian area and have supported many thousands of patients to conveniently access their Covid- vaccination.ldquoThe ELHSCP vaccination team and East Lothian Council have worked closely on this collaboration and we are delighted to finally have the bus ready to support our service.ldquoThe way that vaccinations are delivered is changing in Scotland and, as part of our primary care improvement plan, all vaccinations will be administered by ELHSCP rather than inidual GP practices.The bus stops off in Ormiston medical practicersquos car park from .am to .pm and from -pm todayand tomorrowbefore heading to Gullanersquos medical practice the following day and Friday.More information about flu vaccine is available at www.eastlothian.gov.uk flujab

title: towns-corn-exchange-opened-one-off-test-run
story: Haddingtonrsquos Corn Exchange has been closed to the public since February  while it has undergone refurbishment works.The building was due to reopen in November of that year but the date has been pushed back, firstly by a need for ldquofurther intrusive survey work and then the coronavirus pandemic.It is unlikely that groups will be back in the building, which is used by the townrsquos community council and ious other clubs and organisations, until next year.However, it was opened for the Most Venerable Order of St John of Jerusalem at the beginning of the month, with the Priory of Scotland of the Order of St John holding the annual Service and Investiture of Postulants and promotions of members at St Maryrsquos Parish Church.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed that the venue had been used by a group on October .She said: ldquoAccess to Haddington Corn Exchange for community groups and events is unlikely to be possible until .ldquoThis is due to a combination of continued dficulties experienced, with staff shortages around the pandemic and Brexit, and our need to prioritise enhanced school cleaning regimes, as well as in the shorter term a number of outstanding snagging issues requiring to be completed in the building.ldquoA long-standing booking was honoured earlier this month, with the event providing a one-off lsquotest runrsquo for the facility.
