However, it is clear that the staffing support required, combined with some outstanding works and safety measures, means that the Corn Exchange is not yet available for regular use.Provost John McMillan, who attended the two events, said that the booking had been made about  months ago on the assumption that the work within the Corn Exchange would be complete.However, the test run had highlighted issues which meant the venue was not yet ready for day-to-day use.The situation at the building was highlighted at the townrsquos community council earlier this month.Fiona McEwan, secretary of the group, had been in touch with East Lothian Council to askthe building could be used during the marking of Armistice Day but was told the venue would likely not be open until the new year.She added: ldquoI have heard through the grapevine of there being a few groups, one in the Corn Exchange last weekend and another scheduled for this weekend, that are getting to use it.Diann Govenlock, from the townrsquos area partnership, was also at the meeting.She confirmed there were still ldquosnagging issues being addressed, as well as problems with the gentsrsquo toilets and heating in the rear hall.The pound, refurbishment includes new roof lights in the main hall, as well as repairs to the roof and timber flooring. A new storage area, new kitchen and additional toilets were also included in the works.

title: new-home-derelict-site-gets-go-ahead
story: The arcade, on Dunbarrsquos Lamer Street, closed its doors about  years ago and was later demolished. Planning permission was given for a two-storey home on the site  months ago.Changes to the style meant a fresh application was needed, which has now been given the go-ahead by East Lothian Council.Dunbar Community Council was supportive of the plans, which, according to the planning officerrsquos report, saw ldquoan opportunity to regenerate the area and bring it back into use in the form of a habitable home.Pippa Swan, community council chairwoman, hoped progress could now be made on the site, which has been used as an unofficial car park in recent years.When the proposals were revealed earlier this summer, she said: ldquoThe site has been derelict for so long. It was a blight on the shorefront.ldquoIt would have been really nice to find a way to bring it into public use but that did not happen.ldquoFrom my point of view, it is far better it is put to good use to make a nice house than left.Plans for the site show two studios alongside two lounges, a kitchen dining area and a third bedroom on the ground floor.Upstairs would feature a master bedroom and terrace, along with a bathroom and dressing room.Documents included with the application note: ldquoThe contemporary design approach to the dwelling house has been retained and developed with little perceptible change and shall provide an outstanding architectural statement to support the historic evolution of Dunbar waterfront.

title: said-todays-covid-update-amid-cop26
story: The health minister provided a statement on Covid in Scotland, as thousands of people descend on Glasgow for the climate conference.In last weeks update, the first minister warned that Covid hospitalisations were rising slightly as the virus became more prevalent in the older population.Experts have warned that Scotland could see a surge in cases following the climate summit due to the huge number of extra people in the country.However, the Scottish government has previously said it is doing everything it can to mitigate the spread of the virus during and after the conference.Heres what we learned from the Covid update today...HumzaYousaf confirmed today that Covid hospitalisations are still on the rise in Scotland. people are in hospital with Covid, with  in intensive care. people were admitted to hospital in the last week.The decline in cases we saw after the summer surge has halted, hovering around , cases per day.This is likely to increase in the coming weeks as the temperature drops and people spend more time inside.According to the health secretary, there are early indications that cases could begin to rise again.As a result, the Scottish government will keep in place the limited measures which remain.Humza Yousaf also added that the government could not rule out reintroducing further measures.The entire healthsystem is under "enormous" pressure according to the health secretary.Pressures are likely to intensy over the coming weeks, particularly with COP demonstrations and bonfire night.Yousaf urged people to think sensibly and with the health service in mind when making decisions, to avoid putting further pressure on the NHS.An additional package of pound million to get AE patients to the right care as quickly as possible has been introduced by the health secretary today.This aims to avoid sending an influx of people to hospital while they are near capacity.The remaining countries on thered list for international travel havebeen removed.This is subject to change, with three weekly reviews taking place in line with the UK government.These changes wereeffective from November .

title: tantallon-golf-club-sell-crates-wine-help-members-use-bar-tabs
story: Tantallon Golf Club in North Berwick includes a bar credit of up to pound in its annual subscription, which is put into membersrsquo personal accounts.Before the coronavirus pandemic, any unused credit would have been written off at the end of the year.A meeting of East Lothian Councils licensing board was told that the clubrsquos council had decided last year to carry the  bar accounts over to  because of Covid lockdowns.But it meantthat a number of full members had built up credit and the club was now keen to give them the chance to spend it before December , when leftover cash would once again be written off.Andy Edwards, from the club, which has played at the townrsquos West Links course since the mid-th century, told the virtual meeting of the board that the club wanted to introduce a wine scheme which would give members the chance to buy it by the crate to use up their balances.He said that the club currently had  full-time members with an additional  country members, who live more than  miles from the clubhouse, and  social or non-playing members.Mr Edwards said: ldquoAs part of our annual subscription for all our members, they are levied with an amount which is attributableto an account on their card for bar purchases and can be spent on food and drink.ldquoFor full members that amounts to pound annually it is an encouragement for people to come to the clubhouse and socialise with the other members.ldquoHowever, last year, , obviously with all of the closures of the clubhouse through Covid lockdowns, our council decided it was unreasonable to write off these balances so brought them forward into .Mr Edwards told the board that this year the clubrsquos council had agreedto revert to writing off unused bar credit and wanted to give members the chance to spend their remaining credit.He said: ldquoWe have found some members have built up a reasonable amount over the two years we would like to give them the opportunity to use those balances up.ldquoWhat the council would like to do is come up with a scheme, for example selling a case or two cases of wine to members which we would order on a case by case basis for collection from the clubhouse, so they can use up their balances before they are written off on December .The club applied for a general off-sales licence for the clubhouse, which was described as a well-run business by the boardrsquos trading standards officer.The licence was unanimously granted.

title: dog-walker-finds-turtle-longniddry-bents
story: The turtle, which countryside rangers believe could be a terrapin, was discovered last Thursday morning at Longniddry Bents.Terrapin turtles are one of several small species of turtle living in fresh or brackish water.A spokesperson for East Lothian Countryside Rangers said: "Turtles can sometimes go off course due to bad weather or currents following jelly fish blooms."This could be a terrapin."They can survive in the wild but wouldnrsquot usually be encountered on a beach as they tend to be found in freshwater."

title: scottish-open-returning-renaissance-club-2022
story: The European Tour and PGA Tour announced todaythat the Genesis Scottish Open would once again be played in the county next year.The  event will take place from July  to , ahead of The th Open Championship, which is being played at St Andrews the following week.Founded in , The Renaissance Club is one of the newest additions to the world-famous Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast.Jerry Sarvadi, The Renaissance Club CEO, was already counting down to the tournament.He said: ldquoThe Renaissance Club is extremely excited to continue its ongoing relationship with the European Tour and delighted to commence a relationship with the PGA Tour by hosting the  Genesis Scottish Open."The first co-sanctioned European Tour and PGA Tour event is truly historic, in the expansion around the world of the professional game of golf.ldquoWe are expecting a world-class field next July, one week prior to the th Open Championship at the Old Course in St Andrews.ldquoThe ongoing venue discussions with the European Tour about hosting future tournaments will allow The Renaissance Club to continue its course improvement projects being incorporated by the clubrsquos architect Tom Doak and player consultant Paacutedraig Harrington.ldquoThese efforts are an integral part of the clubrsquos desire to bring world-class fields to the Genesis Scottish Open for years to come in the future.A play-off has been needed to decide the winner at the event each of the three years it has been played at The Renaissance Club.Bernd Wiesberger defeated Benjamin Hebert in  before Aaron Rai held off fellow Englishman Tommy Fleetwood in , with the event pushed back to October because of the coronavirus pandemic.Min Woo Lee won this yearrsquos event after a play-off with Thomas Detry and Matt Fitzpatrick.Theto The Renaissance Club also marks the fth year in a row that the competition has been held in East Lothian, as Gullane Golf Club welcomed golfers in .Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesman for economic development and tourism, said: ldquoItrsquos looking set to be another wonderful summer of golf in East Lothian in , with this announcement following the news that the AIG Womenrsquos Open will be played at Muirfield."Irsquom delighted that the Genesis Scottish Open is ing to The Renaissance Club."This yearrsquos tournament showcased Renaissance and East Lothian to a global TV audience and having this prestigious event ing for the fourth consecutive year will be a real boost once again for Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast."As we progress out of the pandemic, I would hope it will have even greater economic benefit next year with increased spectator numbers.Keith Pelley, the European Tours chief executive, said: "The Renaissance Club is a magnicent venue for a Rolex Series event, situated in a simply stunning part of the world.ldquoIt has been a terric home for the Genesis Scottish Open since , during which time we have been impressed by the commitment of Jerry Sarvadi and his team in providing a first-class experience for some of the worldrsquos best golfers from the moment they arrive on site."We are therefore delighted to be ing to The Renaissance Club in  ndash when the event is co-sanctioned with the PGA Tour for the first time as part of our Strategic Alliance ndash whilst also continuing discussions about extending our stay beyond that.ldquoWith three Major championships being hosted in Scotland, including the th anniversary of The Open at St Andrews taking place the following week, the focus of the world will be on the country next summer.ldquoAlongside new title sponsor Genesis, Rolex and everyone at The Renaissance Club, we are grateful to VisitScotland for their long-term support and vision for the Genesis Scottish Open."A limited number of launch price tickets will go on sale on Thursday, with those who have pre-registered their interest for the Genesis Scottish Open getting an exclusive window with first access to purchase tickets.Visit ET.GOLF ScotlandNews to pre-register.

title: covid-latest-statistics-get-tested-east-lothian
story: And residents can continue to get tested for the virus at mobile testing units across East Lothian.Between October  and October ,  cases of Covid- were recorded in East Lothian, giving a seven-day positive rate per , people of ..A week earlier, between October  and October ,  cases were recorded, a seven-day positive rate of ..The current coronavirus hotspot in East Lothian is Tranent North, where  cases have been recorded in the last seven days, giving a seven-day positive rate per , people of .. The vast majority of areas of the county have seven-day positive rates per , people between  and .With regards to vaccinations, , residents over the age of  have received a second dose of a coronavirus vaccine, or . per cent, while ,have received their first dose.East Lothian residents with no symptoms can get tested at one of the mobile testing units in the county.These provide PCR tests.Times of operation are am to pm unless otherwise stated:WednesdayMercat Bar and Grill, WhitecraigDunbar Leisure PoolLoch Centre, TranentJohn Muir House, Haddington - closes at pmThursday and FridayPort Seton CentreDunbar Leisure PoolLoch Centre, TranentJohn Muir House, Haddington - closes at pmSaturdayDunbar Leisure PoolLoch Centre, Tranent -closes at pmSundayDunbar Leisure PoolLoch Centre, TranentWhile appointments are not needed they are preferable to save time.Bookings can be made from pm on the day prior to when you get tested online at: get a free test online or by phone:   .When asked why you are booking a test, select: lsquomy local council or health protection team has asked me to get a test, even though I do not have symptomsrsquo.Home test kits are also available to order online.A number of pharmacies have stocks of rapid lateral flow test kits, which are suitable for home testingyou have no symptoms.

title: christmas-craft-fayre-held-vet-practice-raise-funds-therapy-pets
story: Dunedin Vets is hosting a Christmas Craft Fayre next Sunday , am-pm in the car park of its main practice in Tranent.Home-made Christmas decorations, baubles, gt ideas for people and pets, as well as Christmas cakes and bags of food for Santarsquos reindeers will be on offer.A raffle and tombola to raise money for Pets As Therapyndash a charity that helps to enhance the health and wellbeing of people in communities all over the UK through the visit of trusted volunteers and pets to hospitals, hospices, special needs schools and nursing and care homes ndash will also take place.Money raised supports PAT to recruit more volunteers, register them and set them up with an establishment on the charityrsquos waiting list.Margot Hunter, Dunedin Vets clinical director, organised the event with senior receptionist Anna Willox and practice manager Fiona McLaren.Margotrsquos love of crafting started when she was undergoing chemotherapy  years ago following breast cancer.She said: ldquoFiona is a baker and has made loads of delicious Christmas biscuits.ldquoAnna has made all sorts, from gnomes to reindeer food. They have made huge hampers to win in the tombola, one for cats, one dogs and one human.ldquoIrsquove made snowmen sweetie jars, light-up wine bottles and lots of assorted knitted gts. I have always knitted but took it up seriously again when undergoing chemotherapy. Irsquove just carried on making things and, apart from last year, I sell my wares at craft fairs for ious charities.ldquoThe three of us were chatting and decided we could arrange a Christmas fayre at the surgery for Pets as Therapy, as we hadnrsquot raised much throughout the year due to Covid, and the idea took off. We are really looking forward to the event and are working hard to get everything organised. Wersquove managed to get an outdoor music licence and borrowed lots of gazebos so herersquos hoping for good weather.

title: south-african-barbecue-street-food-van-longniddry-bents-gets-go-ahead
story: Edinburgh-based BBQ StreetFood applied for planning permission to bring its mobile rotisserie to Longniddry Bents No  car park after East Lothian Council advertised a potential snack van site there.However, concerns over road safety saw conditions attached to the permission ruling that the snack van, which is described as a .-metre-long trailer, cannot turn right into the car park on arrival each day or when leaving it.Councillors imposed the condition after visiting the car park, which lies on a bendy stretch of the East Lothian coast road, and raising concerns about fast-moving traffic.The move means that when arriving from its current storage site in Portobello, it will automatically turn left however, when leaving, the mobile trailer will have to head half a mile east before being able to turn right up towards Longniddry Railway Station to double back.And the owner of the snack van was also ordered to bring his own bins to the site, which has not had a bin for  years.Concerns about litter at the beach were raised by councillors and Longniddry Community Council chairwoman Helen York during a virtual planning meeting on Tuesday.The meeting was told that bins were not provided at Longniddry Bents because they encouraged littering.Neil Clark,from the councilrsquos countryside rangers service, said the no litter bins strategy had been a ldquohuge success.He said: ldquoLongniddry Bents was a dficult site to manage. At its very worst, we had litter and rats to deal with.ldquoWe have no litter bins and have had none for  years. Not having litter bins has been a huge success story.The new snack van was described by applicant Andre De Villiers as an upmarket rotisserie which would be serving chicken and ribs.He told the committee: ldquoAll our packaging is biodegradable, from knives and forks to packing itself, there is no plastic involved.ldquoThis is not a takeaway van, it is a fully bespoke rotisserie.Applying for planning permission, the company said it planned to operate at the car park from .am to .pm from November to February and then .am to .pm from March to October.Ms York told the committee that there were concerns about litter caused by customers taking food onto the beach from the car park.And she hit out at the council for advertising sites at its coastal car parks without ldquopublic consultation.She said: ldquoAs a community council, we would have liked to have seen a sustainable tourism policy before East Lothian Council started advertising trade stands.ldquoThere is a lot of anger from other community councils about this being slipped in with no discussion.And she warned that advertising boards for snack vans would ldquoclutter the coast road.She said: ldquoWhat about the people who just want to visit beaches and countryside  They do not want the smell of fried food or having discussion with children about buying food when they arrive at the beach. They want a cheap day out.However, ward councillor Lachlan Bruce said that people wanted more to be available when they came to the county.He said: ldquoI have heard from people using the beaches who live locally and further away. They want more to do while there.The committee granted temporary planning permission for the the new street food vendor for one year only to allow its impact to be reviewed in the future.

title: not-happy-all-loss-recycling-wheelie-bins-rural-residents
story: Simon Booth, , of Cairndinnis Cottages, east of Haddington, is upset with the switch away from recycling wheelie bins in rural parts of East Lothian.All of East Lothian will move to weekly recycling collections from next Monday , with recycling to be separated into four streams: paper and card in a blue box cardboard in a separate blue box or a larger cardboard box glass bottles and jars in a green or black box and plastic, cans and cartons in a new weighted bag.The system will retain the blue and green black boxes already used for recycling in most parts of the county ndash however, some rural areas have until now had wheelie bins for recycling.There are approximately , rural households in East Lothian and they make up about . per cent of the total number of households in the county .Security officer Mr Booth said: ldquoWhen the recycling was set up years ago it was deemed that boxes were unsuitable for rural areas due to weather conditions and distance that collection points could be from the address but now theyrsquove changed their minds, so wersquove now got boxes.ldquoIrsquom not at all happy, it is totally unsuitable for what we need. In adverse weather it is more likely a collection could be missed.ldquoIt is very windy where we are so they will get blown all over the place.Wersquove also got quite a distance between the collection point, so instead of wheeling two bins out, we will now have to carry two boxes, loose cardboard, a food carrier and a sack.ldquoThe council has pushed through these changes without public consultation.He feared the changes would ldquoreduce the number of people recycling and would disadvantage older and disabled residents, who would have to carry the boxes to the kerbside.Mr Booth added: ldquoThis in itself is a health and safety issue. The council may offer an assisted collection but many people are too proud to use that.He also said there were increasing hygiene issues in rural areas, adding: ldquoI live on a working farm and often the lane is covered in cow dung. We are going to end up with manure in the boxes or on ourselves when the boxes are moved.ldquoWill the council collect boxes contaminated with cow dung And he claimed: ldquoldquoMany East Lothian residents have for many years complained about these recycling boxes as being totally unsuitable for their needs and, instead of listening to the taxpayers of East Lothian, the council has forced through the changes and made the system more complex. For people to engage, the collection system must be simple to understand.Another rural resident, Helen Robertson, of Quarryford, near Gford, wrote to the Courier to express her dismay at the loss of the recycling wheelie bins .An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoThe new recycling collections will be a weekly service rather than fortnightly, which potentially means each household, whilst being able to recycle more, will present less than they currently do on a fortnightly collection.ldquoThis system is a county-wide system and an assisted service is available for householders who, through disability, age or ill health, are not able to present their containers for collection and have no one living at the household who can assist.The new recycling service in East Lothian had been due to launch in September but was pushed back to November due to problems with the delivery of the new weighted bags.The local authority says that the ldquorefreshed recycling service is designed to help residents recycle more than ever before with all materials collected by a single vehicle into separated compartments.

title: halloween-gallery-musselburgh-burgh-primary-school-celebrates-style
story: Children across the school took part in ious in class activities including potion making, pumpkin carving, Halloween science and crafts, alongside lots of singing and dancing.A Musselburgh Burgh Primary Schoolspokesperson said: "Each class took part in a costume parade where our dinner-lady Linda and our janitor Roddie had the very tricky task of picking their favourite costumes from every class."Everyone had a great day and there was lots of smiles to be seen across the whole school."

title: youths-allegedly-vandalise-house-port-seton-halloween
story: The home, on Castle Terrace, was damaged by a group of youths ndash mostly young boys ndash on Sunday evening.The homeowner said that five of them approached and knocked on the front door but, as no one was home, there was no answer.Upon leaving the property, two of the five boys allegedly picked up stones from the driveway and threw them at a bedroom window at the front of the property, causing two holes in the double-glazed unit.The estimated damage to the windows is pound.The incident, which was caught on CCTV, has been reported to police.

title: knox-academy-pupils-selling-poppies-tesco-part-annual-fundraising-efforts
story: Pupils at Knox Academy have fundraised for Poppyscotland for more than five years but were unable to put collection tins in the townrsquos stores last year due to the pandemic.Sue Cook, headteacher at the Haddington secondary school, was pleased to say fundraising efforts were up and running once again.She said: ldquoAll poppies and tins have now been distributed in the town and pupils will be in Tesco this weekend, November  and .A bake sale with poppy cupcakes and biscuits will also take place in the school.All money raised will be used to provide support for current and former members of the armed forces and their families.

title: pictures-communities-unite-climate-change-vigils-north-berwick-east-linton
story: The North Berwick West Beach event, organised by Sustaining North Berwick, gathered members of the public to share their fears on the climate crisis and their opinions on what governments should do to halt the global rise in temperature.And Paul McLennan MSP said he was delighted by the childrenrsquos knowledge of the subject.He said: ldquoItrsquos great to see so many kids, because it is about their future.ldquoWe need to keep the pressure up on world leaders, on leaders in Scotland and the UK.ldquoThe key thing for me is to think globally and act locally.ldquoWhat we can do in East Lothian is be a real exemplar. We can really change things.Mr McLennan was joined by Dr Eurig Scandrett, lecturer at Queen Margaret University and former head of community action at Friends of the Earth Scotland.Dr Scandrett highlighted that the fact so many countries were now speaking about the problem was progress in itself.He added: ldquoAnd itrsquos not actually all humans that caused climate change.ldquoI didnrsquot make the decision to base our economy on fossil fuels.ldquoThe people who are making these decisions are actually a tiny proportion of the worldrsquos population.ldquoSome of us are fortunate enough to have some choices in our lestyles, and Irsquom sure the people here are doing things like that, using public transport, cycling and so on.ldquoWe have that choice ndash but the vast majority of people in the world donrsquot have that choice ndash whether theyrsquore on low incomes with poorly insulated houses, whether theyrsquore living up against the fence line of the oil refineries.ldquoThose of us who have choice need to use our voices to keep the pressure on.Mr McLennan and Dr Scandrett were joined by ious members of the vigil to share their thoughts, including five-year-old Rory, who said we need to plant more trees and move away from fossil fuels Siri, , who pointed out that ldquo you just use non-renewables all the time, eventually therersquos nothing left and Rab, , who said the pound.bn spent on nuclear weapons in the UK last year could have been used to transition to renewable energy.Lilia, , said: ldquoYou talk a lot about money and recycling and infrastructure.ldquoItrsquos easy to forget that large swathes of the population live in relative poverty.ldquoFunding and services need to be increased to educate everyone and reach everyone.Mr McLennan told the crowd he was impressed by the childrenrsquos level of engagement.He said: ldquoThe childrenrsquos knowledge and passion was incredible.Mr McLennan also joined Climate Action East Lintonon Saturday, at the newly refurbished high street phonebox, which was filled with messages on climate change by members of the local community.A CAEL spokesperson said: ldquoDespite the heavy rain, the atmosphere was really positive, friendly and informative, and many passers-by stopped for a chat and took away information leaflets.ldquoMr McLennan gave a short talk on his hopes for a coalition of East Lothian climate action groups, who all have the same aims and objectives, one of which is to work towards making East Lothian Scotlandrsquos first carbon-neutral region.ldquoHe also outlined the real prospects of job conversion opportunities and energy-saving house building for the area.The event ended with a candlelit vigil in the village square, where a piper played and poems were read.Further vigils will be held in East Linton tomorrowand next Thursday , pm to pm.

title: comedy-film-music-theatre-brunton-next-days
story: Midlothian comedian Eric Davidson brings his style of humour to The Brunton today . A regular at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, his poetry and musical parody has had audiences spellbound with his ldquoclever satirical wordplay.Classic lunchtime theatre is back, offering company, soup and a sandwich, and a short play. Rapturersquos new production of The Dock Brief tells the story of budgie fancier Herbert Fowle, who murdered his we because she laughed too much. The production, written by John Mortimer , stars Scottish theatre legend and award-winning performer John Bett as Morgenhall. It is live on stage this Saturday .A classical lunchtime concert on Tuesday will be performed by Toronto-born musician Tim Beattie, who has won prizes at international guitar competitions in many countries. Now a star student at the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, he brings a programme of romantic music for guitar .The midweek movie next Wednesdayis Respect . Jenner Hudson stars as Queen of Soul Aretha Franklin in this epic biopic from director Liesl Tommy.Audiences, meanwhile, can relive the magic of the s with nine chart-topping acts at lsquoSixties Gold: the Ultimate Line Uprsquo on November , at .pm and .pm.It stars The Tremeloes, Mamas and Papas UK, Hermanrsquos Hermits, The Marmalade, PJ Proby, Dave Berry, Vanity Fare and Gerryrsquos Pacemakers.The Tremeloes have sold in excess of  million records worldwide, with their huge number one hits Silence Is Golden, Suddenly You Love Me, Even The Bad Times Are Good andNumber One.Hermanrsquos Hermits formed in Manchester in , chalked up  hit singles,  hit albums, appeared in three major movies and have sold in excess of  million records.Marmalade were the champions of the Scottish Beat in  PJ Proby was first invited to the UK by The Beatles Dave Berry had chart-topping hit The Crying Game Mamas and Papas UK will be performing songs including Calornia Dreaminrsquo and Gerryrsquos Pacemakers will perform hits including Yoursquoll Never Walk Alone.Tickets and information can be found at thebrunton

title: scotland-v-australia-channel-scotland-rugby-game
story: Last week the team played against Tonga in front of a home crowd, winning - in an impressive match.Now turning their attention to Australia, the odds look slightly tipped in Scotlands favour, having won the last two matches against the team.With the fansbehind them once again, they will look to repeat last Saturdays triumphant performance as they go against the Aussies for the first time since .As rugby enthusiasts once again fill up the Edinburgh stadium, heres how you can watch at home...The Scotland v Australia match will take place at Murrayfield on Sunday November  at :pm.It is the teams second match in the autumn series, which will take place throughout November.Amazon Prime hasthe broadcast rights for the autumn international series in the UK.You will need a membership to tune in, butyou dont already have one you can sign up to a -day free trial.If you dont want to continue your trial after the -days however, you will need to remember to cancel your subscription.Here is Scotlands schedule for the autumn series:Scotland v Australia: Sunday November  at :pmScotland v South Africa: Saturday November  at pmScotland v Japan: Saturday November  at pm

title: limmys-show-watch-three-series-limmys-show
story: Throughout the show, which has a cult following, Limmy plays himself and a iety of other characters in observational comedy sketches.The first series was broadcast in , with the second and third coming in  and  respectively, airing on BBC Scotland.A Christmas special in  marked the final episode, with Limmy saying he didnt want to do any more episodes in the aftermath.Now all three series are available to watch - heres how you can tune in....You can watch all three series of Limmys Show on BBC iPlayer.The original musicaccompanies the show, rather that the music which was substituted when the show appeared on Netflix.There are  episodes across the three series, plus the Christmas special which is also available on iPlayer.Revealing the news, Limmy tweeted: "I am happy to announce that all three series of Limmys Show are now on iPlayer! Including the pilot! And with the original music, not that stuff I had to swap to for Netflix!"I am happy to announce that all three series of Limmys Show are now on iPlayer!Including the pilot!And with the original music, not that stuff I had to swap to for Netflix!https:t.co RKfyFSyoThe Scottish comedian has a huge following on Twitter where he often posts videos of sketches using the handle @DaftLimmy.His extensive fan base will likely be pleased at the news of the release, with series one and two previously only available on DVD, while series three did not come out on disc.It was available for a short period on Netflix, before being removed in .

title: northern-lights-aurora-borealis-can-see-northern-lights-tonight
story: It is known officially as an aurora borealis, whichis the latin translation of northern lights.These lights occur when there is activity on the earths sun.Atoms and mollecules from the earths atmosphere collide with particles from the sun and create colours in the sky.The earths magnetic field is what causes the wavy lines and patterns of the northern lights.They are a fairly rare occurence, but we in Scotland might get another chance to see them tonight.Heres what we know...According to AuroraWatch UK, parts of Scotland could see the northern lights again tonight.Yesterday, areas across the UK reported sightings of the aurora borealis.As of pm on Thursday, AuroraWatch UK reported "minor geomagnetic activity" on its Facebook page, meaning there is a possibility of an aurora laterthis activity continues.It advised checking the site again when it was dark for confirmation of whether or not the northern lights could be seen in Scotland tonight.The site is available here.The chance of seeing an aurora is on the left side of the graph, while the time is along the bottom of the graph.A red alert means it is likely an aurora will occur, while an amber alert means a possible aurora.Earlier in the day, the site had reported a red alert meaning that an aurora was likely, however this has decreased as the day has gone on.Meanwhile, Met Office space weather expert Krista Hammond also confirmed there was a chance of spotting the lights again tonight."As was predicted by the Met Office Space Weather Operations Centre, a coronal mass ejection impacted with the Earth yesterday."The resulting strong geomagnetic storm meant the Northern Lights were visible across large areas of the UK overnight last night."Wersquove had reports that the aurora could even be seen in some central areas of the UK, which is possible when a storm of this magnitude impacts the Earth."This means there is the potential for further sightings of the Northern Lights overnight, although there will be spells of patchy cloud over Scotland which could limit visibility in places."The northern lights are usually most visible between pm and am, however they could be spotted any time during the hours of darkness.

title: runs-scotland-investigation-scotlands-corridors-power-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive access to the people and organisationswith signicant influence over so many aspects of our lives.From the hundreds of secret lobbying meetings to who really runs Scotlands wind farms, whisky and media - the investigation will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just pound for two months here.Hundreds of meetings between Scottish ministers and multinationals, wealthy iniduals and other influentialorganisationswere left off the lobbying register in  due to loopholes in legislation, The Ferret can reveal.Analysis of Scottish Government ministersrsquoengagements in shows that meetings, potentially of key public interest, were not in the register, including those between ministers andcompaniesawarded multi-million poundUK and Scottish contracts to supply the NHS in the run-up to Covid-.Read the full scale of unrecorded discussions here.Professional lobbyists, including former politicians, advisors and a former minister have met with Scottish Government representatives on behalf of clients  times since March , The Ferret can reveal.Scotlandis home to dozens of public relations, think-tanks and consultancy firms, including several formed by or employing people who served in the upper echelons of government.Find out the whos who of professional lobbyists here.Questions have been raised over the power and influence of energycompaniesfollowing analysis by The Ferret revealing how key sectors dominate Scottish lobbying.The Ferretcategorisedorganisationsthat lobbied Scottish Government ministers since the register was introduced in  to increase transparency.Read the full exclusive analysis here.Bigbusinessincluding oil and renewable energy, farming, fishing, finance and whisky dominated Scotland Office ministersrsquo meetings last year, analysis by The Ferret has found.We looked at all external meetings logged in  by Alister Jack, Secretary of State forScotland, UK Government ministers for Scotland David Duguid and Iain Stewart, as well as Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross, who was deputy Secretary of State until he resigned in May that year.Read the full report exclusively here.The number ofcompaniesregistered in tax havens investing in Scotland over the last decade has increased by nearly  per cent.Analysis of Scottish Governmentdataby The Ferret found that in  there were  firms registered in the Cayman Islands, Bermuda and British Virgin Islands operating, compared to  in . Their collective turnover last year amounted to just over poundbn.Read the full exclusive story here.Nearly a third of Scotlandrsquos biggest wind farms have owners with links to offshore tax havens in the Cayman Islands, Luxembourg, Guernsey and Jersey.An investigation by The Ferret has also revealed that  of the largest  wind farms are ultimately ownedoutwithScotland in England, Spain, France, Germany, Norway, China and where.Read the full report here.Nearly  per cent of malt whisky distilleries are ultimately owned bycompaniesoutside Scotland with wealthy people linked to the industry including a French fashion billionaire, an Australian yoghurt tycoon, a Swiss philanthropist and Thailandrsquos richest man.The Ferret can reveal that of the Scots distilleries only a thirdare owned by Scottish firms.Read the full story here.Ten of Scotlands major newspapers are owned by just three men: Rupert Murdoch, Lord Rothermere and Frederick Barclay. They are all billionaires who, personally or through their businesses, have used thelawto avoid paying tax.An analysis by The Ferret reveals that all but one of Scotlands national newspapers, the Sunday Post, are owned in other countries.Read the full storyhereFive privatecompanieswho employ around three quarters of the workforce in Scotlandrsquos arms industry had thousands ofclosed doormeetings with the UK Government between  and .As part of TheFerretrsquosWho Runs Scotlandinvestigation we looked at firmsoperating in Scotlandrsquosdefenceindustry and examined data about them obtained by the Campaign Against Arms Trade .Read the full report here.The chief executives of quangos appointed by Scottish Government ministers were paid over poundm in total last year, leading to ldquoexcessive pay gaps between those at the top and lower paid public sector workers, The Ferret has found.In the course of ourresearchwe looked at the salaries ndash before bonuses or pension tops-up ndash of  leaders of quangos . There are just over  quangos in Scotland, which include Scottish governmentpublic andhealthbodies, executive agencies, non-ministerial offices and commissions.Read the full exclusive story here.Women board members appointed to Scotlandrsquos public bodies get paid half a million pounds less than their male counterparts, despite a drive for gender equality, The Ferret can reveal.Published pay arrangements for board members across  dferent public bodies, where appointments are largely overseen by the Scottish Government, show there are now virtually equal numbers of men and women serving on them.Read the full story here.Influential bankers,retired senior civil servants, well-connected industry insiders, powerful chief executives and former politicians - meet Scotlandrsquos quango class, the people who serve on the boards of Scotlandrsquos public bodies.Some roles are unpaid, and manyworkextra hours intheirdevotion to public service. But analysis by The Ferret of Scottish Government public board positionshas also found a web of influential connections binding many serving in the public sector.Read the full analysis here.So who runs Scotland  Thatrsquos been the central question of The Ferret and The Heraldrsquos week-long investigation.Along the way wersquove examined the corridors of power and looked at who gets the most access to ministers ndash and who doesnrsquot.Find out the top most influential people in Scotland here.Scotlandrsquos biggest private landowner has been attacked as ldquomanipulative and ldquoundemocratic after The Ferret revealed that his company lobbied the Scottish Government to stymie plans for a spaceport in Sutherland.A letter released under freedom of informationlawshows thatWildland Limitedmdash which runs three large estates acrossScotlandfor Danish billionaire,Anders Holch Povlsenmdash warned the former ruraleconomyminister, Fergus Ewing, that its planned investments could be endangered by the spaceport.Read the full story here.Scotlandneeds a radical sht in the way that power and influence are distributed to help address democratic deficits and rebuild trust in the political process, The Ferret has been told.Politicians and campaigners reacting to our week-long investigation ndash Who Runs Scotland ndash claimed it has revealed deep flaws in our transparency legislation and a heavy reliance on big businesses based outwith Scotland, including those with links to tax havens.Read the full final story here.

title: scottish-politics-features-covid-sign-newsletters
story: Weve been expanding our newsletter service here at The Herald, and we want to take you through our new and improved offerings.You can subscribe to our newslettersyoure a registered user or a subscriber by heading to our sign up page and selecting your favourites.Every day, were giving you a rundown of who you can expect in our incredible Voices section.We go through the columnists of the day, giving a sneak peek into their musings - and well also showcase the fantastic illustrations from our in-house artist, Steven Camley, as well.In April, we launched a new evening political newsletter, Unspun, which promises readers an exclusive analysis of the day in Scottish politics - and a look at whats coming next.As Scotland deals with the aftermath of what was one of the most important Scottish elections in history, were bringing you top insight from some of our most popular contributors every weekday at pm.Wersquove enlisted the help of Alison Rowat on Tuesdays, Kevin McKenna on Wednesdays, Iain Macwhirter on Thursdays and Neil Mackay on Fridays.For all the latest coronavirus news in Scotland, including the latest figures and updates, make sure you subscribe to our Covid in Scotland newsletter, reaching inboxes at pm each day.Youll be given the latest figures in Scotland, and have all the latest news and analysis about the pandemic from our health correspondents at your fingertips.At pm, well take you through the stories our readers have been enjoying the most from that day.Well give you a rundown of the headlines and a preview of the pieces that have been getting our readers talking in our catch-up newsletter - perfect for your commute home.In addition to politics, fans of Scotlands arts and cultural scene are set to benefit from our brand new Herald Magazine newsletter, reaching inboxes every Saturday at pm.Written by assistant editor Garry Scott and senior features writer Susan Swarbrick, youll get the latest from our weekly Saturday magazine straight to your inbox, and our top picks from the pages.So sit back, relax, and get the latest straight to your inbox everyday by signing up here

title: green-scotland-can-read-investigation
story: From big-name polluters to Scotlandrsquos most deteriorating rivers and lochs, The Heraldrsquos exclusive, week-long investigation kicks off on Tuesday, October , to answer some of the crucial questions in the ongoing climate crisis.Hot off the back of the successfullsquoWho Runs Scotland rsquo series in July, no stone will be left unturned in The Herald and The Ferretrsquos joint bid to uncover wrongdoing, stimulate debate, and generate discussion.This special series will run in print and online all of this week, exclusively to our subscribers.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today.

This will entitle you to unlimited access to The Heralds digital  for two weeks.After that, itll be just pound. a month to continue this fantastic access after the conference.What will this free trial entitle you to during COP  We have a whole host of content for you over the next few weeks.Each day during COP, well be bringing you the latest in breaking news both inside and outside the conference. Well have reporters inside the SEC, and others on the streets of Glasgow ready to bring you the most up to date news from all across the city.Each day, well have experts from across the environmental sphere in our Voices Live section, promising analysis and opinion on the biggest issues of the day.And as a subscriber, you have access to our wide iety of newsletters - including our dedicated COP daily briefing. As the conference gets underway, our reporters will give registered users and subscribers a digest of whats to come throughout the day, and the biggest updates from the ground.A subscription will give you access to our unrivalled COP coverage as well as a number of unmissable perks.With that subscription, yoursquoll see % fewer adverts on our websiteand have unlimited access to all our stories, including premium articles.This means you will be able to readThe Heralds online coverage from our award-winning team uninterrupted.Itrsquos our job to make sure The Herald is your go-to site to keep you up-to-date.But as a Herald subscriber, you will also have access to exclusive "Premium" articles. title: letters-no-fan-royal-family-can-admire-remarkable-queen
story: In a broadcast message during the pandemic, she referred to the importance of staying in touch with families and friends and paid tribute to front-line workers. More recently, at the opening of the Scottish Parliament, she spoke of her deep and abiding affection for Scotland, and of the many happy memories she shared with Prince Philip of the times spent here.She has had a demanding time over the last year or so as a we, with the loss of Prince Philip a mother, with the court problems of Prince Andrew and a grandmother, with the independent le sought by Prince Harry. However, in the face of all that and in spite of current health issues, she still rose to the occasion.Ian W Thomson, Lenzie.WHY ARE FIREWORKS STILL BEING SOLD PEOPLE are more and more concerned about the environment. So why are we having fireworks displays and allowing fireworks to be sold Fireworks cause air pollution, noise pollution and littering. They frighten domestic and wild animals. Their explosions cause flashbacks with servicemen who suffer from post-traumatic disorders.Fireworks place an unnecessary burden on the emergency services. On November  the fire brigade responds to hundreds of bonfire incidents across Scotland. In some cases officers are attacked by the perpetrators.Edinburgh "prides itself" in being able to compete with the waste of London and Sydney in propelling tons of explosives into the night sky at Hogmanay. But this year London and Sydney have cancelled their events. Meanwhile Edinburgh is going ahead. Why  Whatever happened to our leaders "world-leading" commitment to going green Fireworks should be banned. A small but important step has been taken towards that end by Sainsburys and the Co-op, who no longer stock these wasteful and harmful products.William Loneskie, Lauder.LIFESAVER FROM THE LIBRARYRE George Dales letter , I would refer him to the BorrowBox app. This is a facility run by libraries, at least in North Lanarkshire, where on presentation of your library card details you are given access to a large selection of digital reading and audio materials. You can borrow up to six items at a time and have tothem within four weeks.This was a lesaver to my we during lockdown when physical access to our local library was not possible. As she consumes books at an enormous rate this made living with her almost tolerable. Best of all, it is free to use.Harry Shaw, Airdrie.GREEK TALE WAS A TRAGEDYI HAD a trip down memory lane with your ldquoRemember when image of ldquoGreek Thomsonrsquos Queenrsquos Park Terrace .Councillor Iain Dyerrsquos lament at its loss was felt equally by the Old Glasgow Club we too had objected to demolition proposals, by letter, duly sent to The Herald. The eventual cloud of dust and flying debris of November rsquos demolition squad has, of course, been replaced by the new M fly-over at this point. A masterpiece lost, yes but, hopefully,-plus years later, we live in more enlightened times.Brian D Henderson, Past-President, Old Glasgow Club.LETS GET METAPHYSICALNEIL Mackaymentions the new obsession "which will allow each of us to live imagined lives in a truly non-existent world".A few years ago I came across something called "metaphysics" and was quite relieved when I was informed that I was to think of it as "subject, object and the nature of reality" and to simply matters to think of it as "a kitchen table when you are not there".Sounds to me rather like the present state of mind of much of the so-called "thinking world". I have to add, in my Lancashire voice, that it is nowt to do wi me I dont own a kitchen table anyway.Thelma Edwards, Kelso.BATHROOM SUITE SURRENDERTHE demise of the avocado , judged over-rated by my proletarian taste buds, and never a berry, comes as no surprise. Interior designers pulled the plug on them years ago.R Russell Smith, Largs.WHAS LIKE US I WAS amused by your report of President Biden being surprised by ldquoa large, naked Scottish man as he drove through the countryside .I wonder what identied him as Scottish Forbes Dunlop, Glasgow.

title: john-lewis-2021-christmas-advert-revealed-full-unexpected-guest
story: The highly-anticipated ad is ato form for the retailer as it attempts to tap in to customer enthusiasm for a traditional Christmas season after last yearrsquos muted celebrations amid pre-vaccination Covid.Titled ldquoUnexpected Guest, the two-minute ad stars space traveller Skye crash-landing at the height of festivities in the woods near the home of -year-old Nathan, who introduces her to the traditions of eating mince pies, decorating the tree and, to her slight confusion, wearing novelty jumpers.The soundtrack is provided by -year-old London singer and songwriter Lola Young, who performs a cover of Together In Electric Dreams, originally released by Philip Oakey and Giorgio Moroder in .The release of the ad is around a fortnight earlier than usual and comes as the retailer revealed Christmas-related searches on its website are up % on this time last year.The ad was created with agency adameveDDB, with John Lewis refusing to reveal a budget but saying it was in line with previous yearsrsquo spending.Shoppers can buy a version of the Christmas jumper that Nathan gives Skye ndash minus the added lights in the adrsquos version, in a nod to environmental sustainability ndash for between pound and pound depending on size, with % of the profits going to the charities FareShare and Home-Start UK.Every product in the ad is from John Lewis, with customers able to ldquoshop key scenes, including the decorated Christmas tree and dinner table.The ad first airs at .pm on Thursday on ITV during The Pride of Britain Awards after launching at .am for members of the lsquoMy John Lewisrsquo loyalty scheme via email access and from am on the retailerrsquos website and social media channels.John Lewis customer director Claire Pointon said: ldquoThere is nothing more magical than discovering the joy of Christmas for the first time and enjoying your favourite festive moments with loved ones.ldquoAfter the last  months, we wanted our advert to really celebrate this as we look forward to a brighter future.ldquoWe know our customers are excited for this festive season more than ever, as they reconnect with family and friends. Through the story of Skye and Nathan we celebrate friendship and are reminded of the joy of experiencing Christmas for the first time.The campaign comes after the retailer ldquodeviated slightly last year from the style of previous adverts due to the backdrop of Covid- with nine dferent vignettes showing acts of kindness.It also follows, just last month, the retailer being forced to pull a home insurance ad featuring a boy wilfully destroying his home after the Financial Conduct Authority found it could potentially confuse customers about the extent of the cover provided.The partnership, which operates the John Lewis department store chain and Waitrose supermarket arm, unveiled a pound million pre-tax loss for the half-year to July , representing a signicant improvement from the pound million loss it posted for the same period last year.

title: john-lewis-2021-christmas-advert-star-lola-young----musical-star
story: The -year-old singer-songwriter, from south London, joins previous music superstars including Ellie Goulding, Lily Allen and Tom Odell in contributing to the retailerrsquos annual festive campaign.Her cover of Together In Electric Dreams, originally released by Philip Oakey and Giorgio Moroder in , accompanies Unexpected Guest ndash a two-minute tale of a young alien experiencing their first Christmas on Earth, complete with mince pies and novelty jumpers.Young started writing songs aged  and by  had competed in and won a national open mic competition, and cites Joni Mitchell and Prince as early influences.Lola Young: John Lewis  Christmas advert revealed in full as the Unexpected GuestShe enrolled at the arts-focused Brit School in Croydon, south London, which counts Adele, Amy Winehouse, Raye and Loyle Carner among its alumni.After gigging around London, she secured a record deal with Island Records, owned by Universal Music Group and the home to Ariana Grande, Jessie J and Nicki Minaj.Her catalogue so far includes the single Woman, her debut seven-track release titled Intro and the Renaissance EP.Young has received support from radio DJs and taste-makers such as Annie Mac, Clara Amfo, Benji B, Gilles Peterson, Jo Wiley, MistaJam and DJ Target and featured in a number of glossy magazines and news publications.Keep an eye on the skies, an #UnexpectedGuest is landing at am # pic KPYszqJySince mid- she has been in the studio writing with superproducer Paul Epworth, who has worked with artists include Adele, Florence + the Machine and Rihanna, ahead of the release of a new collection of tracks scheduled for this year.She has a run of live dates scheduled for November and December, taking her from Dublin, London, Liverpool and Manchester to Amsterdam and Berlin.Last year Celeste became the first musician chosen to write and record an original song for the John Lewis Christmas advert.In a step away from tradition, the retail giant commissioned the singer to produce a new track, titled A Little Love.

title: john-lewis-christmas-adverts-full-excitable-dragon-sir-elton-john
story: Here is a rundown of the ads and their soundtracks since the first one screened in .ndash : ShadowsThe ad shows a group of people stacking a pile of gts including a desktop lamp, a computer and a leather satchel in an empty room. The finished product ends up creating a shadow that looks like a woman walking her dog through the snow, accompanied by the tagline: ldquoWhoever yoursquore looking for this Christmas.ndash : From Me To YouCulminating in the tagline: ldquoIf you know the person, yoursquoll find the present, it shows a succession of characters followed by a matching gt.The soundtrack is a cover of The Beatlesrsquo From Me To You recorded for the campaign, with vocals by Matt Spinner, a member of the John Lewis IT department, and its music society.ndash : Sweet Child Orsquo MineThis was the first of the storersquos Christmas campaigns created by advertising agency Adam  Eve, now adameveDDB, and the first to feature a musical cover by a current artist, on this occasion a Taken By Trees version of Sweet Child Orsquo Mine by Guns Nrsquo Roses.The ad shows children opening gts for adults including a laptop, coffee machine and handbag, followed by the tagline: ldquoRemember how Christmas used to feel  Give someone that feeling.ndash : A Tribute To GiversEllie Gouldingrsquos cover of Sir Elton Johnrsquos Your Song was the soundtrack to this ad, which showed parents sneaking a rocking horse upstairs while their children watched television, a man struggling to wrap a pair of candlesticks, a mechanic attempting to wrap a teapot at work and a young boy hanging a stocking on his dogrsquos kennel.ndash : The Long WaitSet to Slow Moving Milliersquos cover of Please, Please, Please Let Me Get What I Want by The Smiths, the ad shows a young boy impatiently counting down to Christmas, only to show that his real motivation was to give presents to his parents.ndash : The JourneyA snowman traverses mountains and motorways to get to a shop to buy his snow girlfriend a scarf to keep her warm.The soundtrack is Gabrielle Aplinrsquos cover of The Power Of Love by Frankie Goes To Hollywood, and the tagline is: ldquoGive a little more love this Christmas.ndash : The Bear And The HareLily Allenrsquos cover of Keanersquos Somewhere Only We Know accompanies an animated tale that opens with the line: ldquoThere was once an animal who had never seen Christmas. It goes on to show the friendship between a bear and a hare until the bear departs to hibernate when snow starts to fall. The hare thinks of the perfect Christmas present for the bear, an alarm clock to allow him to wake up and experience Christmas.ndash : Monty The PenguinMonty, who hopes for love at Christmas time, is the imaginary character created by a boy whose favourite toy is a stuffed penguin. A female penguin toy happily arrives under the tree for Monty on Christmas Day.The ad features a Tom Odell cover of John Lennonrsquos Real Love.ndash : Man On The MoonThe biggest tearjerker of them all shows a young girl who spots a lonely old man on the moon and decides to send him a telescope to give him a connection to Earth. The partnership with Age UK had the tagline: ldquoShow someone theyrsquore loved this Christmas.Norwegian artist Aurora provided the soundtrack with a cover of Half The World Away by Oasis.ndash : Buster The BoxerThe story of Buster, who makes a break for the new Christmas trampoline after having to suffer watching foxes, a badger, squirrels and a hedgehog trying it out first, was accompanied by a cover of Randy Crawfordrsquos One Day Irsquoll Fly Away by electronic trio Vaults.ndash : Moz The MonsterA friendship develops between seven-year-old Joe and his imaginary monster under the bed, Moz, based on a mutual love of late-night Scalextric and piggyback games. Moz eventually realises that their late nights must end when he sees the toll they are taking on Joe. Joe wakes on Christmas morning to find a clumsily wrapped present of a night light under the tree.The ad was set to a cover of Beatles song Golden Slumbers by Manchester band Elbow.ndash : The Boy And The PianoThe Christmas campaign took its first celebrity turn by making Sir Elton John the star of this ad, with his performance of Your Song the soundtrack to a festive-tinged retrospective of his le and career.The ad opens with the superstar tapping out the opening notes to Your Song, his first major hit, and ends with the four-year-old Elton running down the stairs on Christmas morning and unwrapping his grandmotherrsquos gt of her piano.ndash : Excitable EdgarAn exuberant young dragon called Edgar almost derails festivities in a medieval village with his fire-breathing excitement, accidentally melting the ice rink, reducing a snowman to a puddle and setting fire to a Christmas tree as his anxious friend Ava looks on.The advert, the first in partnership with Waitrose, was set to a recording of REO Speedwagonrsquos Canrsquot Fight This Feeling by Dan Smith from the band Bastille and was filmed over two weeks in Budapest with a live extras cast of around  people.ndash : Give A Little LoveThis campaign focused on acts of kindness during the coronavirus pandemic.The stripped-back advert was a departure from the blockbuster clips of previous years and consisted of a series of short stories, all depicting random acts of kindness and released to mark National Kindness Day.The ad featured a new song written and performed by singer Celeste.

title: discover-seven-quirky-independent-bookshops-scotland
story: Our independent bookshops havenrsquot had an easy time of it after having to close for months and need our support now more than ever. With so many quirky independent bookstores in Scotland, each one offers something original when browsing for your next page-turner. Whether yoursquore on the hunt for a second-hand classic, rare edition, or a new release, these independent Scottish bookshops have got you covered.THE PORTOBELLO BOOKSHOP, EDINBURGHPortobello High Street, EH DALocated in the seaside community of Portobello, this independent bookshop has been curated to exude a warm, modern open space making it easy to find your next literary match. The Portobello Bookshop opened in July .Owner Jack Clark says: ldquoWhilst our first couple of years were extremely dferent from what wersquod anticipated, wersquore glad to have made it through a global pandemic and are looking forward to many more years of bookselling.The indie bookshop is known to host many interesting events and stocks a healthy supply of fiction and non-fiction in spacious and well-lit surroundings. Notable features in the store include decorative columns, foliage, and colourful window displays.am to pm,  days@portybooksLEAKEYrsquoS BOOKSHOP, INVERNESSChurch St, IV EYThe perfect place to while away the hours on a dreich day, Leakeyrsquos Bookshop in Inverness town centre is a firm favourite with visiting bibliophiles.The former Gaelic churchwas converted in the mid-s to become one of Scotlandrsquos most impressive bookstores. Once inside the grand building, visitors can discover a wealth of second-hand books, prints, maps and even heat up beside the storersquos wood-burning stove.A spiral staircase connects the two floors in Leakeyrsquos, and with plenty of comfy chairs to sink into, you may find yourself becoming like part of the furniture while getting lost in new literary adventures.Monday-Saturday, am-:pm@LeakeysBookshopARMCHAIR BOOKS, EDINBURGHWest Port, EH LEOverlooking Edinburghrsquos Grassmarket and in view of the castle is Armchair Books. Inside you will find a plethora of floor to ceiling passageways packed with books with plenty of stylish hanging lights and oriental rugs lining walkways.Armchair Books is full of character and matches Edinburghrsquos historic surroundings to great effect. Jaclyn Kaye, who owns the store alongside Andrew Govan-Prini, jests: ldquoFamily-run for over  years, our current incarnation has manested as a bunch of recovering academics, job-stealing immigrants, and nersquoer-do-well youths raging against the dying of long-term affordable housing hellip we also sell books: all used, many quite interesting.Armchair Books has been lucky to have so much community support, especially during the pandemic.: - :pm, SunndashThurs am - .pm, Fri Satwww.armchairbooksTHE BOOKSHOP, WIGTOWNNorth Main St, DG HLLocated in Scotlandrsquos National Book Town, this Wigtown-based shop is Scotlandrsquos largest second-hand bookshop and claims to be the oldest in the town.Established over  years ago, The Bookshop stocks a ied and extensive collection of second-hand books that cover nearly a mile of shelving. Filled with around , books, make sure you give yourself some time to browse and get lost in the shoprsquos many nooks and crannies.The storersquos relaxing and quirky atmosphere appeals to many visitors, giving the place an almost museum feel. Shaun Bythell, owner of The Bookshop, has maintained the charm of the period building, while creating a homely welcoming feel to the bookstore. Visitors are also warned to watch out for The Captain ndash the shoprsquos resident cat.am ndash pm, Monday ndash Saturdaywww.the-bookshopVOLTAIRE  ROUSSEAU BOOKSHOP, GLASGOWOtago Lane, G PPNestled discreetly in Glasgowrsquos West End, down the trendy bohemian Otago Lane, you will find this emporium of second-hand and antiquarian books on a wide range of subjects. With thousands of books, including rare tomes, manuscripts, maps, records, and hundreds of curiosities from the countryrsquos past, Voltaire  Rousseau Bookshop is an Aladdinrsquos cave for any self-confessed bookworm.Customers are invited to peruse the aisles, sink into a chair, and enjoy an afternoon book hunt in the cosy confines of the store.With aisles stacked with books you may have to rummage around, butyoursquore looking for inspiration then itrsquos the ideal store. Voltaire  Rousseau Bookshop also has help from the friendly shop cat.am ndash pm, Mon ndash Satwww.voltaireandrousseaubooksTHE BIRNAM READER, BIRNAMStation Rd, Birnam, Dunkeld PH DSWhile Dunkeld continues to boom with tourists, neighbouring village Birnam has many charms of its own. A main attraction in the village is independent bookstore The Birnam Reader. Frazer Williams runs the small but well-stocked store and cafeacute.Frazer is also an event organiser for the increasingly popular Birnam Book Festival.am - pm, Friday ndash Monday@thebirnamreaderTHE WATERMILL, ABERFELDYMill Street, PH BGThis Perthshire bookshop, cafeacute and gallery remains an integral part of the community. ldquoThe building dates back to  and was a working oatmeal mill for a while before being lovingly restored into a mill museum, says Kevin Ramage who, along with his we Jayne, transformed the A-listed building into The Watermill.In - The Watermill was voted UK Independent Bookshop of the Year and was included in the New Yorker collection lsquoFootnotes to the  Greatest Bookshops in the Worldrsquo in .Kevin admits: ldquoI think one of the things people most admire about the place is that there is plenty of space for books to breathe and room to allow the books to be presented properly.am-pm, Mon-Sat am-pm Sundaywww.aberfeldywatermill

title: green-scotland-cop26-climate-investigation-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive accessas we look to answer the pressing questions in Scotlands climate crisis fight.As the COP conference looms on the horizon, we will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate on this crucial topic.Find out more about our exclusive pound for two months offer here.From the hundreds of sites and big-name companies that broke environmental rules, to the most polluted streets in Scotland, readers can expectground-breaking exclusives, in-depth analysis, and interactive content ndash as well as regular live videos, giving you the chance to speak directly with the award-winning reporters behind the stories.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just pound for two monthshere.More than  industrial sites across Scotland have been officially damned as ldquounsatisfactory on pollution, according to data from the ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyseen by The Ferret.Sepa assessed the environmental performance of two big oilcompanies, ExxonMobil and Ineos, as ldquovery poor in . A Grangemouth chemical plant and a Coupar Angus chicken processor were rated as ldquopoor.Read the full exclusive report here.More than one in ten of Scotlandrsquos fish farms have been rated as ldquounsatisfactory" by the Scottish Governmentrsquos environmental watchdog because of pollution, pesticide and reporting breaches, wecan today reveal.The ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyhas assessed over  of some  salmon farms around the coast as either ldquovery poor, ldquopoor or ldquoat risk because they broke, or threatened to break, environmental rules in .The exclusive revelations can be read here in full.WE can today reveal the top sitesacrossScotland that have been officiallydeemed "unsatisfactory" on pollution by Scotlands environmental watchdog.The ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencydamnedthe performance of more than  sitesincluding Trump Turnberry, Ineos, and Faslane nuclear base.View the full interactive map of sites here.More than , of Scotlands wildle species and natural habitats are in a "poor" condition, and dozens of the nationrsquos protected sites have been damaged byclimate change, we can reveal.Ahead of the COP conference in Glasgow, our joint investigation with The Ferret reveals that  habitats and  species inScotlandare in poor condition. We also found that climate change has impacted  protected sites and  natural features.Read the full exclusive report here.DOZENS of Scotlands protected sites have been damaged byclimate change, we canreveal today.The long term decline of Scotlandrsquos wildle was documented in a report in  called the State of Nature which claimed one in nine species - including kittiwakes and wildcats - was threatened with extinction.View the full map here.MORE than  habitats and  species inScotlandare in "poor" condition, we can reveal.Environmental and wildle groups are calling for urgent action to combat the twinclimate changeand wildle crises and help preserve Scotlandrsquos natural heritage.View the list in full here.Almost a third of Scotlandrsquos streets have higher levels of toxic particle air pollution than they did before the Covid- pandemic, analysis can reveal.#The ldquoappalling findings show the levels of air pollution caused by small particles ndash known as particulate matter and#largely due to traffic pollution ndash increased in  per cent of average readings taken this year, when compared with data from .View the full exclusive report here.Air pollution is to be the subject of a Scotland-wide investigation ndash the first to be carried out by the countrys new environmental watchdog, we can reveal.EnvironmentStandards Scotland , an independent body which came into force on  October to oversee environmental law post-Brexit, confirmed the "intractable issue" which has plagued Scotland for ldquoover a decade would be the focus of its first major piece of work.Read the full story here.The traffic is at a standstill on Atholl Street in the centre of Perth, cars, trucks and buses running their engines as they wait for the lights to change.##For years this city street ndash#with its mixture of shops, cafes and homes ndash#has been amongst Scotlandrsquos most polluted due to levels of particulate matter . Nitrogen dioxide readings are as high as many on the streets of Scotlandrsquos biggest cities. Exposure to high levels of both pollutants has been linked to increased risk ofhealthconditions like asthma, strokes and even dementia.#Read the full case study here.In an open letter to the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, published as part of our joint investigation, over  leadinghealthprofessionals ndash including consultants, GPs and medical academics ndash are calling for more action to be taken on air pollution to save lives.Councils must enforce laws, they say, air monitoring should be increased, including outside schools, while the Scottish Government should invest more heavily in active travel, publictransportand green infrastructure.Read the letter in full here.Scotlandrsquos rivers, lochs, canals and burns are in the worst state on record, with more than  damaged by pollution and other problems, according to the latest official analysis.New assessment methods used by the ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyhave more than doubled the number of waterways classied as ldquobad between  and . There are ldquosignicant environmental problems caused by a number of pressures, Sepa said.Read the full exclusive report here.SCOTLANDS worst rivers, lochs, canals and burns for pollution have been revealed in new analysis of official watchdog data.Amongst the many rivers rated as either bad or poor by Sepa are some of Scotlandrsquos most well-known. They include long stretches of the Almond, Carron, Dee, Don, Earn, Esk, Kelvin, Lossie, Nairn, Nith, Spey, Tay, Tummel, and Water of Leith.Find how your local river or loch ranks using our interactive toolNearly  sites run by Scottish Water including sewage and wastewater treatment are ldquopoor, ldquovery poor or ldquoat risk, according to Scotlandrsquos environmental watchdog.Almost all these ldquounsatisfactory sites are considered to be among Scotlandrsquos critical national infrastructure ndash operations deemed essential for the state to deliver vital public services.Read the full story here.Today, we reveal the Scottish Government has missed its targets on reducing climate emissions in five of the seven sectors set out in its  plan to tackle climate change.Environmental activists said the missed targets painted a ldquodisappointing picture of widespread failure on emissions reductions. They worry that static or increasing annual emissions in key sectors mean Scotland risks squandering good progress made in other areas.Read the full exclusive report here.The Scottish Government must take ldquoradical action on green job creation and ending fuel povertyit is to achieve a Just Transition to net-zero carbon emissions, trade unions sayThe Scottish low carbon economy provided , jobs in , the most recent data available, a nearly five per cent decrease from . It was also fewer than the , roles provided by the sector in .Read the story in full here.
