title: Assumption pals are going on stage
story: TEN years ago, a group of lelong friends decided to mark their th birthdays by putting on a play for charity.After months of rehearsals the friends, all past pupils at Assumption Grammar School in Ballynahinch, put on a sell-out performance in Down Arts Centre in Downpatrick, raising nearly pound for Marie Curie.Roll on another decade, a lockdown, an approaching big birthday, months of rehearsals and there is another production.The women will be performing Steel Magnolias in Assumption Grammar School on November -.Marcelle Orsi, director, past pupil and vice-principal at Assumption, explained the reason for treading the boards again.ldquoIt was one of those zoom calls during lockdown when we decided to try our hand at putting on a play again, she said.ldquoWe had always really liked the play Steel Magnolias and the film version was of course set in the era when our friendships were forged.It is a great play to use as it is an all-female cast but it also suited us and what we were trying to achieve.ldquoIt is an emotive play with warm, funny characters but it also deals with sensitive subjects such as questionable relationships, living with illness and the loss of a loved one.Moreover, it just seemed so appropriate as it centres on the friendship of six women whose love and humour and solidarity help them through the challenges of le.Marcelle said the importance of friendship was recognised during the lockdown.ldquoAs a group, we feel very fortunate to share such a strong bond, she explained. We wanted to celebrate that and also remember our dear friend and past pupil, Sonia Kinsella, who died of cancer last year.ldquoWhen we think of her strength and her courage and more importantly, her optimism, this play seemed so appropriate. We hope it pays tribute to Sonia as I think the sentiments this play evokes were embodied in that remarkable lady.ldquoThe play celebrates the strength of female friendship and the incredible support women experience from each other. I think our audiences will find themselves laughing one minute and crying the next.I am so proud of what has been achieved not only in the fact we havenrsquot fallen out despite the dficulties you face when you are trying to work with friends but also the time these busy women have devoted to learning lines and rehearsing while working full time and coping with family responsibilities. It has been hard work but I truly feel audiences will really enjoy the performance.Proceeds from the performances will be in aid of Marie Curie and Assumption Grammar Schoolrsquos sister schools in South Africa.Marcelle said: ldquoThese schools struggle financially anyway but they are experiencing great challenges during lockdown. The money we raise will make a huge dference to many lives there, allowing girls to get access to education and to be offered a meal each day.The provision offered to these students in South Africa can make all the dference to their future.She added: It is wonderful to see the fruition of all our hard work that all stemmed from a conversation during lockdown and that will hopefully benefit others in dferent ways.To purchase a ticket the production, please contact the school reception on   . Tickets are pound each with all proceeds being ided between the two charities. Those unable to make it, can still donate by going to the JustGiving Page..prettyPhoto

title: Birds of prey finding a safe home
story: BIRD feeding for the majority of people means putting out some seeds and nuts but Stephen and Karen Malcomson have taken this to the next level and beyond.At their farm in the townland of Dechomet in Ballyward on the western slopes of Slieve Croob, the couple have developed a wildle sanctuary mdash The Red Kite Retreat mdash with a custom built hide for guests to observe the fantastic aerial displays of the Red Kites.The retreat is the only Red Kite feeding station and bird hide in Ireland, located on the Malcomson family farm.Although the Red Kites were persecuted to extinction in Ireland over  years ago, they were successfully reintroduced in  when the RSPB Northern Ireland, the Golden Eagle Trust and the Welsh Kite Trust mdash in conjunction with local councils mdash began an ambitious reintroduction project to help bring the magnicent birds back to Northern Ireland.The Malcomsonsrsquo farm lies at the epicentre of their habitat in Northern Ireland and visitors can now sit in the newly constructed bird hide and watch these majestic birds feed and soar through the skies.In addition, a planning application has been submitted for a caravan and camping site on the farm, with a classroom for education and conservation events.ldquoWe are now officially open, said a delighted Karen.ldquoIt has been a long road and we wish to thank you everyone who has helped us get to this point. The website is now live. It is www.redkiteretreat and we are regularly updating our Facebook page @redkiteretreat. For more information please pay us a visit on Facebook, like and share the page.Red Kites were in the area and over a year ago and Stephen started feeding them and as this continued more and more started turning up daily.Red Kites are a bird of prey and have a huge wingspan of up to . metres they are reddish brown with black wingtips and a grey head.They have a distinctive V-shaped tail which they use like a rudder as they twist and turn through the air on thermals and their call is a long whistle.Red Kites are primarily scavengers and a big part of their diet is made up of dead animals , including road-kill. They also follow tractors when ploughing and swoop down to grab any small animals that have been killed by the mowers or brought to the surface.They are no threat to livestock and the largest animal they have the power and speed to kill is a young rabbit. Red Kites, like all other birds of prey, are protected by law and to harm, disturb or kill them is a criminal offence.The new Red Kite Retreat bird hide has already become very popular with wildle photographers and bird watchers and booking a slot is essential.Three generations of the Malcomson family have also helped to plant some of the first of , native trees on a -acre site to create The Warriorrsquos Wood on Dechomet Mountain.The main contractor, Scottish Woodland Ireland Ltd, managed the forest expansion and farm ersication project and planted Irish Oak, Hazel, Holly, Scots Pine and Downy Birch. Stephen and Karen also created two new ponds to encourage wildle and sowed a new wildflower meadow.Warriorrsquos Wood is the initial habitat enhancement works which form part of the new eco-tourism development known as the lsquoRed Kite Retreatrsquo.Stephen and Karen are the projectrsquos co-founders and wanted a means of ersying their farm business to ensure future sustainability.Currently, Stephen has a pig and beef unit on the farm but said ldquofarming enterprises have to adapt and evolve to ensure sustainability for future generations of farmers. I see no reason why modern farming practices cannot go hand in hand with conservation, environmental enrichment and encouraging bioersity.The Red Kite Retreat project aims to create a unique tourist and visitor facility and focuses on conservation and education about the Red Kite bird of prey, with the creation of the Warriorrsquos Wood the first step in the project.The Wood has been designed to mimic ancient woodland with species adapted to grow in elevated and exposed locations, with the planting including Scots pine, oak, birch, aspen, rowan, hawthorn and juniper.The Scots pine is favoured by native red squirrels which it is hoped will be reintroduced once the woodland has matured, while Juniper is also being established on the site.Updates in the Red Kite retreat are available on Facebook @redkiteretreat, by logging on at www.redkiteretreat or telephone .prettyPhoto

title: Castle Espie receives plaudit
story: THE Castle Espie Wetland Centre on the shores of Strangford Lough, which recently hosted the popular BBC wildle programme Autumnwatch, has been praised for its ongoing conservation work.Ards and North Down deputy mayor Robert Adair visited the centrersquos base recently and met BBC programme presenter Gillian Burke and Castle Espie manager Paul Stewart.Cllr Adair said after the huge success of Springwatch at Castle Espie, the television programmersquosfor Autumnwatch has shone the spotlight on the rich wildle of the borough and Castle Espie as an icon of sustainable green tourism.In addition to hosting Autumnwatch, the visit comes as the charity is currently celebrating with a Winter Migration Festival at Castle Espie which includes a series of bespoke events for adults and children alike and runs until November .Cllr Adair said the international importance of Strangford Lough and its exceptional bioersity is a real asset to the environment.ldquoCastle Espie provides a window on the lough with the Winter Migration Festival and filming of Autumnwatch being a fitting way to introduce people to this wonderful asset on our doorstep, he added.Mr Stewart said the centre has been celebrating the natural resource and theof the Brent geese with events in and around Autumnwatch aimed at connecting people with nature.ldquoFrom sunrise yoga, art workshops, walks and talks, to nature focused activities for children, they are all aimed at connecting people to this wonderful place, he explained.ldquoThe worldrsquos wetland habitats like those at Castle Espie actually sequester more carbon than all the worldrsquos forests despite occupying only a fraction of the area around the globe.ldquoAs well as helping to deal with the effects of climate change, wetlands are one of the most bioerse habitats on Earth, protect us from flooding, filter pollutants and help improve our mental health.The Wildle and Wetlands Trust works around the globe, protecting wetland habitats and migratory bird flyways and operates  wetland centres across the UK with Castle Espie the only one in Northern Ireland.The charity recently launched a new lsquoWetlands Can!rsquo campaign, urging people to get behind the leading conservation charityrsquos call for creating , hectares of healthy wetlands in the UK to help combat the climate crisis.Mr Stewart added: ldquoIf the Covid crisis has taught us one thing, itrsquos that we canrsquot go back to how things were before. We need to get serious now about fighting the climate emergency and, as wetlands are particularly fast and cost-effective at absorbing carbon, they need to be an essential part of that fight.To book a Winter Migration Festival event, visit https:www.wwt.org.uk wetland-centres castle-espie whats-on winter-migration-festival- To join WWTrsquos urgent pledge, visit wwt.org.uk WetlandsCan.prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick getting more Christmas lights
story: PLANS by Newry, Mourne and Down Council to add some festive sparkle to Church Street and lower English Street in Downpatrick this Christmas have been welcomed by local politicians.In addition, Down Arts Centre will have a new Christmas lighting display to add to the yuletide atmosphere in the town.For many years, Church Street and lower English Street missed out on festive lighting, but that is all set to change.Downpatrick area councillors Oonagh Hanlon and Dermot Curran say the new lighting displays will be welcomed by local people and the business community.They have confirmed that the local authority is working on providing new illuminations on the front faccedilade of the Arts Centre and illuminating two trees at De Courcy Square at the bottom of English Street.ldquoThis is a welcome addition for this area of Downpatrick, said Cllr Hanlon.ldquoI have been working closely with local businesses and council officers over the past few years on this project and the new festive lighting is a small example of how working collaboratively can improve our area.She said the new festive lights will be especially welcome after what has been a particularly dficult year for many.She also confirmed that as part of the pound, Church Street revitalisation programme, additional festive lighting will be provided.Cllr Curran said the business community in particular will welcome the additional lighting on the Arts Centre and at Church Street and lower English Street.ldquoIt would be fair to say that these areas have largely missed out for many years on festive lighting and the local councilrsquos recognition to put this right will be warmly welcomed, he said.ldquoGiven what the community and businesses have had to endure for  months, the additional festive lighting in tandem with displays where in Downpatrick town centre will help lt the mood.Cllr Curran said he has spoken with some business owners who were concerned that English Street had missed out on Christmas lighting over previous years.He added: ldquoWhile it is planned to decorate two trees at De Courcey Square, this must just be the start and I will be keen to see an enhanced festive display next year. Businesses at this part of the town deserve nothing less..prettyPhoto

title: East Down AC star in Bangor
story: THE highly popular North Down festival of cross country running event took place on the outskirts of Bangor on Saturday.We might get used to these dry cross country running days although it was much colder than recent weeks, the sun still shone. Perhaps there is something to this global warming malarkey after all EDAC had two juniors taking part. Both were using the course as practice for the more competitive All-Ireland races coming up in the middle of November.Alex Robinson ran in the U- race which was two loops of the one-mile course. He ran very well and held onto fourth place for most of the race, just ping to fth on the final turn. The hills drained his legs so he couldnrsquot master a sprint.He finished the two-mile course in a time of ., which at just over six minutes per mile, is nothing to be disappointed with for cross country.Oliver Robinson ran in the U- race. The U- and U- boys and girls ran together for three miles, three loops of the same course.Oliver said he went out at his planned pace, leading the pack for half of the race before being overtaken towards the end of the second lap by the U- and U- eventual winners.He placed second in the U- race in a time of .,managing his usual sprint finish. Oliver finished third boy overall. Well done to both lads for continuously keeping the East Down name to the fore, week in week out.EDAC member Patrick Smith also made the long trip to Bangor on Saturday to take part in the gloriously titled North Down Festival of Cross Country Running, just to try it out.Although he was the sole EDAC representative, he soon settled into a good rhythm, despite the very tricky underfoot conditions brought about by heavy overnight rain, which almost flies in the face of the seemingly never ending forecasts of impending global warming doom.He was only running to have a go at cross country, since all his club colleagues had been fulsome in their praise for last weekendrsquos races in Comber, and also to re-kindle the love for the genre, some  years after his last attempt.So without over exerting himself and drinking in the applause of the spectators, he finished in a highly respectable . and th place in a high quality field.Despite Patrick being unduly critical of his performance, he had finished the course in what is a pretty good time for a cross country race. Race position is only a number.Well done Patrick, no need to run down your achievements, yoursquoll find plenty to do that, keep your chin up and keep going.Coach Ryan Maxwell sent Gordy Graham off to the Armagh ten miler on Sunday as his first building block on the road to the Manchester Marathon next spring.Gordy said that it was a brilliant event but a tough courseyou were after a personal best. In his case, as this was his first time at the distance, his time of . gives him a PB anyway.He admitted that it was hard at the end when he saw other runners giving it a kick for the finish as he had been warned well to stay to his own pace.In the end, he achieved both his goal time and the prize for first male  and over. He also commended the Armagh AC volunteers and marshals for putting on such a fantastic event. A good day out all round.Neil Curran has been steadily working on form and fitness and went to Armagh unsure of how he would fare. He was happy to go under the hour in saying it was: ldquoA first time for me on this course, more hills than anticipated so very happy with the time considering itrsquos a tough enough route.ldquoI started off slow to see how I felt, upped it in the last three miles and felt it was a solid run.His time of . gave him th place overall. If Irsquom not being presumptuous could I offer word of advice to both Gordy and Neil  Target the phenomenal Tommy Hughes, the Marrakesh Express, who continues to set records at  and who finished Sundayrsquos race in . and th place overall.He is maintaining his form and is surely an excellent man to take a pace from..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C  November 7%2C 2001
story: SHRIGLEY ndash Down District has suffered a major jobs blow.The Shrigley Tannery has this week confirmed it has laid off a number of staff at its leather processing plant, blaming the move on a downturn in orders.Ten workers were laid off last Friday and another seven are due to go this Friday at the plant which  months ago employed  people.The current workforce stands at  and staff fear more job losses could be just around the corner at the only leather tannery in the Province.A spokesman for International Leathers has blamed the lay-offs on a downturn in orders, but remains optimistic about the future. He said the local company, which is the largest private employer in the Killyleagh area, regrets that after two yearsrsquo growth, it has been necessary to lay off staff.The spokesman said evenit had not been for the events in America on September , there has been an unfortunate downturn in the leather clothing business.ldquoAs a result of reduced orders, it has been necessary to take this short term step and we would stress these are lay-offs not redundancies and we remain optimistic about the future, the spokesman added.DOWNPATRICK ndash A vandalism attack on the GPrsquos emergency vehicle placed patientsrsquo lives across the district at risk last week.Doctors have revealed that had the Pound Lane attack in Downpatrick not been spotted by paramedics based at the Downe Hospital, the consequences for patients could have been fatal.Two tyres on the special car used by GPs belonging to the DowneDoc GP co-operative were slashed during the early hours of Thursday morning in an attack described as a ldquofrightening new development.The emergency vehicle, which is packed with vital medical equipment, was targeted outside the Pound Lane Health Clinic sometime between .am and .am. The manager of the local service has confirmed that the incident is the first deliberate attack against an on-call GP service in Northern Ireland in the past five years.Mr Mark Armstrong described the Downpatrick attack as a ldquofrightening new development because the vandals deliberately put the emergency car off the road by puncturing both tyres.He also confirmed an immediate review of security has been ordered in the wake of the attack to ensure it does not happen again and that patients lives are not put at risk.SEAFORDE ndash Criminals have once again targeted a family-owned business on the Newcastle to Seaforde Road.Police are investigating the most recent attack on Brennanrsquos service station during which a car rammed into the front of the building on Thursday evening, causing damage estimated at several thousand pounds.Just a few week ago a Securicor van parked outside the garage was also targeted by thieves.Those responsible for the most recent incident made off in their vehicle without taking anything from the premises.It is understood that they were attempting to access a cash machine inside the building but were disturbed before they got to the machine.Councillor Patsy Toman said people throughout the community were ldquodisgusted that the McKibbenrsquos family business had been targeted.ldquoThis family is working hard to serve the district and they have installed the cash machine as a service to local people which some think was the target for last weekrsquos attack, he said.ldquoIt would be a real pitythis cash machine had to be removed to stop vandals attacking the store.DRUMANESS ndash Drunken vandals ran amok in a night of horric Halloween violence in Drumaness last week.Parts of the village were vandalised as the teenagers, some of whom were brandishing fireworks, terrorised residents in the village on Wednesday night.The situation was so bad that local politicians and police were called to speak with teenagers in a bid to quell the trouble and a number of parents were also contacted to take their children home.Local councillor, Mr Patsy Toman, said many people were disgusted at the behaviour of the teenagers, many of whom he claimed were fuelled by alcohol they had bought illegally.Mr Toman, who was called to the village along with Down Council chairwoman, Mrs Anne McAleenan, said the widespread hooliganism and violence has no place in Drumaness and hopes the situation will not be repeated.He said young children and elderly people were terried as the teenagers ran amok and claimed the damage to property was widespread.ldquoThe majority of the teenagers responsible for the trouble were tanked up on illegal alcohol they had purchased and there is a real underage drinking problem in Drumaness which has to be addressed, he said.BALLYNAHINCH ndash Northern Ireland Electricity will invest pound, on improvements to the Ballynahinch network over the next six months.NIE officials have confirmed that the programme of work in the locality will include the installation of high voltage underground cables which will improve the local environment.The work began this week and the first section, at Church Road between the Downpatrick Road junction and Carlisle Park, will be completed before the end of the month.NIE customer service centre manager, Ann Ferguson, said the work was part of a pound.m investment programme in the South Down area.ldquoBallynahinch was badly affected by storms over the past year, causing disruption to electricity supplies in the town and surrounding areas, she said.ldquoI am delighted to announce this investment, which should bring improvements to the current system and enable one of the fastest growing towns in Northern Ireland cope with increasing demand for electricity.CROSSGAR ndash Roads Service officials have been urged to do all they can to secure additional finance to allow further improvements on the main Crossgar to Saintfield Road.The call was issued at a special meeting of Down Council on Monday night when the districtrsquos senior roads chief revealed work on a current pound, realignment scheme is expected to be completed ahead of schedule.A large section of the busy A between the Killybawn and Carsonstown Road junctions has been realigned during a major construction scheme over the past number of months and while local politicians are delighted, they hope the completion of the current phase does not signal the end of improvements work at the main route which links Downpatrick and Belfast.They hope Roads Service officials will now concentrate their efforts on improving another major section of the road from Doranrsquos Rock into Saintfield.Mr William Dick, who has been lobbying for the entireof the main road to be upgraded, says the latest work to be completed has transformed the area and will make a major dference to road users.NEWCASTLE ndash Arsonists caused pound, of damage to a toilet block in Newcastle last week.The fire, at the public toilets in the Islandrsquos car park off the Bryansford Road, was discovered by a passer-by at .pm on Friday night.Local fire crews attended the scene, but the blaze was already well underway and the building, which was installed as part of a major Down Council scheme just four years ago, was gutted.Describing the fire as ldquototally senseless, council official Mr Winston Reid explained the Newcastle toilet block has been part of scheme which cost pound, several years ago to improve council-owned public toilets in the district.ldquoThis is totally dreadful, especially when Down Council spends so much money on improving public conveniences in the area.The attack was condemned by local councillor Willie Clarke. He said attacks on public property represented attacks on ratepayers and meant that money earmarked for important development projects would have to be spent on repairs..prettyPhoto

title: Keep on running for Alistair who notches up 20 marathons and raises money for charity
story: A SAINTFIELD man who ran his th marathon in Boston last month has raised nearly pound, for liver research.Alistair Craig is now back on course for completing the Six Stars mdash the accolade of completing the worldrsquos top marathons mdash when he aims to run the Toyko Marathon in .He would have completed all of the big six racesmdash London, Berlin, New York, Chicago, Boston and Tokyo mdash last year but the Covid- pandemic meant he was unable to travel internationally.Forty-four year-old Alistair said: ldquoI managed to run the New York Marathon andjust before the pandemic took hold and then the Boston race was cancelled and ran virtually which I also took part in.ldquoOne of the big challenges with Boston is that you nearly have to be semi-pro to be fast enough to get in and qualy, or  you have run it for charityldquoI ran for the American Liver Foundation which funds research into dferent liver disease and cancer and helps support patients. I did so because my mum Marilyn has had liver cancer for the last three years.Alistair said that the Boston Marathon was quite an emotional event for him this time due to his motherrsquos illness.ldquoI ran as part of a charity team with  people from all over the States and some other international runners and I got to hear why other people were running and their situations as well.The overall time effort was raising , which will go into medical research.Alistair has raised thousands more for other charities, such as Barnardorsquos, from his running.He felt that running the marathon was not as challenging as actually getting to Boston.Alistair explained: ldquoThere was lots of training without knowingit would even happen, waiting and hoping the US border would open to allow travel and when it didnrsquot in time, I had to convince the US Consulate in Belfast to grant me a special exemption to travel, so there were lots of hurdles to overcome on this journey.Alistairrsquos achievements are all the more impressive since he only took up running nearly six years ago.ldquoI decided to take up running for fitness and I used a couch to K running app on my phone. I certainly wasnrsquot particularly sporty. I found that running ldquoI started at Christmas  and did my first my first marathon in November  in Valencia, Spain, so my progress was quite quick.Alistair, who is CEO of the tech company, PeopleHawk, continued: ldquoOnce I did my first half-marathon, the move-up to full marathon was not that bad.ldquoRunning has not only improved my fitness but it also helps me to unwind and de-stress, and clear my head.ldquoAnytime I felt under pressure, I would go out for a run and when I came back I felt so much better.ldquoYou never regret going for a run, despite the struggles that you have to convince yourself to get up and go.He is still in a marathon runnersrsquo hall of fame as the top five finishers.Married to Julie, Alistair is the father of ten year-old twins, John and Hannah.He plans to do two or three marathons next year in the UK or Europe in preparation for Tokyo..prettyPhoto

title: Kilclief are champions
story: THIS final was low scoring, but certainly not low on quality or drama.East Belfast, unbeaten all year and Dean Davies Cup winners, were victors against Darragh Cross in the semi final, whilst Kilclief overcame a strong Ballela outfit to set up a fascinating showpiece final between two sides at opposite ends of their development spectrum.Kilcliefrsquos strong heritage and championship know how, versus an energetic East Belfast side, that has had the most remarkable two years.In a very cagey opening quarter, tackles were flying in, Bernadette Convery, Ciara Mathers and Jane McErlain formed a strong defensive barrier in front of an impressive full back line of Aine Moynan, Clare Kelly and Shannon McWilliams.Ben Dearg, have the most potent and dynamic of forward lines, with Eimear Breen, Nora Maguire and the lethal Zara Burns.The aforementioned trio have wreaked havoc on defences all season, but the Belfast Gaels stayed resolute and organised, with the scores level at - to - at the first water-break.The historic goal for East Belfast came from Aoe McGrenaghan who somehow forced the sliotar under Ben Dearg netminder Jordan Hynds.It was an impressive score, given that Aoe was surrounded by Kilclief defenders. Hynds produced a peerless display aside from that concession, a former Poc Fada competitor, her restarts were struck with precision to wing forwards Katie Black and Niamh Galloway, who in turn fed team captain Joanne Sloane.Straight away, Sloane would angle deliveries into the mobile Maguire. Sloanersquos slick stickwork was impressive, and she had a fine contest versus Bernie Convery throughout.The key battle however, was the dual between Dearg centre back Grainne Glendenning and Belfastrsquos Jessica Rush.With her luminous green boots and helmet, Rush would stand out in any game, but she has the class to back up the bright colours.Winning a huge amount of primary possession, Jessica lsquos jinking, probing runs and vision to find Nicole Clerkin and Niamh Dolan was causing huge headaches for an experienced Ben Dearg defence.Kilcliefrsquos breakthrough goal came in the th minute with Burns finishing brilliantly past Lara OrsquoHare.Clare Kelly and Aacuteine Moynan made timely and brave blocks from Nora Maguirersquos goalbound efforts. The midfield battle was an intriguing and crucial one.Dual star Cara Doran has been on a scoring spree in the football championship this year and she continued her hot streak, with some exceptionally well taken scores from tight angles.Eimear Dorrian was everywhere, covering every blade of grass, never static, always roving, trying to create and make things happen. Dorrianrsquos dynamism and Doranrsquos deadliness contributed hugely to the green and reds display.Niamh McGuigan produced an equally impressive display for the Belfast side. McGuiganrsquos magnetic ability to gain possession in the tightest of spaces is remarkable.Never rushed, despite the chaos around her, she has that precarious talent of always having time, allowing her to scan and assess options, a luxury that only the very top operatorrsquos have.All season, Niamh Daly has also operated at centre field, but cruelly missed out on this final through injury.Brigid Scullion cleverly ped deep to forage for possession, picking up loose ball and linking well with half backs McErlain and Mathers. Kilclief thundered into action with another brace of points from deadly Doran.Her score in the st minute was worthy of the admission fee. Still only  years of age, a career in county colours surely beckons for this gted youngGael.Eimear Breen was a constant outlet for her defence to hit, a player who uses her pace effectively at the right times.With  minutes remaining, Kilclief were edging the contest with a five point cushion. Management Brendan Breen and Seaacuten Paul Doran madetactical tweaks to thwart the increasingly dangerous Clerkin and Dolan axis up front.A double sweeper system was swtly put in place, Cliona Shields and Catherine Deegan were tasked with shutting up shop forming a highly effective shield in front of Ballinascreen stalwart Nicole Clerkin.Nicolersquos space was greatly reduced, but still she battled as hard as possible to cut the deficit. McMullan and Mastersonrsquos masterclass in creating space for goalkeeper Hynds to aim towards, were signicant.McMullan typied the fight and character within the Ben Dearg outfit, as did the industrious Catherine Deegan. Yet, East Belfast pressed with an astounding intensity and relentlessness.That huge work rate comes from having dual players with fierce commitment and blocks of fitness from constant competing, but also from their Bainisteoiriacute Ciaran Hughes and Seaacuten Coulter who encourage their team to play with flair, and they certainly do that, but intense work ethic is paramountyou are to retain a place in this highly motivated team.That competition for places has ensured consistent performance levels all season.Niamh Dolan cleverly created precious space in the congested final third in the th minute, but her angled drive was superbly blocked by Cliona Shields, then swept up bravely by the heroic McMullan, who swtly transitioned to the always available Dorrian.Testament to the synchronisity that is within this Ben Dearg side, Dorrian didnrsquot have to look up to spot the expertly timed run of Burns who showed a deftness of touch to control the sliotar and sail it straight over the black spot.It was a score that comes from playing training together over many seasons. At the other end Aacuteine Moynan and Shannon McWilliams made important blocks, just as Joanne Sloan and Niamh Galloway were about to raise green flags.Clodagh Hanvey made a strong contribution after entering the fray. Maguirersquos maturity and decision making is exceptional for a Gael just turned .With Cara Doran the same age, the future is bright for this Kilclief team. Breen too, displays a shrewd tactical brain, dropping into spaces, covering runs, causing havoc.Doran was awarded player of the match, for her scintillating display, though a case could also have been made for East Belfastrsquos Niamh McGuigan.Niamhrsquos link up play with Jessica Rush was a joy to watch, but equally impressive was her willingness to help team mates in trouble, a true team player.With both teams featuring strong and dynamic forward units, this game was always going to be decided by which defence came out on top.Ultimately, the craft, guile and experience of the Kilclief reargaurd ensured that they closed the game out and got the Championship title they so craved, especially after last yearrsquos heartbreaking defeat to Attical.Euphoric scenes and emotions were unleashed as referee HP McCusker blew his final whistle.Team captain Joanne Sloane spoke from the heart, with a speech that did her club proud. A huge roar went up from the Ben Dearg support whenever she lted aloft the Liam Mac An Ri championship trophy.Each age group at juvenile and now senior level has collected silverware this season, testament to the solid work taking place at their fantastic new facilities in St Malachyrsquos Park.Lorraine MacCartanrsquos priceless contribution in the development of players at the club was highlighted, and deserved praise was duly given to this exemplary East Belfast side.The Ulster Championships now beckon for Kilclief.Referee: H P McCusker .prettyPhoto

title: Kilmore navigate their way past Maze
story: KILMORE Rec welcomed Lower Maze to Robert Adams Park in the third round of the Peaky Blinders Irish Cup and produced a barn storming second half comeback to progress to round four.With Kilmore two goals down at half-time, having been harshly reduced to ten men after  minutes, the odds were stacked against them.However, a tactical change and a second half performance full of hard work and passion epitomised by man of the match Paddy Grant saw Michael Carvillrsquos men defy those odds and produce one of the most memorable comebacks seen at Robert Adams Park in recent times.Kilmore started brightly but after just eight minutes they failed to clear their lines from a corner, allowing Lower Mazersquos Alex Scott to pick up the ball  yards out and fire through a crowded goal mouth past an unsighted Chris Turley in the Kilmore goals.The task in hand got harder when the referee adjudged Kilmore captain Niall McCarthy to be the aggressor in a midfield confrontation and, to the astonishment of all in the ground, deemed it a red card offence.The injustice of the sending off galvanised Kilmorersquos ten men and they took the game to Lower Maze, dominating possession and creating chances.The first of these saw Caolan Conlon burst through from midfield. His shot was well saved and the rebound fell to Gary Kennedy who fired towards the net only to see Maze lsquokeeper Heron produce a great double save.Cai Gemmel, who was magnicent throughout, saw a goal bound effort deflected wide of the head of a Maze defender as it seemed destined for the top corner.As the chances came and went Kilmore got caught with a sucker punch in the nd minute.Bradford made his way down the left and his mis-cued cross beat a stranded Turley to leave Kilmore two down at half-time and up against it.Carvill changed the shape of the team at half-time and went with a front two of Paddy Grant and Josh Smyth.This change paid idends in the th minute when Grant weaved his way into the box, although it appeared he had been forced too wide, but the forward still managed to fire a rasping drive to the roof of the net.In the th minute a sustained period of Kilmore pressure brought the equaliser, with Grant again involved when his clipped cross was nodded in at the back post by the energetic Josh Smyth.Kilmore continued to dominate and press for the winner, as it seemed as though the game was destined for extra time.In the th minute the pressure finally paid off when Carvill whipped in a corner and that man Grant was on hand to hook the ball home from close range to send the Kilmore faithful into raptures.As Lower Maze then threw everything at Kilmore in injury time, the Blues defence of Magee, Larkin, Kennedy, Stewart and lsquokeeper Turley remained steadfast.Kilmorersquos substitutes of Dagen and Lynas had a chance each on the break for a fourth, but it wasnrsquot to be.Carvill spoke of his ldquoimmense pride in the resilience and determination shown by his side after the match.It came as no surprise that the Kilmore supporters man of the match went to Paddy Grant for his two goals and an assist in a match winning performance.This win sealed double delight for Kilmore, as the club recently secured approval for the installation of a new G football pitch, complete with floodlights, dug-outs, pitch side fencing and associated pathways.Kilmore: Turley, Smyth, Stewart, Larkin, Magee, Gemmell, Conlon, McCarthy, Kennedy, Carvil, Grant. Subs: Lynas, Dagen, Mulholland.Lower Maze: Heron, Davidson, Snoddy, McDowell, Scott, Bradford, Canavan, Stevenson, Short, Scott. Subs: Davidson, Kelly, Glover..prettyPhoto

title: Lions clubs teaming up to deliver some Xmas cheer
story: LOCAL Lions Clubs are to join forces as part of a major fundraising operation to help support the districtrsquos foodbanks in the run-up to Christmas.Conscious that the festive season will be even more dficult for many families this year, Lions Clubs in Downpatrick, Newcastle and Ballynahinch are to work alongside their counterparts in Banbridge, Newry and Armagh as part of the new initiative.In previous years, Lions Club officials helped foodbanks in their respective areas, but the new campaign will see the total amount the ious clubs raise ided equally among six foodbanks, with the money handed over on December .Lions members will raise money for the foodbanks by taking part in ious fundraising projects themselves and providing a facility for the public to donatethey would like to help a very worthy cause.The fundraising project will include six Lions presidents taking part in a k sponsored walk around the beautul Montalto Estate in Ballynahinch at the end of November.All the participating clubs will provide prizes for a raffle and will be encouraged to donate from running one off events.Already, Newcastle Lions Club has raised pound for the new fund which was raised during a recent pub quiz andanyone would like to donate to the Foodbank Christmas appeal they can do so by logging on at www.lionsnewcastlecodown.org and clicking the donate button.Lions officials say they are acutely aware that given how dficult Christmas can be for many families, dedicated volunteers who run foodbanks will be doing all they can to ease as much of that pressure as they can.To achieve their goal, they require additional manpower, food donations and financial support.Over previous years, Lions clubs have helped inidual foodbanks, with some clubs donating boxes of Easter eggs, full Easter and Christmas dinners, cash or boxes of food.And while the clubs themselves are under pressure given the events of the past  months with donations down and Covid- still in circulation, they want to make a concerted effort to help those in need at a time of the year noted for peoplersquos giving and generosity.In Downpatrick, the Fountain Foodbank volunteers provide an average of  parcels of non-perishable food, cleaning products and toiletries Butcher vouchers are given with the parcels helping to increase the benefit to clients, with the Downpatrick foodbank pleased with the generosity of the local community in response to the increasing need.Using a referral system and working with other charities ensures the parcels get to those who need them most.In trying to help the foodbanks in their towns, the six Lions Clubs all face a challengethey are to raise any money.In coming together in a common effort, this has inspired each club and provided the confidence to realise that while their own club may have small membership numbers, there now are over one hundred Lion members helping to raise donations for a fund that will be split six ways equally and handed over next month.Lions officials say that in some towns there could be several foodbanks and some have Christian ministry models whose goal is to help people become self-sustainable. Even though not all are called foodbanks, all are there helping families regardless.Each foodbank or ministry tells a dferent story and each provides help in dferent ways. While Downpatrick has the Fountain Foodbank, Banbridge has a Christian ministry group called J based in the old cinema which will be supporting  families this Christmas..prettyPhoto

title: McKee stands down from UUP
story: MOURNES Ulster Unionist councillor Harold McKee has quit the party.The veteran politician and former South Down MLA has resigned, saying that Doug Beattiersquos leadership of the party is at odds with his religious beliefs.Cllr McKee, who will remain an independent member of Newry, Mourne and Down Council, criticised Mr Beattie for advising members to ldquoleave their Christianity at the door.His resignation comes ahead of next Mayrsquos Assembly election when his wide network of connections across the Mournes area would havebeen a key part of the UUPrsquos drive to secure a seat in South Down.Cllr McKee has confirmed that he intends to serve as an independent ldquoat this point in time with some suggesting that he could potentially be approached by the DUP to join its three councillors on the local authority.He has attacked his former party leader over his stance on abortion, same-sex marriage and a recent vote at Stormont on gay conversion therapy.ldquoIn relation to same sex marriage which Mr Beattie is keen to endorse, I cannot go against the infallible word of God that marriage is between one man and one woman, said Cllr McKee.ldquoI am saddened to observe that these views seem to be of little value in the UUP of today but, rather, a stance of celebrating left-of-centre liberalism seems to be the only acceptable viewpoint.His resignation statement said Mr Beattiersquos leadership was ldquoa far cry from the UUP roots and ldquothe party of Carson and Craig.When Mr Beattie succeeded Steve Aiken as UUP leader earlier this year, he pledged to have a dferent style that would be ldquoable to reach out to all people in Northern Ireland regardless of what your religion is, sexual orientation or ethnicity.Cllr McKee said it was ldquobecoming very dficult to endorse a leader who is constantly to the fore promoting liberal issues while conservative values were being squeezedout. A UUP spokesperson said the party was sorry that Mr McKee had decided his political future no longer lay with the UUP.ldquoWe would like to thank Harold for his service and wish him well for the future, the spokesperson said. ldquoThe party will continue to hold out the hand of friendship as Harold takes a new path.Slieve Croob Ulster Unionist councillor Alan Lewis has described the decision by his former colleague to quit as ldquodisappointing.He continued: ldquoThere are many things that I find myself disagreeing with in all parties, not just my own and sometimes I find that it is better to continue to lobby, talk through and progress these issues from the inside, rather than walk out the door.ldquoThatrsquos democratic politics. Nobody is going to call for the gallows just because your opinion dfers, no matter how rigorous the debate. Unionism demands cohesion with the avoidance of ision.Cllr Lewis also thanked his former colleague for his ldquohelp, support, wisdom and guidance since he was elected to Newry, Mourne and Down Council.He added: ldquoI will always consider Harold a friend and fellow unionist. He has overcome personal turmoil and, like many of us, has a strong faith which has encouraged and supported him through dficult times.ldquoI genuinely wish him all the best in whatever he chooses to do next.Earlier this year, DUP councillors Glyn Hanna and Kathryn Owen quit their party over concerns following the election of Edwin Poots as leader.Mr Poots was subsequently replaced by Sir Jeffrey Donaldson MP and a short time later Cllr Hanna, who also represents the Mournes area, and Cllr Owen, who represents the Rowallane area, rejoined the party..prettyPhoto

title: New £12m sports pitch at Ballyhornan ‘fantastic facility’ for local community
story: BALLYHORNANrsquoS new G sports pitch has been officially opened.The pound.m investment mdash which includes floodlights and ultra-modern changing facilities mdash has been funded by the Northern Ireland Executiversquos Social Investment Fund and Newry, Mourne and Down Council.Located adjacent to the Ballyhornan Family Centre, the new pitch is already widely used and has brought a number of benefits to the community.The Social Investment Fund contributed pound.m to the new development with the remainder provided by the local authority, with the Ballyhornan Community Association playing a pivotal role in helping secure the funding for the new pitch which was completed in October last year.Designed to increase access to community and leisure services by providing a fit-for-purpose, safe and structured environment to meet the needs and expectations of the Ballyhornan community and surrounding area, the new pitch will make a major contribution to help improve the health and well-being of people in the area.Ballyhornan and District Community Association chairwoman, Patricia Curran, expressed her delight to finally have a completed facility after years of rallying to secure funding for the G pitch which can be used all year round.ldquoWe are very grateful to all the statutory bodies and the local council who supported us throughout this campaign. Without them, we would not have achieved our goal, said Mrs Curran.ldquoThis pitch will be a great asset to Ballyhornan and outlying communities and we are very appreciative of this opportunity to provide a top of the range sports facility.Mrs Curran extended thanks to several people who worked with community officials to secure agreement for the new pitch and deliver it.Special thanks were extended to former local council officer Liam McLernon, Cllr Dermot Curran and former councillor Naomi Bailie for their ldquoimmense support.Mrs Curran also highlighted the support of Celtic Bhoys Football Club which uses the new pitch for its home games. She said the clubrsquos support was essential ldquoin making the project a success.Council chairwoman Cathy Mason, who performed the official opening, said one of the organisationrsquos key objectives was to improve the health and wellbeing of everyone in the district and reduce health inequalities.ldquoThis new facility will become a thriving hub that will have a hugely positive impact on the local area, benefitting the health and wellbeing of people of all ages by offering improved access to modern sporting facilities, she said.ldquoThis fantastic new facility is an excellent example of partnership working between statutory and voluntary groups and the health and wellbeing impact on our community will be immense.South Down MLA Colin McGrath said the official opening of the new pitch was ldquotestament to the work done by Mrs Curran and the team at Ballyhornan, working alongside officials from a number of organisations and elected representatives.ldquoItrsquos a real joy to see a picture of the late Eddie McGrady in the community centre in Ballyhornan who officially opened the building, he continued.ldquoThis latest development should serve as a reminder as to what can be delivered when communities, political representatives and government bodies work together in a common effort. I can only hope we get to see more of these good news stories in the time ahead.Cllr Curran said he was ldquodelighted to attend last weekrsquos official opening ceremony and thanked the funders of the new pitch for their respective contributions.ldquoThese investments are investments in our community and something we should all be very proud of. However, none of this would have happened without the hard work and determination of Patricia Curran and her team, he continued.ldquoGetting to this point over the past  years was a hard road with plenty of potholes, but Patricia never gave up. I am delighted that with help she get over those hurdles. However, had it not been for her dedication, this new pitch development simply wouldnrsquot have been possible..prettyPhoto

title: Politicians say ‘no’ to plan for school
story: A NUMBER of politicians and school principals are opposed to creating a new integrated education college in the area.The proposed -place Mid Down Integrated Collegewould replace Blackwater Integrated College in Downpatrick, providing sixth-form places.Public consultation into the development proposal brought forward by the MDIC steering group ended in September and the Education Authorityhas already given its response to the parentsrsquo group behind the proposal.However, DUP politicians and three of four post-primary schools in the area mdash Saintfield High School, St Colmanrsquos High School and Sixth Form College in Ballynahinch and St Colmcillersquos High in Crossgar mdash have publicly voiced their concerns for the first time.Strangford MLA Harry Harvey said: ldquoI am disappointed that despite widespread opposition locally, the Education Authority continue to press ahead with these proposals. The nearby Saintfield High School, a school supported by the entire community, is in dire need of funding for expansion and refurbishment.ldquoI would call on the EA to listen to the local community and support a truly cross community educational establishment that is already in existence.Cllr Billy Walker, who represents the area, said he will not supporting the development proposal, which he described as ldquoill-thought.ldquoAs an elected representative, I will not be supporting the call for an integrated college in the Mid Down area, he told the Recorder.ldquoFirst and foremost, I want to put on record that I am not opposed to integrated education in any shape or form.Cllr Walker said along with Strangford MP Jim Shannon, they lobbied for a new integrated primary school at Drumlins in Ballynahinch and were also instrumental in helping to get the funding to turn Killyleagh Primary School into an integrated school.He continued: ldquoMy credentials speak for themselves. My concern is that we have four post-primary schools in the Rowallane area that have been very successful in the last number of years.ldquoThe four schools are totally opposed to it as this will put serious pressure on these schoolsa new integrated college opens.ldquoThese schools have an excellent track record in working together in a cross-community basis which I have seen at first hand.The councillor claimed he had seen figures to show that Blackwater College was under-subscribed by pupils and local people have made representations to him about the development proposal.He and Mr Shannon recently met with the principals of the four local schools, including The High School Ballynahinch, to hear their concerns.ldquoHow can you honestly push for another integrated school in the Mid Down area when you have another one already under-subscribed, Cllr Walker continued.ldquoIf Blackwater wants to expand, hopefully in the near future Down High will get the go-ahead for its new build which would leave a site for Blackwater to move to. Thatrsquos something I could add my support to further down the line.ldquoBut I will not be quiet on this any longer. I have given a commitment, as has Mr Shannon, to the four schools we have visited that we are % behind their very robust case against which has been submitted to the Education Authority.Tim Jackson, co-chair of the MDIC steering group, said that the development proposal was looking at the future need for an integrated college.The group had already collected  expressions of interests from parents who would send their children to the school,along with  parents who are supportive but donrsquot have children of school age year.He also stressed that the schools had been consulted before the end of the last school year and the public consultation completed by September.ldquoWe feel that people have not understood what our approach and what our proposal is trying to achieve, continued Mr Jackson.ldquoWe are very much about increasing the provision of integrated education in the area, not at the expense of other schools but to support and reflect the support for it in the area and Northern Ireland as a whole.ldquoWe are not about trying to compete with other schools but are trying to deliver something that supports that demand of integrated education. We have had lots of support from local primary schools, many of which are integrated themselves and from other integrated colleges, who you could argue we would be in more competition with.He said that the group had written to every MP and MLA in the area and pointed out that Cllr Walker had not yet been briefed by them.ldquoHe did not take up the opportunity for us to brief him which might have assuaged some of the concerns he has highlighted, said Mr Jackson.ldquoAnd while we are hoping to establish a sixth form, we are not aware that the other local schools have also applied to do something like that.He added that the group were looking at the EArsquos response to the development proposal ldquoin detail as we think that some of our assertions have not been fully understood or appreciated as the EA looks at historical data while we are looking into the future as the urban and geographical landscape changes.Mark Morgan, principal of St Colmanrsquos, described the proposal as a ldquosolo run that disregards accepted protocols and should be dismissed.He added: ldquoIt is imperative that any proposals for change in any sector of the education system must be aligned to the area planning process.Saintfield High School principal Sarah-Lucy Hynds pointed out that irrespective of the proposal, her school would continue to strive for its own expansion.She said: ldquoSaintfield High Schoolrsquos campaign to grow has remained the same for decades. The challenges we face as a result of our capped enrolment at Year  must now be addressed as a matter of urgency.Mr Seamus Hanna, principal of St Colmcillersquos, said he was disappointed with the lack of ldquoproper consultation.ldquoOn a very basic level, the proposal ignored the reality that our staff and students already come from erse faith backgrounds and our ethos is and always has been, pupil centred, welcoming and respecting every pupil, regardless of faith or academic ability, he said.ldquoOn a higher level, it ignored the reality that schools must work in partnership to place student needs above institutional interests. An inclusive and imaginative solution would have received our whole-hearted support, but this current proposal unfortunately fell short of this vision..prettyPhoto

title: Smell in Downpatrick causes stink with MLA
story: A PERSISTENT foul smelling odour which is prevalent in a large part of Downpatrick is to be addressed by Northern Ireland Water.The utility company is to invest in a permanent dosing plant that will be added to sewage before it is pumped for treatment, with the news welcomed by South Down MLA Colin McGrath.He said he had been lobbying for the odour issue to be addressed and had been working with NI Water to come up with a solution to the problem,The foul smell is noticeable in a large part of Downpatrick including the Ballymote Centre and parts of Killough Walk, Glebetown Drive, Bishops Brae Gardens, Mallard Road, Braeside Drive, Vianstown Road, Cathedral View, Pemberton Park and Pegasus Walk.ldquoEssentially we are looking at a quarter of Downpatrick affected by this odour issue, said Mr McGrath.ldquoIt has been a long road to get to this point, but NI Water is working to come up with a solution. I had previously requested a site meeting with officials to look at the key areas where the issue is most prominent and have been told that talks will take place, alongside some preliminary work.Mr McGrath said this included the continued dosing of sewage at an upstream wastewater pumping station, with NI Water looking to acquire additional land to construct a permanent dosing plant.ldquoSome very welcome news is that a local businessman plans to treat waste generated at his premises before it enters the sewerage system, he said.ldquoThe new system should be up and running in the coming weeks and this is the sort of community activity that Downpatrick does best local people identying solutions and putting their shoulder to the wheel.Mr McGrath said he will continue to seek progress reports from NI Water and keep local people up-to-date with whatrsquos happening.He added: ldquoItrsquos my hope that we are approaching an appropriate and sustainable solution to this long running issue..prettyPhoto

title: Trust committed to Downe MRI scanner
story: THE districtrsquos most senior health official said she would welcome regular conversations with the public and politicians in helping shape ldquosafe and appropriate services across the area.The commitment by South Eastern Trust chief executive Roisin Coulter came after a meeting she had on Monday with Newry, Mourne and Down councillors.Describing the talks as ldquouseful, positive, open and honest, Mrs Coulter said the health trust was ldquoproud to offer health and social care services from over  facilities across the Down area.She said that since the start of the coronavirus pandemic, all services apart from urgent care have been restored to the Downe Hospital in Downpatrick, where  inpatient beds are open and all outpatient services back up and running.The health chief also issued a reminder that the regional review of urgent and emergency care services across Northern Ireland which is being led by the Department of Health is expected shortly.ldquoIt is anticipated that this review will influence the future of all urgent and emergency care services throughout Northern Ireland, said Mrs Coulter, confirming that the health trust continues to provide a consultant led urgent care centre at the Downe from Monday to Friday between am and pm, alongside a nurse-led minor injuries service on Saturday and Sunday and GP out-of-hours service.ldquoThe urgent care centre has proven very successful with the public and treats an average of  patients every day, the health chief continued.ldquoWe remain committed to the installation of a new MRI scanner at the Downe. Indeed, this is a capital priority for the organisation. However, it requires approval from the Health and Social Care Board and the Department of Health.Mrs Coulter acknowledged that Covid- has had a signicant impact on the mental health of many people and posed unprecedented challenges for the health service.She continued: ldquoPrior to Covid, the system was already facing huge strategic challenges in the form of an ageing population, increasing demand, long and growing waiting lists, workforce pressures and the emergence of new and more expensive treatments.ldquoWithin the Trust, an enormous effort has been put in to introduce telephone and video-based appointments for mental health service users. The use of digital media to remotely contact service users has been very successful and has enabled teams to hold more consultation appointments.Mondayrsquos meeting with councillors also heard that the health and wellbeing of staff across the South Eastern Trust is of vital importance, with Mrs Coulter heartened to hear that council members said they appreciated and valued the care provided across all of the services the organisation provides locally.The chief executive stressed that she was both ldquooptimistic and realistic about the future as staff deal with the fourth surge of the pandemic and prepare for the expected winter pressures.Mrs Coulter added: ldquoOur health and social care services are facing unprecedented demand, and we so appreciate the tireless dedication and commitment of all our staff.ldquoI would welcome further, regular conversations with Newry, Mourne and Down Council and the public in shaping services that are safe and appropriate across the Down area..prettyPhoto

title: republican triumphalism hardens unionist attitudes and confirms suspicions
story: IN PICTURES: Fans say farewell as funeral of Rangers manager Walter Smith passes Ibrox   New Covid- iant ‘Delta Plus’ detected in Northern IrelandNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionRepublican triumphalism hardens unionist attitudes and confirms suspicionsA letter from Michael Palmer:By LettersThursday, th November , : amUpdated Thursday, th November , : am  "       "  The Sinn Fein Ard Fheis was the usual down-talking to unionists about how we should be ashamed of the NI stateI watched the Sinn Fein Ard Fheis over the weekend – trying to be open-minded and fair – though I couldn’t find anything in it that would even remotely appeal to someone from a unionist background. Instead, it was just the usual down-talking to unionists about how we should be ashamed of the Northern Ireland state. It is a tired historical revisionism that never changes where the British state is to blame for everything and republicans are to blame for nothing.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...Letter to the editorIt plays well to their audience but it repels me from anything to do with a united Ireland. This republican triumphalism is very damaging to the unionist community. It hardens attitudes. It confirms suspicions. It builds barriers. If polls are to be believed, Sinn Fein is due to expand its electoral representation in the near future. If this is how they are behaving now, how will they behavethis strength is realised  I don’t think they’ll magically moderate. Rather, any success will encourage them to go further down this triumphalist route.The many assumptions I heard from the Ard Fheis on a united Ireland were cringe-worthy. A border poll has not even been called, let alone won, and yet victory is already taken for granted. This is arrogant and insulting to the unionist community. Yet, these assumptions will also be their downfall, as outside republican echo chambers, exist many other communities of people who are not convinced about Sinn Fein’s version of a united Ireland.Nevertheless, unionists must learn from the rise of Sinn Fein. The good news for unionism is that discomfort is a key ingredient to growth. We will harness our discomfort to achieve positive outcomes.Michael Palmer, Ulster Unionist Party member, NewtownardsDUP MLA: SF posture about discrimination yet republicans escape scrutiny of their own murky past——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: orange order not surprised by huge interest in northern ireland centenary parade date announcement
story: Man hospitalised and others arrested on suspicion of attempted murder after incident in NI town   NI High Street Voucher: How long can it take to get spend local card and what to doyou havent received itNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPoliticsOrange Order not surprised by huge interest in Northern Ireland Centenary parade date announcementAn Orange Order chief says he is not at all surprised by the dramatic level of interest shown in plans for a gigantic Orange parade marking  years of Northern Ireland’s existence.By Philip BradfieldThursday, th November , : amUpdated Thursday, th November , : am  "       "  Yesterday the News Letter reported that the order will parade on May  next year to celebrate the centenary - an event originally planned for May this year but delayed due to Covid. The story proved exceptionally popular online. Orange Order Grand Secretary Mervyn Gibson said he was not in the least surprised by the level of interest. “We knew everybody was awaiting a new date and lookingforward to the celebration parade,” he said.“People very much enjoyed the  Ulster Covenant parade and wanted to see it replicated in many ways. It was so huge that the parade was still leaving Sandy Row as the  proceedings had finished at Stormont. ”   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...The Orange OrderNext year’s parade is planned to follow the same route, but in reverse.“I don’t think you could heighten interest any more - this will be people’s first chance to have a large centenary celebration,” he addedNationalist commentator Malachi O’Doherty said he hopes the Orangemen have a good day. “But there is no sense now in which an Orange Celebration can be regarded as representative of Northern Ireland, a region which is no longer defined by Protestantism or Orangeism,” he said. Tens of thousands took part in the Ulster Covenant centenary parade in . The Orange Order says many people want to replicate the experience. Picture: Charles McQuillan Pacemaker.“There was a time in my youth when a minister might lose his job for not being an Orangeman or for attending a Catholic mass. But those days are long over. Let them celebrate the survival of Orangeism into a secular and erse culture, butthey want to say they are celebrating Northern Ireland, then let them invite [LGBT] Pride and a few others to join them.”Commentator Ruth Dudley Edwards said opposition to NI Centenary celebrations will only have heightened interest in the parade. Sinn Fein’s “mean-mindedness” in stling a range of centenary events and Irish President Michael D Higgins’ decision not to attend a commemoration event in Armagh were “bound to provoke a reaction” among grassroots unionists, she said, “as was the establishment’s timidity about commemorating the centenary”. She added: “But I’m all for a great celebration of the courage of all those from all backgrounds who withstood terrorism democratically and who worked hard to make Northern Ireland prosper. I’m much encouraged at how many young people reject tribal labels and just love the place where they live. I look forward to being in Belfast next year to cheer the parade.”MORE NEWSLord Alderdice hopes book will help Presbyterian Church in Ireland learn tolerance on homosexualityDate is set for massive Orange centenary parade in Northern Ireland – akin to ’s vast Ulster Covenant marchA message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: ogmore by sea one uks best dog friendly beaches
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe region comes in at fth place with  beaches dogs are able to use  days a year. It comes in behind Pembrokeshire at first place with  beaches, Devon with , Cornwall with  and Anglesey with .The research comes as people are looking to continue to holiday at home as Wales and the UK begins to re-open and international travel is still looking unsure. It was carried out by Uswitch and can be viewed here: https:www.uswitch car-insurance guides uk-dog-friendly-beaches-mapped In their list of  beaches from across the UK, Ogmore Beach comes in third place behind Cayton Bay in North Yorkshire and Oxwich Beach near Swansea.MORE NEWS:Coronavirus: One in three adults in Wales now fully vaccinatedDream seaside home has seven bedrooms and an amazing al-fresco entertaining areaLaurence Llewellyn-Bowen joins campaign to transform oldest Vale homeThe Uswitch guide says that Ogmore Beach is best for fishing, walking and dog-friendly pubs and the car park costs pound a day, with dogs allowed on the beach all-year round and there are no restrictions. They say that the beach is a sand and shingle beach and has a reputation for being one of the cleanest in the region. There is a coastal walk, chance to go fishing, surfing and views of Tusker Rock.For those owners who may not yet have ventured to the beach with their pups or are concerned about behaviour while at the beach, Wood Greenrsquos dog behaviour and training specialist, Wendy Kruger, has provided some tips to prepare your dog for the beach.bull Ensure your dogrsquos microchip and collar tag details are up to date ndash just in case.bull Get used to checking ground surface temperatures before you take your dog out, as dry sand can be too hot for dogsrsquo paws on sunny days. To check the ground temperature, place the back of your hand on the ground. If its too hot to hold comfortably for five seconds, itrsquos too hot for dogsrsquo paws..removebull Practise basic, reward-based training when out and about to help your dog to maintain focus and engagement on walks.bull Recall is also an area that needs particular attention. Evenyour dog has a great recall at home, its not something that can be guaranteed in unfamiliar environments with exciting new distractions. Games with toys are a fantastic way to help your dog engage with you when there are other distractions around. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe duo will share the honour following a directive by the International Olympic Committee in March and were selected by a Team GB  following nominations from their respective sports.Mills won sailing gold in  in the womenrsquos  class alongside Saskia Clark, and will defend the title in Tokyo with a new team-mate, Eilidh McIntyre.Welsh Conservative Senedd leader Andrew RT Davies MS has publicly congratulated Dinas Powysrsquo Team GB sailor Hannah Mills.He said: "Irsquom absolutely thrilled that Hannah, from Dinas Powys in my region, will be flying the Union flag for Wales at the opening of the Tokyo Olympics on Friday."Hannah will be putting Dinas Powys on the map as she becomes the first female sailor to carry the Union flag at an opening ceremony."I look forward to watching the ceremony and Irsquoll be cheering Hannah on to bring back another medal for Wales and Team GB."Only around  of around  Team GB athletes are expected to march at the opening ceremony, with many reluctant to take part because of coronavirus concerns so close to their events.Pickings were therefore slim for those responsible for selecting which man and woman would fly the flags for Britain, but it speaks volumes for the countryrsquos past recent success that the  was able to select two Olympic champions. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: vale author details history welsh pubs new book
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityGraham Loveluck-Edwards has announced the release of his new book Historic Pubs of Wales where he relishes in some of the more colourful myths, legends and stories from Wales ancient past and oldest pubs.Included in the book is The Captains We, in Sully,a house originally owned by a captain."I have always loved old pubs, and we are blessed to have so many belters here in Wales," added Mr Loveluck-Edwards.Graham Loveluck-Edwards out snapping some pubs for his book "For example, the pub which claims to have an elephant buried under its beer garden, or the pub where funeral parties take a short cut to the cemetery through the bar to keep an ancient right of access alive, or the pub that claims to have invented pancake day and so many more."In all, Ive compiled over  incredible stories based around  amazing old pubs - is there any truth to them "Some for sure, but this book captures them and puts them in the context of history so you can be the judge."MORE NEWS:The book also contains a travel guide so readers can go on a tour around Wales and visit all the pubs in the book.You can find out more at www.talesfromhistoricpubsofwales.The book is available to buy now "As you can imagine for such a book the research was relentless and thorough, and a lot of fun," he added."Pubs have had such a tough time in the last year with us going in and out of lockdowns and with the introduction of social distancing measures."Sixteenth centuryinns are usually a warren of tiny rooms so being two metres apart has made opening and trading near impossible for many."So, a book which celebrates all that is great about our old pubs, which tells people their history, where to find them and what to expect when you get there has been welcomed by all landlords." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityDerek Brockway has made quite a splash in the weather world ndash following  years of working at Met Office he joined the BBC back in .The Welshman is also a keen walker ndash having recently launched a book on walking Weatherman Walking: The Welsh Coast which features guided walks of Walesrsquo Coast Path and offers walkersrsquo of all ages to discover new routes and places of interest along the way.On Saturdayhe will be at Grfin Books, on Windsor Road, to sign copied of his latest book, as well as previous titles in the series.The day will give people the opportunity to meet him and have a chat about their favourite Welsh walks.Tickets are not needed, just pop in on Saturday October  between pm and pm.Derekrsquos no stranger to the Vale of Glamorgan earlier this year he joined Ramblers Cymru on a walk from Merthyr Mawr to Southerndown ndash one of the rambles features in his latest book.
